questions.text: A male infant presented with distension of abdomen shortly after birth with a history of not passing meconium. Subsequently, a barium enema was done and its findings are shown below. This disease is associated with which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The image depicts a barium enema showing a dilated right colon with a transition zone in the mid-descending colon characteristic of Hirschsprung's disease. Hirschsprung disease is associated with Down syndrome. 10% of all cases of Hirschsprung disease occur in children with Down syndrome.

Hirschsprung disease is also known as congenital aganglionic megacolon. The premature arrest of normal migration of neural crest cells from the cecum to the rectum produces aganglionosis of the distal intestinal segment. This causes functional obstruction of the affected bowel and proximal dilation. Diagnosis requires documenting the absence of ganglion cells within the affected segment.

Heterozygous loss-of-function mutations in the receptor tyrosine kinase RET account for the majority of familial and sporadic Hirschsprung disease cases. There is an association between Downs syndrome and Hirschsprung disease as well. The disease is more common in males, but, when present in females, the affected aganglionic segment tends to be longer.

Diagnosis : 

Histologic confirmation that ganglion cells are absent within the affected segment through hematoxylin and eosin-stained sections or immunohistochemical stains for acetylcholinesterase.

Based on the segments affected, they are classified into -

  • Short-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease limited to the rectosigmoid segment
  • Long-segment Hirschsprung disease - Disease having proximal extension beyond the rectosigmoid segment

The rectum is always affected, but the length of the additional involved segments varies widely. In most cases, the abnormality extends to the sigmoid colon, but in severe cases, the entire colon may be involved.

The aganglionic region may have a grossly normal or contracted appearance. The normally innervated proximal colon undergoes progressive dilation and may become massively distended (congenital megacolon) as a result of the distal obstruction.

questions.text: A screening test that has 80% sensitivity is done on two towns A and B. The prevalence of the disease is 10% in A and 40% in B. What does a positive test result mean?

choices.text: The person definitely has the disease, whether he lives in A or B
The person does not have the disease, whether he lives in A or B
A person living in A who tests positive is more likely to be a true positive
A person living in B who tests positive is more likely to be a true positive

questions.solution:
A person living in B who tests positive is more likely to be a true positive.

The predictive value of a positive test indicates the probability that a patient with a positive test result has, in fact, the disease (true positive). This predictive value depends on the sensitivity, specificity, and the disease prevalence. If the disease is more prevalent in a given population, the predictive value of the positive screening test will be more accurate. Hence, a positive test in a person living in town B, which has a higher prevalence is more likely to be a true positive.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the given graph?

choices.text: Inhibitor binds to the active site
Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site
Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition
Vmax decreases and Kmax is unchanged

questions.solution:
The given graph shows competitive inhibition in which the value of Vmax remains constant and the Km value increases.

When the active site or catalytic site of an enzyme is occupied by a substance other than the substrate of that enzyme, this type of inhibition is known as Competitive inhibition. eg: succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate. The inhibitor binds to the active site. The inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site. Competitive Inhibition is reversible.

 

Lineweaver Burk Plot for other enzyme inhibition,

Related Pearl: Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Reversible inhibitors are of two types:

  • Competitive inhibitors
  • Non-Competitive inhibitors

Difference between Competitive & Non-Competitive inhibitors

Competitive inhibitors

Non-Competitive inhibitors

Succinate dehydrogenase is inhibited by Malonate

Pyruvate kinase is inhibited by alanine

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically similar & have same shape

Substrate & inhibitor are chemically not similar & have different shape

Inhibitor binds to active site

Inhibitor binds away from active site, i.e., at allosteric site

Inhibitor does not change the shape of the active site

Inhibitor changes the shape of the active site

Increase in substrate concentration reduces the inhibition

Increase in substrate concentration does not affect the inhibition

Vmax remains constant

Vmax decreases

Km Increases

Km remains constant

questions.text: A biochemist is studying the effect of RNA interference in gene expression. He is neutralizing targeted mRNAs using microRNAs (miRNA). In the RNA induced silencing complex (RISC) complex, these miRNAs can modulate mRNA function by all these mechanisms except _____

choices.text: Inhibition of translation by targeting the 5′-methyl cap-binding translation factor
Trimming small double-stranded RNAs into molecules that can block translation

questions.solution:
DICER trims small double-stranded RNA and generates short, double-stranded (ds) miRNA molecules that can block translation. In the RISC complex, miRNAs can modulate mRNA function by any of the three mechanisms:

  • Promoting mRNA degradation directly
  • Stimulating CCR4/NOT complex-mediated poly(A) tail degradation
  • Inhibition of translation by targeting the 5′-methyl cap-binding translation factor.

Micro-RNA (miRNA) is an endogenous non-coding RNA. The primary function of miRNA is to modulate the translation of target mRNAs into their corresponding proteins. After the target RNA is transcribed from its gene (post-transcriptional), the miRNA may either induce mRNA cleavage or repress its translation. This is referred to as gene silencing.

RNA interference(RNAi) is a biological process in which miRNA/siRNA molecules inhibit gene expression by neutralizing targeted mRNAs.The microRNA (miRNA) belongs to a group of non-coding genes. The miRNA genes are transcribed but not translated into proteins. They play a role in the regulation of the expression of the target gene by post-transcriptional silencing.

Mechanism:

  • The miRNA gene present in the nucleus is transcribed to primary miRNA, which is further converted to pre-miRNA by an enzyme DROSHA intranuclearly and exported to the cytoplasm by an export protein.
  • The pre-miRNA undergoes trimming, by an enzyme called DICER, into mature single-stranded miRNA.
  • The mature miRNA is associated with a multiprotein aggregate called RNA-induced silencing complex (RISC).
  • The target mRNAs contain seed sequences in their 3′ untranslated region (UTR) that determines the specificity of miRNA binding and gene silencing.

Depending on the base pairing between the miRNA strand and its target mRNA, the RISC causes gene silencing either by mRNA cleavage or by repressing its translation.

siRNA is similar in function to miRNA and is used in RNA interference.

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about perinatal mortality rate?

choices.text: Crown heel length of at least 35cms
Deaths within first week of life included

questions.solution:
Perinatal mortality rate (PMR) includes stillbirths which are categorized as late fetal deaths.

The perinatal mortality rate is a significant indicator in the evaluation of obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth. It is calculated as given below to enable international comparisons. Late fetal death or stillbirth is the death of a fetus that weighs 1000 grams or more (corresponds to 28 weeks of gestation). Early neonatal death is the death of a fetus from birth to the first 7 days of life (Option D).

The following parameters must be considered while calculating PMR:

  • Babies chosen for inclusion in the PMR should be those above a minimum birth weight of 1000g. (Option A)
  • If birth weight is not available, then gestational age must be at least 28 weeks.
  • If both of the above are not available, then the crown heel length must be at least 35 cm. (Option C)

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presents with weakness and muscle cramps involving both legs. He also reported difficulty in swallowing food. On examination, he is found to be alert and oriented. Both lower limbs exhibit fasciculations with significant atrophy and extensor plantar reflex. The reflexes in both upper and lower limbs are exaggerated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of amyotrophic lateral sclerosis.

Amyotrophic lateral sclerosis (ALS) is a type of progressive motor neuron disease. The pathological hallmark is the destruction and death of both upper (UMN) and lower motor neurons (LMN). Irrespective of what is involved first, eventually ALS will involve both UMN and LMN. The motor neuron disease involving selectively the upper motor neurons is called primary lateral sclerosis, while the one involving selectively the lower motor neurons is called spinomuscular atrophy.

Patients present with insidious onset asymmetric bilateral weakness of the distal part of the lower limbs. There may be a history of cramping, particularly early in the morning. Lower motor neuron death causes muscle atrophy and fasciculations. Upper motor neuron involvement presents as exaggerated tendon reflexes and spasticity. Some of the patients also tend to develop frontotemporal dementia. However, the sensory, bowel and bladder functions and cognition is preserved even in the late stages of the disease.

Other options:

Option A: Guillain-Barre syndrome is an acute inflammatory demyelinating peripheral neuropathy that occurs 1-3 weeks following an acute infectious process. It results in LMN type of palsy with the absence of deep tendon reflexes. It is also associated with sensory findings like loss of proprioception and autonomic features such as lability of blood pressure. These findings are absent in ALS because only the motor neurons are involved.

Option B: Vitamin B12 deficiency leads to abnormalities in the posterior and lateral column function that results in loss of vibration and position sense, progressive spastic weakness, and sensory ataxia. Loss of deep tendon reflexes due to associated peripheral neuropathy can also be seen. However, there is an extensor plantar response due to the involvement of the corticospinal tracts.

Option C: Lambert-Eaton syndrome is a paraneoplastic neuromuscular disorder that presents with proximal muscle weakness, arreflexia, and autonomic dysfunction. In 60% of patients, there may be associated cancer, usually small cell lung cancer.

questions.text: A 50-year-old diabetic patient presented with cough and breathlessness and a diagnosis of bronchopulmonary aspergillosis is made. The causative organism was found to be Aspergillus fumigatus. Which of the following can be seen on Sabouraud agar on the culture of the organism?
questions.solution:
On the culture of Aspergillus fumigatus on Sabouraud agar, dark-green colored colonies are seen.

Aspergillus fumigatus is the most common pathogenic species. It can cause allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, aspergilloma, invasive aspergillosis in immunocompromised patients, and superficial infections like otomycosis or mycotic keratitis are the other presentations.

This can be due to prolonged treatment with steroids or retro-positive status. It starts as pneumonia, which can later spread to involve other organs.

Histopathological examination of the tissue section shows characteristic dichotomous branching at an acute angle. The hyphae stain poorly with hematoxylin and eosin, so periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) stain is used. 

Other methods for diagnosis include the detection of galactomannan (Aspergillus cell-wall component) and culture isolation. Aspergillus fumigatus grows dark green colonies, while Aspergillus niger appears black. Yellow-green colonies are seen in the case of Aspergillus flavus. Microscopic examination of colonies stained with lactophenol cotton blue would show septate hyphae and conidiophores. 

Intravenous voriconazole, itraconazole, and posaconazole are currently used for the treatment.

The image below shows septate hyphae with 45o branching and conidiophores:

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy presented with a white pupillary reflex for which enucleation was done. The histopathological specimen is given below. Identify the marked finding and the associated likely diagnosis.

choices.text: Irregular hyperchromatic nuclei in a fibrillar background, Astrocytoma

questions.solution:
The histopathological finding shows Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes and its associated diagnosis in a 7-year-old child with a whitish pupillary reflex is retinoblastoma. Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes refer to an arrangement of columnar cells around a central lumen. 

Retinoblastoma is a malignant proliferation of immature retinal neural cells and is the most common intraocular malignancy in children. It is associated with mutations in the RB1 gene at chromosome 13q14. It is a tumor of a group called small round blue cell tumors because the immature retinal neural cells are seen as small round cells with large nuclei.

White pupillary reflex or leukocoria is the most common presenting feature, followed by a squint which is usually convergent. Rarely, the child may present with nystagmus and defective vision.

Image showing leukocoria of left eye.

 

Histopathology of the tumor shows small round cells with large nuclei. Microscopic features of a well-differentiated tumor include Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes (highly specific of retinoblastoma), Homer-Wright rosettes, pseudorosettes, and fleurettes formation. Areas of necrosis and calcification can also be seen.

The histopathological image of retinoblastoma is shown below.

 
Treatment typically involves chemotherapy plus focal therapy. The commonly used three-drug regimen is the CVE regimen consisting of vincristine, carboplatin, and etoposide. Focal therapy includes cryotherapy, laser photocoagulation, thermotherapy, plaque radiotherapy, and external beam radiotherapy. Enucleation is done when: 
  • the tumor involves more than half of the retina
  • the optic nerve is involved
  • glaucoma is present and the anterior chamber is involved

In the stage of extraocular extension, the globe bursts through the sclera, usually near the limbus or the optic disc. This is followed by rapid fungation and involvement of extraocular tissues resulting in marked proptosis. Distant metastasis occurs through the lymphatic spread and the direct extension by continuity to the optic nerve and brain.

Other options:

Option B: Medulloblastoma is a malignant embryonal tumor of childhood that occurs exclusively in the cerebellum. Patients usually present with headaches, ataxia, and signs of brainstem involvement.

Histologically, the tumor is very densely cellular. Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and elongated or crescent-shaped hyperchromatic nuclei. Tumor cells form Homer Wright rosettes. They express neuronal markers such as synaptophysin.

 

Option C: Rhabdomyosarcoma is the most common soft tissue sarcoma of childhood. The child usually presents with rapidly progressive unilateral proptosis. There are 4 subtypes - embryonal, alveolar, botryoid, and pleomorphic. Cells show light microscopic features of striated muscle differentiation. Immunohistochemistry is positive for desmin. 

 

Option D: Astrocytoma of the retina and optic nerve head is rare. It is usually asymptomatic and is most frequently seen in tuberous sclerosis. Fundus examination reveals a yellowish or white plaque, nodule, or mulberry-like lesion. These lesions are semitransparent peripherally and calcified centrally. 

The image below shows a calcified astrocytoma.

Histological finding includes hypercellularity, enlarged, elongated, or irregular hyperchromatic nuclei embedded in a fibrillar background.

Related Pearl: Reese Ellsworth classification for retinoblastoma

Group Prognosis for maintenance of sight Features
1 Very favourable
  • Solitary tumor, <4DD, at or behind equator
  • Multiple tumors, all <4DD, all at or behind the equator
2 Favourable
  • Solitary tumor, 4–10 DD, at or behind the equator
  • Multiple tumors, all 4–10DD all behind the equator
3 Possible
  • Any lesion anterior to equator
  • Solitary tumor, >10DD behind equator
4 Unfavorable
  • Multiple tumors, some >10 DD
  • Any lesion extending anteriorly to ora serrata
5 Highly unfavorable
  • Massive tumors involving more than one half of retina
  • Vitreous seeding

Related Pearl: Histological Features of CNS Tumors

Pilocytic Astrocytomas:

  • Biphasic architecture - loose microcystic component and dense fibrillary areas
  • Bipolar cells (tumor cells): thin, long hairlike processes that are GFAP - positive. 
  • Rosenthal fibers: eosinophilic corkscrew - shaped inclusions
  • Eosinophilic granular bodies: mulberry - like inclusions 

 

Medulloblastoma:

  • Very densely cellular, with sheets of small primitive appearing small blue cells
  • Individual tumor cells have scant cytoplasm and hyperchromatic nuclei that are frequently elongated or crescent-shaped
  • Tumor cells form Homer - Wright rosettes (pseudorosettes) with a central neuropil

 

Ependymoma:

  • Ependymal rosettes: gland - like round or elongated structures that resemble the embryologic ependymal canal, with long, delicate processes extending into the lumen 
  • Perivascular pseudorosettes: perivascular nuclear - free zone consisting of thin ependymal processes radiating toward the central blood vessel

 

Oligodendroglioma:

  • Fried - egg appearance: sheets of regular cells with spherical nuclei containing finely granular chromatin (similar to normal oligodendrocytes) surrounded by a clear halo of vacuolated cytoplasm. 
  • Chicken - wire capillaries: a delicate network of anastomosing capillaries

 

Retinoblastoma: 

  • Composed of collections of small, round cells with hyperchromatic nuclei
  • Flexner - Wintersteiner rosettes: arrangements of a single layer of tumor cells around an apparent lumen
  • Homer - Wright rosettes: a ring of cells with an eosinophilic fibrillary center
  • Fleurettes: retinoblastoma cells that have undergone greater photoreceptor differentiation and group together as a bouquet. Fleurettes lack mitosis or necrosis.

questions.text: Following is the otoscopic image of a surfer complaining of deafness. Pure tone audiometry is suggestive of conductive hearing loss. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The otoscopic finding is suggestive of exostoses.

A surfer with a clinical diagnosis of a conductive type of hearing loss with the otoscopic image showing multiple, sessile bumpy swellings in the external auditory canal draws us to a diagnosis of exostoses.

Exostoses are bilateral multiple smooth sessile bony swellings in the deeper canal seen in surfers. It is also called as surfer’s ear. They can be removed with a high-speed drill to restore the normal external auditory canal.

The following CT image shows the difference between a normal ear canal and an ear canal with exostoses.

The following table differentiates osteoma and exostoses

Osteoma

Exostoses/surfer's Ear

Single

Multiple

Unilateral

Bilateral

Pedunculated, hard

Sessile, smooth

Outer canal

Inner, deeper canal

arises from cancellous bone

arises from compact bone

Ceruminoma: It is a tumour of modified sweat glands. It presents as a smooth, firm, skin-covered polypoid swelling in the outer part of the meatus. Wide surgical excision is done. 

Sebaceous adenoma: It arises from sebaceous glands of the meatus and presents as smooth, skin-covered swelling in the outer meatus. Treatment is surgical excision.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy has had a fever for the past 5 days. On physical examination, he has cervical lymphadenopathy of the right side, congested pharynx, and dry cracked lips. A throat swab is done and the rapid strep test is negative. The child has a maculopapular rash, and changes in the tongue and hands as shown in the image. Considering the most likely diagnosis, what would be the treatment protocol for this patient?

choices.text: Treated with prednisolone (2 mg/kg) and low-dose aspirin
Treated with prednisolone (2 mg/kg) and high-dose aspirin
Treated with 2g/kg of IVIG and low-dose aspirin
Treated with 2g/kg of IVIG and high-dose aspirin

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points towards a diagnosis of Kawasaki disease. Children with acute Kawasaki disease should be treated with 2g/kg of IVIG and high-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day) as soon as possible after the diagnosis.

Kawasaki disease is an acute febrile illness in childhood seen worldwide. It is a vasculitis with a predilection for the coronary arteries. About 20-25% of untreated children develop coronary artery abnormalities including aneurysms. Therefore, Echocardiography should be performed at diagnosis and after 2-3 weeks of illness.

Risk factors for coronary aneurysms in Kawasaki's disease:

  • Age younger than 1 year or older than 9 years
  • Male sex
  • Fever ≥14 days
  • Hematocrit <35 percent 
  • Serum sodium concentration <135 mEq/L
  • White blood cell count >12,000/mm3 

The clinical features are shown in the image below: 

(A) Bilateral, non-exudative conjunctival injection with perilimbal sparing.

(B) Strawberry tongue and bright red, swollen lips with vertical cracking and bleeding.

(C) Erythematous rash involving perineum.

(D) Erythema of the palms, which is often accompanied by painful, brawny edema of the dorsum of the hands.

(E) Erythema of the soles, and swelling dorsum of the feet.

(F) Desquamation of the fingers.

(G) Erythema and induration at the site of a previous vaccination with BCG.

(H) Perianal erythematous desquamation.

 

Patients with acute KD are treated with 2 g/kg of IVIG as a single infusion, usually administered over 10-12 hr within 10 days of disease onset, and ideally as soon as possible after diagnosis. Moderate (30-50 mg/kg/day divided every 6 hr) to high-dose aspirin (80-100 mg/kg/day divided every 6 hr) is administered until the patient is afebrile for at least 48 hours. 

Long-term treatment: Patients with a small and solitary coronary aneurysm to be treated with aspirin indefinitely, and long-term follow-up with periodic echocardiography. Patients with multiple and larger aneurysms may require the addition of antiplatelet agents and anticoagulation because of the risk of thrombosis. Patients on long-term aspirin therapy should receive annual influenza vaccination to reduce the risk of Reye syndrome.

Related Pearl: Kawasaki disease criteria

Diagnostic criteria of Kawasaki disease: 

Fever of five days or more duration plus four out of the following five criteria:

  1. Oropharyngeal changes (90% of cases)
  2. Changes in peripheral extremities (90% of cases)
  3. Cervical lymphadenopathy (~75% of cases)
  4. Polymorphous rash (95% of cases)
  5. Bilateral non-purulent conjunctival infection (90% of cases)

questions.text: A young patient presents with a persistent and painful penile erection. He had been taking sildenafil without proper medical consultation. Which of the following drugs can be given as an intracavernosal injection to this patient?
questions.solution:
Intracavernous injection of phenylephrine can be given to this patient to relieve the priapism and prevent ischemic damage.

Priapism (sustained painful penile erection >4 hours) is a common and serious side effect of sildenafil. Other causes of priapism include trazodone (serotonin receptor antagonist) and cantharidin from Spanish fly.

Phenylephrine is an α1 selective adrenergic agonist. It serves as a vasoconstrictor of the arterioles and reduces the engorgement of cavernosal space, thus reversing priapism.

Phenylephrine is a pure α1 adrenergic agonist. By means of acting on α1 receptors, it increases the peripheral arterial resistance, and decreases the capacity of venous capacitance vessels, leading to an increased venous return to the heart. There is a baroreceptor reflex-mediated increase in vagal tone due to which there is marked bradycardia. However, due to increased venous return, stroke volume remains high and so does the cardiac output.

Other options:

Option B: Oxymetazoline is a vasoconstrictor used in nasal congestion and sinus surgeries. It is available generally as a nasal spray.

Options C and D: Papaverine (with or without phentolamine) and alprostadil are used in the treatment of erectile dysfunction.

Related Pearl: Drugs acting on the receptors of autonomic nervous system

Related Pearl: PDE inhibitors

questions.text: Which of the following monoclonal antibodies is approved for use in familial hypercholesterolemia?
questions.solution:
Alirocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits PCSK9 that is used in familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 is a serine protease that causes lysosomal degradation of the LDL receptors present on the surface of the hepatocytes. Monoclonal antibodies directed against PCSK9 such as alirocumab and evolocumab counter this and cause the persistence of LDL receptors on hepatocytes. This leads to more LDL uptake from the circulation, bringing down the LDL-cholesterol levels in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia.

PCSK9 inhibitors are indicated only as adjunctive therapy in patients with familial hypercholesterolemia or established atherosclerotic cardiovascular disease who have elevated LDL-cholesterol levels despite being on maximum statin therapy.

Other options:

Option A: Omalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against IgE. It is approved for use in patients with asthma with elevated levels of circulating IgE.

Option C: Bevacizumab is a monoclonal antibody against VEGF. It is approved for use in patients with metastatic colorectal cancers and wet age-related macular degeneration (intravitreal administration).

Option D: Natalizumab is a monoclonal antibody against α4 integrin. It prevents α4β1 interaction with VCAM-1, thus restricting T-cell diapedesis into the brain. It is approved for use in multiple sclerosis. The use of natalizumab in a patient requires checking for antibodies against the JC virus. The presence of these antibodies indicates a latent infection, and is a contraindication to the use of natalizumab. Natalizumab can cause JC-virus antibody-positive patients to develop multifocal leukoencephalopathy. 

Note: Vedolizumab is a monoclonal antibody that prevents only α4β7 interaction and is approved for use in Crohn's disease and ulcerative colitis.

questions.text: During your surgery internship, you observe the following incision was made by the senior resident while performing an abdominal surgery. What is the name of the incision  being performed here?
questions.solution:
The above image shows Chevron (rooftop) incision.

Chevron (rooftop) incision is a bilateral anterior subcostal incision joined in the midline. It can be used to access the organs of the upper abdomen and diaphragm.

A Mercedes-Benz modification of this incision includes a midline incision superiorly, providing further access to the upper abdomen or the lower mediastinum.

Other options:

Option A: Kocher’s incision is a right subcostal incision, which is commonly used in open cholecystectomy surgeries.

Option B: Mayo Robson’s incision is a right upper paramedian incision extended like a hockey stick to the midline. It is indicated in cholecystectomy

Option D: Rutherford-Morrison’s incision is an oblique muscle-cutting incision, with its lower end over McBurney’s point and extending obliquely upwards and laterally, as necessary.

questions.text: An epidemiologist is calculating the incubation period for measles in children aged 2 to 14 years. He was assigned a rural area with a sizeable portion of unvaccinated children and adolescents. He takes the sample size as 100. The median incubation period is 10 days. Given that the standard error is 0.4 what is the standard deviation in this case?
questions.solution:
The standard deviation in this case 4.

From the formula for standard error (SE) = Standard deviation/ square root of sample size,

Standard deviation (SD) = (Standard error) x (square root of sample size)
                                          = 0.4 x √100
                                    SD = 0.4 x 10 = 4

Related Pearl: The Standard Error and Related Aspects

  1. Sampling Errors: They refer to natural, expected, random variations in the data. They are not errors per se. Hence, the mean of the sample always differs from the mean of the total population. For example, consider a population with a mean weight of 75. If we take a sample of 500 people from this population, the mean weight of this sample will not be exactly 75.
  2. Random Sampling Distribution of Means (or Sampling Distribution):
    • This refers to the distribution formed when all possible sample means from a population are plotted in a frequency distribution.
    • Sampling distributions provide information into how different the samples are from each other and from the population mean.
    For example, the hemoglobin levels of 100 randomly selected women in a city are measured and their sample mean is calculated. This is done every day for a year with the same sample size but different women each time. If all the sample means of hemoglobin levels of all women are plotted on frequency distribution, the resulting distribution would be called the sampling distribution. It would resemble a normal distribution.
  3. Central Limit Theorem: According to this theorem, as the sample size increases:
    • The sampling distribution tends towards a normal distribution curve (bell curve)
      1. Regardless of the population's actual distribution shape
      2. Assuming all samples are identical in size
    • The sample mean and standard deviations become closer to the population mean and standard deviations 
  4. Standard Error of Mean (SE or σ x̄ ):
    • The standard error is a measure of the extent to which the sample means deviate from the true population mean. It is nothing but the standard deviation of the sampling distribution.
      1. Sample means closer to the population mean lead to a lower SE and a narrower and thinner distribution curve 
      2. More variation in sample means leads to a higher SE and a broader curve 
    SE = Standard deviation / √Sample size

          σ x̄ = σ/√n

Hence, SE is inversely related to √sample size.

questions.text: All of the following are the components of the biophysical profile except_____
questions.solution:
Respiratory rate is not a component of the biophysical profile.

Biophysical profile/Manning’s score:

Parameters Minimal Normal Criteria Score
Non-stress Test (NST)   ≥2 accelerations within 20-40 minutes. 2
Fetal breathing movements   ≥ 1 episode of rhythmic breathing lasting > 30 seconds. 2
Gross body movements   ≥ 3 discrete body/limb movements 2
Fetal muscle tone   ≥ 1 episode of active extension(limb or trunk) with return of flexion. 2
Amniotic fluid volume A pocket of amniotic fluid that measures at least 2 cm in two perpendicular planes (2 ×2 cm pocket) 2
  • Observation for 30 minutes
  • Normal score- 2; Abnormal- 0

questions.text: A researcher is studying DNA replication in prokaryotic cells. Which of the following enzymes is responsible for the unwinding of DNA?
questions.solution:
Helicase is responsible for the ATP-driven unwinding of DNA.

Other options

Option A: DNA Polymerase I (Pol I) helps in gap filling following DNA replication, repair, and recombination

Option C: Topoisomerase helps in relieving torsional strain that results from helicase-induced unwinding.

Option D: DNA polymerase III (Pol III) helps in leading strand synthesis and DNA proofreading.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in DNA Replication

Enzyme Function

DNA polymerase II (Pol II) DNA proofreading and repair

Single-strand binding proteins (SSBs) Prevents premature reannealing of dsDNA.
DNA ligase Seals the single strand nick between the nascent chain and Okazaki fragments on lagging strand.

Eukaryotic DNA Polymerases Functions Proofreading

questions.text: A young man complains of knee pain and a locking sensation in his knees for 3 days. He noticed this following a game of football a few days ago. He does not recall any acute event that precipitated the pain. The test shown in the image is done. What is the name of the test?
questions.solution:
The test done in the image is Apley's test. It is used to detect injuries to the menisci and it is done with the patient lying in the prone position.

A meniscal tear is a split or tear in the meniscus following a rotational or shearing force. The medial meniscus is affected more commonly than the lateral. Sometimes, it may be a vertical tear. If the separated fragment stays attached at the front and back, it is known as a bucket handle tear.

It presents as insidious or acute(in severe cases) onset pain, swelling, popping/catching/locking/giving out the sensation of the knee following a twisting injury to the knee. A plain X-ray appears normal, but MRI confirms the diagnosis.

Apley's test: This test is performed with a prone patient, the knee is flexed to 90  degrees and rotated while a compression force is applied, which is called the grinding test. Reproduction of symptoms indicates a torn meniscus. The distraction test involves repeated rotation while the leg is pulled upwards by the examiner, holding the thigh down. This produces increased pain only if there is ligament damage.

Other options:

Lachman test - done to detect anterior cruciate ligament injuries. Here the leg is in slight external rotation and the knee is in the position between flexion and extension. The femur is stabilized by one hand and the other hand applies the anterior force to the proximal tibia.

McMurray test: Done to detect menisci injuries. The patient's knee is completely flexed while he lies supine. One hand is used to stabilize and palpate the knee joint and the leg is internally and externally rotated with the other hand. The leg is then slowly extended. Meniscal injury presents as a palpable or audible click.

Thessaly test: With the affected knee flexed to 20 degrees and the foot placed flat on the ground, the patient takes his full weight on that leg while being supported by the examiner. The patient is then asked to twist his or her body to one side and then to the other three times. This test has shown a high diagnostic accuracy rate at the level of 95% in detecting meniscal tears.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of injury and tests for knee injuries

Structures Mechanism of injury Tests
Menisci Rotational force

McMurray test

Apley's grinding test

Squat test

Thessaly test
Medial collateral ligament Valgus force Valgus stress test
Lateral collateral ligament Varus force Varus stress test
Anterior cruciate ligament Anterior tibial displacement

Anterior drawer test 

Lachman test

Pivot shift test
Posterior cruciate ligament Posterior tibial displacement

Posterior drawer test

Sag sign

questions.text: A young male patient presents with a right-sided peri-orbital headache. He says that a single episode lasts for 30 seconds but it occurs 50-100 times a day. It is also associated with tearing and redness of the right eye. Which of the following drugs is best for long-term treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of unilateral headache with ipsilateral conjunctival congestion and lacrimation, lasting for seconds and recurring many times a day, is suggesting of short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT). The best drug for long-term preventive therapy for SUNCT is lamotrigine.

SUNCT is a primary headache disorder in which the patient complains of unilateral orbital or temporal pain, stabbing in quality. Each episode lasts for 5 to 240 seconds, and a patient can have hundreds of episodes per day. It is associated with ipsilateral conjunctival congestion and lacrimation. An episode can be brought on by cutaneous triggers as well, just like trigeminal neuralgia. However, there are no eye-related autonomic signs in trigeminal neuralgia. Moreover, there is a refractory period between the episodes of pain in trigeminal neuralgia, but this is not seen in SUNCT.

In hospitalized patients, an acute attack of SUNCT can be aborted with IV lignocaine (option B). For long-term management, the most effective drug is lamotrigine. Other drugs reported to have modest benefits include gabapentin, topiramate, and carbamazepine.

Indomethacin (option D) is used in the management of paroxysmal hemicrania. This is another type of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia, with the duration of attacks between 2 to 45 minutes and multiple such episodes throughout the day. Autonomic features are present.

Related Pearl: Trigeminal Autonomic Cephalalgia

Types of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia:

  • Cluster headache
  • Paroxysmal hemicranias
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache with conjunctival injection and tearing (SUNCT)
  • Short-lasting unilateral neuralgiform headache attacks with cranial autonomic features (SUNA)
  • Hemicrania continua

Character of pain  Stabbing /boring Throbbing pain /stabbing /boring Burning /stabbing/sharp
Severity of pain  Excruciating  Excruciating Severe to excruciating
Site of pain  Orbit, temple Orbit, temple Periorbital
Attack frequency  1-8 /day 1-20/day 3-200/day
Duration 15min-3 hours 2-30 min 5-240seconds
Migraneous feature  Yes  Yes  Yes
Alcohol trigger  Yes No No
Cutaneous trigger No No Yes
Response to indomethacin No Yes No
Abortive treatment

100% oxygen

No effective treatment

Prophylaxis

Chronic cluster

  • Lithium

  • Verapamil

  • Topiramate
  • Gabapentin
  • Indomethacin is effective in paroxysmal hemicrania,hemicrania continuum, and primary sexual/ exercise headache
  • Cutaneous trigger is also seen in trigeminal neuralgia, however, trigeminal neuralgia is a separate entity and not a part of trigeminal autonomic cephalalgia 

Related Pearl: Simplified diagnostic criteria for migraine

Repeated attacks of headache lasting 4-72 h in patients with a normal physical examination with no other reasonable cause for the headache, and

At least 2 of the following features:

  • Unilateral pain
  • Throbbing pain
  • Aggravation by movement
  • Moderate or severe intensity

Plus at least 1 of the following features:

  • Nausea/vomiting
  • Photophobia and phonophobia

questions.text:
In a patient diagnosed with breast carcinoma, the surgeon decides to do Auchincloss modification of modified radical mastectomy. Which of the following steps are included in this surgery?
  1. Removal of breast
  2. Removal of Pectoralis major
  3. Removal of level 1,2, and 3 axillary lymph nodes
  4. Retraction of Pectoralis minor
  5. Incision of Pectoralis minor
questions.solution:
The steps included in Auchincloss modification of modified radical mastectomy are removal of the breast, removal of level 1,2, and 3 axillary lymph nodes, and retraction of Pectoralis minor. 

Radical mastectomy involves the removal of the pectoralis major along with the pectoralis minor. However, the removal of both these muscles led to a lot of functional impairment with no improved cancer outcome.

Structures removed in modified radical mastectomy:

  1. Whole breast tissue
  2. The skin over the breast tissue
  3. Nipple-areola complex
  4. Pectoral fascia
  5. Levels I, II, ± III axillary lymph nodes

The pectoralis minor muscle is either cut (Patey's, Scanlon's modification) or retracted (Auchincloss). The incision used is an elliptical Stewart incision. 

Related Pearl: Important surgeries for breast cancer

  • Tylectomy: Excision of lump
  • Breast conservation surgery (BCS)/WLE (wide local excision): Tumour removal with a 3D clearance of a 1 mm margin of normal tissue
  • Simple mastectomy: Palpable extent of breast + Nipple–areola complex + overlying skin.
  • Extended simple mastectomy: Simple mastectomy + removal of level I axillary lymph nodes.
  • Skin-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope preservation and nipple-areola complex removal
  • Skin+ nipple/areola-sparing mastectomy: Mastectomy with breast envelope and nipple-areola complex preservation
  • Total mastectomy: All breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin.
  • Level I oncoplasty (volume displacement surgery): Tumour excision with wide margins followed by defect repair via dual-plane mobilisation of the breast parenchyma to maintain shape and symmetry
  • Level II oncoplasty (volume replacement surgery): Skin excision and glandular mobilisation involving >20% resection of breast volume
  • Modified radical mastectomy:  Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + axillary lymph nodes (levels I + II ± III) dissection
    • Patey’s: Pectoralis minor is removed
    • Scanlon’s: Pectoralis minor incised
    • Auchincloss: Pectoralis minor only retracted
  • Halsted’s radical mastectomy: Entire breast tissue + Nipple–areola complex + skin + Levels I + II+ III Axillary lymph nodes + Pectoralis major and minor
  • Extended radical (Urban) - Halsted’s + internal mammary lymph nodes dissection
  • Extended radical (Dahl-Iverson) mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary and supraclavicular lymph nodes dissection
  • Super radical mastectomy: Halsted’s + internal mammary, supraclavicular and mediastinal lymph nodes dissection.

*Dual-plane mobilisation of breast parenchyma: Mobilisation of the dermoglandular plane and plane between breast parenchyma and pectoralis muscle.

questions.text: A person working in the smelting industry noticed the following changes in the nails. This finding can be seen in chronic poisoning with which of the following?
questions.solution:
The image shows transverse white lines of 1 to 2mm in breadth across the nail which is called Aldrich-Mees lines and is usually seen in chronic arsenic and thallium poisoning.

Chronic Arsenic Poisoning :

  • Source: Occurs in persons engaged in smelting or refining ore or long-term exposure to arsenic compounds

Manifestations of chronic arsenic poisoning: 

System involved Symptoms
Skin Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, raindrop hyperpigmentation 
Nails Aldrich Mees Line: Transverse white lines in the fingernails 
Neurologic Polyneuritis, anesthesias, paraesthesia,
encephalopathy. 
GI tract Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss
Liver Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis
Haematologic Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis
Cardiovascular Blackfoot disease due to platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries

Diagnosis: Urinary level of > 100 mg/ 24 hours suggestive of arsenic toxicity. Blood levels and hair levels are not reliable.

Laboratory tests to detect arsenic poisoning are:

  • Marsh’s test
  • Reinsch test
  • Atomic absorption spectroscopy

Management:

  • Hemodialysis is the treatment of choice for massive arsenic poisoning.
  • Chelation with BAL(British Anti Lewisite). Penicillamine or DMSA can be used instead of BAL.
  • Gastric lavage with warm water and milk

Other options:

  • Lead poisoning is characterized by a blue line on the gums called the Burtonian line. It can also be seen in mercury poisoning.
  • Mercury poisoning is characterized by mercurial tremors or Hatters shake.

Related Pearl: Arsenic poisoning

Summary of Arsenic poisoning

Source of exposure: Arsenic-containing pesticides, natural sources - drinking water and soil

Route of absorption: GI tract

Mechanism of action: binds to sulfhydryl groups and inhibits pyruvate dehydrogenase, gluconeogenesis, glutathione metabolism

Characteristic clinical findings are as follows: Mnemonic-ARSENIC

A- Aldrich mees lines

R- raindrop pigmentation, rash, red velvety mucosa

S- subendocardial haemorrhage

E- Excessive pigmentation- Blackfoot disease

N- Neuritis

I- Iron oxide + BAL –treatment

C- Cholera like illness

Diagnosis: 24-hour urine arsenic

Treatment: BAL; succimer(DMSA)

Clinicopathological findings in acute and chronic arsenic poisoning:

System

Acute

Chronic

Skin

Delayed hair loss (alopecia)

Melanosis, Bowen’s disease facial edema, hyperkeratosis, cutaneous cancer, hyperpigmentation.

Nails

Mees’s lines in 2-3 weeks post ingestion.

Mees' lines

Neurologic

Hyperpyrexia, convulsions, tremors, coma

Encephalopathy, polyneuropathy, tremors, axonal degeneration

GI tract

Abdominal pain, dysphagia, vomiting, bloody or rice water diarrhea, mucosal erosions.

Nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, anorexia, weight loss

Liver

Fatty infiltration

Hepatomegaly, jaundice, cirrhosis

Kidney

Tubular and glomerular changes – oliguria and uremia

Nephritic finding

Haemetologic

thrombocytopenia, impaired folate metabolism

Bone marrow hypoplasia, anemia, leukopenia, basophilic stippling, and karyorrhexis.

Cardiovascular
  • S-T wave abnormalities,
  • prolonged QT interval
  • ventricular fibrillation
  • atypical ventricular tachycardia 

There is platelet activation and hypercoagulability of blood in peripheral arteries leading to blackfoot disease

Reproductive system

Maternal ingestion of inorganic

Arsenic crosses the placental barrier and infant death shortly after birth.

-Nil-

questions.text: A young man presents with a painless mass in the submandibular region. On performing drainage, the discharge contained yellow granules and was foul-smelling. Microscopy of the sample showed gram-positive filamentous rods. The colonies on agar had a molar tooth appearance. Which of the following is the drug of choice to treat his condition?
questions.solution:
This is a typical case of cervicofacial actinomycosis. The patient presents with a painless nodule that indurates with purulent discharge that contains sulfur granules. Sulfur granules are composed of a matrix of bacteria, calcium phosphate, and host tissue. Penicillin G is the drug of choice.

Actinomycosis is an indolent, slowly progressive suppurative and granulomatous infection that produces pyogenic lesions with interconnecting sinus tracts that contain sulfur granules. It is caused by anaerobic or microaerophilic bacteria, primarily of the genus Actinomyces.

It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- (most common site) fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas. (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.
  • Pelvic actinomycosis- due to the colonization of intrauterine contraceptive devices.
  • Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

 

Diagnosis:

  • Gram staining of sulfur granules shows a dense network of thin gram-positive filaments, surrounded by club-shaped structures. (sunray appearance)
  • Culture shows a molar tooth appearance of the colonies.

The image below shows the molar tooth appearance of the Actinomyces colonies.

Treatment involves surgical drainage or excision along with high doses of intravenous penicillin G over two to six weeks, followed by oral penicillin V.

questions.text: Identify the plots with the maximum interquartile range and the least median respectively.
questions.solution:
The graph shown is a boxplot where Plot 1 has the maximum interquartile range and Plot 2 has the least median.

A boxplot is a method for graphically depicting groups of numerical data through their quartiles. Box plots may also have lines extending vertically from the boxes (whiskers), indicating variability outside the upper and lower quartiles, hence the terms box-and-whisker plot. 

It shows the five-number summary of a set of data as shown below.

In the box plot, a simple box extends from the 25th percentile (lower limit of the box) to the 75th percentile (upper limit of the box) and represents the interquartile range. The interquartile range is maximum in Plot 1 and least in Plot 4. The line through the box indicates the median value (50th percentile). The median is highest in Plot 3 and least in Plot 2.

Interpreting the box plot:

  • When the median is in the middle of the box and the whiskers are about the same on both sides of the box, i.e when each quartile is of the same length, then the distribution is symmetric or normal (as shown in box plot-1)
  • When the median is closer to the bottom of the box, and if the whisker is shorter on the lower end of the box, then the distribution is positively skewed (skewed right, as shown in box plot-2)
  • When the median is closer to the top of the box, and if the whisker is shorter on the upper end of the box, then the distribution is negatively skewed (skewed left, as shown in box plot-3)
  • Small circles or unfilled dots are drawn on the chart to indicate where suspected outliers lie. Filled circles are used for known outliers (as shown in box plot-4)

Related Pearl: Box and Whisker Plot

  • A box and whisker plot is used to show variation in a set of data.
  • They can summarize data from various sources and display it in a single graph.
  • A box and whisker plot is usually based on median, quartiles and percentiles.
  • It is also called a box plot.
  • In the box plot as shown in the image, a simple box is divided into two by the median value. Above and below it are the whiskers. The top and bottom ends of the whiskers are the highest and lowest value of that group. 
  • A box plot can help in identifying outliers and the interquartile range (IQR), as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A newborn baby presented to the pediatrician with respiratory distress.  On examination, the infant has a scaphoid abdomen and breath sounds are decreased on both sides. The baby was born via normal vaginal delivery at term and antenatal visits were not done regularly. An X-ray of the infant is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the management of this condition?

choices.text: For small defects a porous polytetrafluoroethylene patch can be used
Extra corporeal membranous oxygenation is contraindicated
Conventional mechanical ventilation is used for managing respiratory failure
Bag and mask ventilation should be used in the initial management

questions.solution:
The above X-ray chest shows intra-thoracic bowel shadows along with a mediastinal shift suggestive of congenital diaphragmatic hernia and conventional mechanical ventilation is the main strategy used to support respiratory failure in infants with CDH.

If the defect is posterolateral it is called Bochdalek hernia and if it's anteromedial it is called Morgagni hernia.  Bochdalek hernia is the most common variant.

Clinical features :

  • Respiratory distress is a cardinal sign in infants with a congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH).
  • Early respiratory distress, within 6 hr after birth, is thought to be a poor prognostic sign.
  • Children with CDH may also have a scaphoid abdomen and increased chest wall diameter.
  • Bowel sounds may also be heard in the chest, with a bilateral decrease in breath sounds.
  • The point of maximal cardiac impulse may be displaced away from the side of a hernia if a mediastinal shift has occurred.
  • Retroperitoneal fat, left kidney, spleen or only the omentum commonly herniates through the defect. If the defect is large, most abdominal contents including the stomach may herniate.

Diagnosis:

  • Chest radiography and passage of a nasal gastric tube confirm the diagnosis.
  • CDH can be diagnosed on prenatal ultrasonography (between 16 and 24 weeks of gestation)
  • High-speed fetal magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) can further define the lesion.

Differential diagnosis:

  • Diaphragmatic eventration
  • Cystic adenomatoid malformation
  • Bronchogenic cyst
  • Cystic teratoma

Treatment:

Variable period of time (24-72 hours) to allow for stabilization before surgical repair. Immediate respiratory support should be provided, including rapid endotracheal intubation and sedation. 

Bag and Mask Ventilation is contraindicated in newborns with congenital diaphragmatic hernia because it causes distension of the stomach which in turn may limit the expansion of the already hypoplastic lung.

During surgery, the viscera are reduced into the abdominal cavity, and the posterolateral defect in the diaphragm is closed using interrupted, nonabsorbable sutures.

In most cases (80%-90%), a hernia sac is not present. If identified, it is excised at the time of repair.

Conventional mechanical ventilation, high-frequency oscillatory ventilation (HFOV), and extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) are the 3 main strategies to support respiratory failure in the newborn with CDH.

Good relative indicators of stability are as follows:

  • Requirement for conventional ventilation only
  • Low peak inspiratory pressure
  • Fi-O2 <50

If the defect is too large, a porous polytetrafluoroethylene (Gore-Tex) patch is used.

questions.text: The organ least likely to be involved in acute graft-versus-host disease reaction is ________
questions.solution:
Graft-versus-host disease (GVHD) affects the liver, skin and gut and is least likely to affect the adrenal glands amongst the given options.

GVHD occurs when immunologically competent cells or their precursors are transplanted into immunologically compromised recipients. The transferred cells recognize the alloantigens in the host and attack host tissues. It is seen most commonly during hematopoietic stem cell transplantation but may also occur following the transplantation of solid organs. 

GVHD may be of two types: acute and chronic.

Acute GVHD occurs within days to weeks after allogeneic hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. It mainly involves the immune system and the epithelia of the skin, liver, and intestines. But the affected tissues are not heavily infiltrated by lymphocytes. It may present as:

  • Generalized rash over the skin that may lead to desquamation
  • Destruction of small bile ducts in the liver giving rise to jaundice
  • Mucosal ulceration of the gut resulting in bloody diarrhea

Chronic GVHD may follow acute GVHD or may occur insidiously. Some patients even develop autoimmunity, owing to the grafted CD4+ helper T cells reacting with host B cells and stimulating them, which may result in autoantibody production. It may present as:

  • Destruction of skin appendages and fibrosis of the dermis resembling systemic sclerosis
  • Chronic liver disease manifested by cholestatic jaundice
  • Damage to the gastrointestinal tract may cause esophageal strictures
  • Involution of the thymus and depletion of lymphocytes in the lymph nodes with recurrent bouts of life-threatening infections.

Depletion of donor T cells by irradiation before transfusion can eliminate the occurrence of GVHD. But irradiation also has its adverse effects such as tumor recurrence in leukemic patients, increased incidence of graft failures, and EBV-related B-cell lymphoma.

Related Pearl: Transplant Rejection and Hypersensitivity

Type of Rejection  Type of Hypersensitivity

Host vs Graft
Hyperacute Type 2
Acute Type 2 and 4
Chronic Type 2 and 4
Graft vs Host
Graft vs host reaction Type 4

 

The image given below explains the pathophysiology of hyperacute graft rejection (type II hypersensitivity). 

The image below shows the mechanism of type IV hypersensitivity in graft rejection.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true regarding pheochromocytoma?
  1. Associated with sustained hypertension
  2. Associated with paroxysmal hypertension
  3. Associated with orthostatic hypotension
  4. Most are bilateral
  5. DOPA-PET scan can be done for localization
questions.solution:
Pheochromocytoma can present with both paroxysmal and sustained hypertension, and DOPA-PET can be used for the localization of the tumor.

Pheochromocytomas and paragangliomas are catecholamine-producing tumors that are derived from the autonomic nervous system. According to WHO terminology, the term pheochromocytoma is restricted to adrenal tumors, while the term paraganglioma is used for all the other sites.

The patients present with the classic triad of headache, sweating, and palpitations. The dominant finding seen in the patients is hypertension. Both episodic/paroxysmal and sustained hypertension can be seen in the patients. During one of these episodes, there can be arrhythmias and heart failure. Pheochromocytoma is a state of contraction of the intravascular volume. This is because increased catecholamines cause systemic vasoconstriction. Further, there is increased activity of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system, causing efferent arteriolar vasoconstriction and increased filtration in the kidneys. Intravascular volume contraction causes orthostatic hypotension. 

Biochemical tests used to diagnose pheochromocytoma include 24-hour urinary catecholamines and metanephrines, and plasma catecholamines and metanephrines. T2 weighted MRI with gadolinium contrast is the investigation of choice for localization of the tumor. This is better than contrast-enhanced CT for detecting extra-adrenal tumors. Localization can also be done using MIBG and DOPA-PET scan. These agents are also useful for assessing metastatic disease.

The optimal treatment is by resection of the tumor, either by partial or complete adrenelectomy. Normal adrenal cortex preservation is important to prevent the development of Addison's disease when the tumor is present bilaterally. The pre-operative preparation consists of giving oral phenoxybenzamine for α blockade first. Oral prazosin or IV phentolamine can be given to the patient while adequate α blockade with phenoxybenzamine is awaited. α blockade is achieved first in patients with pheochromocytoma because β blockade alone will cause severe vasoconstriction because of the elevated catecholamine levels. Once α blockade is achieved, β blockers are then added.

Related Pearl: Clinical features of Pheochromocytoma (By frequency of occurrence)

  • Classical triad of symptoms:
    • Headaches – most common symptom
    • Profuse sweating
    • Palpitations and tachycardia
  • Hypertension (sustained or intermittent) – most common sign
  • Anxiety, panic attacks
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Pallor - due to alpha-1 mediated vasoconstriction
  • Polyuria and polydipsia 
  • Orthostatic hypotension
  • Dilated cardiomyopathy
  • Erythrocytosis, high hematocrit (hemoconcentration)
  • Constipation
  • Abdominal pain
  • Weakness
  • Weight loss
  • Nausea

questions.text: The plasma half-life of beta hCG is _____
questions.solution:
The plasma half-life of beta hCG is 36 hours.

Beta hCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) has a biological activity similar to that of luteinizing hormone (LH). It is a glycoprotein produced by syncytiotrophoblasts. It is made up of α and β subunits. Though the α subunit of hCG is similar to the α subunits of LH, FSH, and TSH. Each of the β-subunits has distinct amino acid sequence. Placental GnRH is responsible for the regulation of hCG formation.

The functions are to maintain the corpus luteum function, regulate fetal testis testosterone secretion and stimulate the maternal thyroid. Its level peaks at gestational week 9 and then decline gradually but is present in lower concentration till the end of pregnancy.
 

Different clinical situations are associated with varying levels of maternal plasma hCG. Examples of circumstances with significantly higher hCG levels include multifetal pregnancy, erythroblastosis fetalis linked to fetal hemolytic anemia, and gestational trophoblastic disease. In cases of Down syndrome, women carrying an affected fetus may also exhibit relatively elevated hCG levels, which have been incorporated into screening strategies. Conversely, women with early pregnancies and ectopic pregnancies typically display comparatively lower hCG plasma levels.

questions.text:
A researcher is studying the incidence of asthma in children who are exposed to second-hand smoke and those who are not (as given in the table below). Which of the following formulas helps determine the association between exposure to second-hand smoke and asthma?
  Asthma
Exposure to second-hand smoke   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d
questions.solution:
Formula 3 representing relative risk helps determine the association between exposure to second-hand smoke and asthma.

In this study, the sample population is classified on the basis of exposure and non-exposure to second-hand smoke and it follows the individuals until the development of the disease. This makes it a cohort study. The best parameter to find the association in this cohort study is relative risk. Relative risk is the ratio of the incidence of disease (or death) among exposed and the incidence among non-exposed. It is a direct measure of the strength of the association between suspected cause and effect in a cohort study but does not imply causation.

  Asthma
Exposure to second-hand smoke   Yes No
Yes a b
No c d

From the given table:

The incidence of disease among exposed is a/(a+b)
The incidence of disease among non-exposed is c/(c+d)

Relative risk (RR) = a/(a+b) 
                                  c/(c+d) 

Other options:

Formula 1 represents the Odds ratio. The odds ratio (OR) or cross-product ratio is a measure of the strength of association between a risk factor and outcome in case-control studies (not applicable to the study in question which is a cohort study). It is a ratio of two sets of odds: the odds of the event occurring in an exposed group versus the odds of the event occurring in a non-exposed group. It helps identify how likely an exposure can lead to a specific event. 

Odds ratio (OR) = a/b
                             c/d

Formula 2 represents the attributable risk. Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates of disease (or death) between an exposed group and the non-exposed group. It indicates the extent to which the disease under study can be attributed to the exposure and how much the disease can be eliminated by controlling this exposure. In this case, attributable risk will express the incidence of asthma that is attributable to exposure to second-hand smoke.

Attributable risk (AR) =   a   -   c  
                                           a+b   c+d

It is often expressed as a percentage as shown below.

Formula 4 represents the absolute risk reduction (ARR). ARR is the difference in the absolute risk rates between the placebo or control group and the drug or intervention group. It indicates the proportion of patients who are spared the adverse outcome as a result of having received the experimental therapy rather than the control therapy.

Absolute risk reduction (ARR) =    c     -     a   
                                                           (c+d)    (a+b)

This absolute risk is usually multiplied by 100 and expressed in percentage.
ARR is not applicable to this study as it deals with exposure to a risk factor and not interventions.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

Related Pearl: Odds Ratio

  • Odds ratio is a measure of the strength of association between risk factor and outcome in case control studies.
  • Odds ratio can be arrived at from case control studies.
  • It is also known as cross product ratio.
  • A representation of the odds ratio (OR) is given in the picture below:

Calculation of odds ratio (OR) = (a/b)/(c/d) = ad/bc where,

  • OR < 1 indicates possible protection (negative association) as the frequency of exposure is lower among cases than controls.
  • OR = 1 indicates no association of risk with exposure, or that the event is equally likely in both groups.
  • OR > 1 indicates increased risk (positive association) as the frequency of exposure is greater among cases than controls.

questions.text: A 48-year-old male who is a known diabetic for 10 years has incurred community-acquired pneumonia. The acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) had set in after 2 weeks of hospitalization. Which of the following cells play a significant role in tissue injury caused by this inflammatory response?
questions.solution:
In acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), tissue injury is caused mainly by neutrophils.

ARDS is a clinical syndrome manifested as a result of severe lung injury and characterized by inflammation, which causes increased pulmonary vascular permeability and edema. Damage to the endothelial and alveolar epithelial cells, with inflammation, is the key initiating event and the basis of lung damage.

In ARDS, neutrophils adhere to the activated endothelium and migrate into the interstitium and the alveoli, where they degranulate and release inflammatory mediators, including proteases, reactive oxygen species, and cytokines.

questions.text: A 70-year-old male patient presents with regurgitation of food and exacerbated nocturnal cough for a week. He also notices gurgling sounds while swallowing. On barium fluoroscopic examination, the given finding is seen. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis​?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and barium swallow showing a fraction of the ingested barium sulfate being trapped in a pharyngeal pouch in the cervical esophagus suggests a diagnosis of Zenker's diverticulum. 

Zenker diverticulum, otherwise known as cricopharyngeal achalasia/pharyngeal pouch, is a pulsion-pseudodiverticulum (false diverticula occurring due to motor disorder causing increased intraluminal pressure). It results from the herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle (dehiscence of Killian).

Killian's triangle is an area of muscular weakness between the transverse fibers of the cricopharyngeus and the oblique fibers of the thyropharyngeus (shown below).

 

It is usually seen in the seventh decade of life and is thought to occur due to loss of muscle tone and elasticity causing incomplete relaxation. The impaired relaxation and spasms of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing results in increased pressure within the distal pharynx and the development of Zenker's diverticulum.

Patients complain of dysphagia, halitosis, recurrent regurgitation, and respiratory infections. The most serious complications are aspiration pneumonia and lung abscess.

Diagnosis is by barium swallow studies and video laryngoscopy. The gold standard of treatment is either endoscopic or open surgery. The transoral endoscopic approach is known as the Dohlman procedure in which the common wall between the diverticulum and the cervical esophagus is ablated using laser, electrocautery, or stapler devices. It can be used for diverticula between 2 and 5 cm in size. Lesions less than 2 cm are managed with myotomy. A sac more than 5 cm is usually excised.

Other options:

Option A: Epiphrenic diverticula is a pulsion pseudodiverticula that arises from the terminal third of the thoracic esophagus (next to the diaphragm). They are often associated with diffuse spasm, achalasia, and other esophageal motor abnormalities. 

Option B: Achalasia is a type of esophageal motility disorder and a premalignant condition that occurs due to hypertension of the lower esophageal sphincter and thereby failure to relax. The classic triad of presentation is dysphagia, regurgitation, and weight loss. Esophagogram shows the classic bird beak appearance (dilated esophagus with distal narrowing). 

Option D: Lateral pharyngeal diverticulum, otherwise known as a pharyngocele, is the herniation of the lateral pharyngeal wall in the piriform recess or vallecula. Patients are often asymptomatic or may complain of dysphagia, neck mass, cervical pain, etc. 

Related Pearl: Zenker’s Diverticulum

Zenker's diverticulum occurs due to herniation of mucosa and submucosa through the Killian's triangle, which is a weak area between two parts of the inferior constrictor - (thyropharyngeus and cricopharyngeus) in the posterior pharyngeal wall. It is usually seen in elderly patients (>60 years).

Characteristics of Zenker's diverticulum:

  • Hypopharyngeal
  • False diverticula - doesn't have a muscle coat
  • Acquired 
  • Pulsion diverticulum 

Pathophysiology: Impaired relaxation and spasm of the cricopharyngeus muscle after swallowing can result in increased pressure within the distal pharynx, and cause the diverticulum.Clinical features:

  • Dysphagia
  • Regurgitation
  • Halitosis
  • Aspiration
  • Gurgling sound during swallowing

The investigation of choice is barium swallow (lateral X-ray).

It is treated with:

  • Cricopharyngeal myotomy
  • Surgical diverticulectomy
  • Marsupialization
  • Dohlman’s procedure

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the role of Hepcidin in Iron metabolism?

choices.text: Hepcidin activity is low in secondary hemochromatosis
Hepcidin binds to ferritin and inhibits iron transfer
Hepcidin production is increased in chronic diseases
Hepcidin activity is low in  primary  hemochromatosis

questions.solution:
Hepcidin inhibits iron transfer from the enterocytes into the plasma by binding to ferroportin (not ferritin).

Hepcidin is released by the liver in response to increases in intrahepatic iron levels. It inhibits iron transfer by binding to ferroportin and causing it to be endocytosed and degraded. As a result, iron becomes trapped within the duodenal cells in the form of mucosal ferritin and is lost in feces when these cells are sloughed off.

Transcription of hepcidin is increased by the following factors:

  • Inflammatory cytokines
  • Iron

Transcription of hepcidin is decreased by the following factors:

  • Iron deficiency
  • Hypoxia
  • Ineffective erythropoiesis
  • primary and secondary hemochromatosis

Mutation in hepcidin causes Hereditary hemochromatosis. Secondary hemochromatosis can also occur due to the suppression of hepatic hepcidin production in diseases associated with ineffective erythropoiesis, such as β-thalassemia major and myelodysplastic syndrome.

questions.text: A young patient presented with hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis. Which of the following is the likely underlying abnormality?
questions.solution:
Fanconi syndrome presents with type 2 renal tubular acidosis (RTA) and causes hypokalemia and metabolic acidosis.

Type 2 RTA occurs because of a defect in the proximal tubule HCO3- reabsorption. There is increased excretion of HCO3-, leading to metabolic acidosis. There is increased delivery of the tubular fluid to the distal tubule, leading to increased Na+ reabsorption and K+ secretion in the distal tubule under the effect of aldosterone. Note that the effect of HCO3- loss overpowers the H+ loss in the distal tubule due to aldosterone, and thus the net result is metabolic acidosis. The urine pH is mostly <5.5 because of the depletion of the HCO3- stores in the body, but it can be >5.5 early in the disease course due to excess filtered HCO3-. The causes of type 2 RTA include Fanconi syndrome, multiple myeloma, and Wilson's disease.

Other options:

Option B: Gitelman syndrome causes increased fluid delivery to the distal tubule, leading to more Na+ absorption, and increased H+ and K+ secretion under the influence of aldosterone. Thus, it causes metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia.

Option C: Bartter syndrome also causes increased Na+ absorption, and increased H+ and K+ secretion under the influence of aldosterone, thus, causing metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia.

 Option D:  Liddle syndrome occurs due to a gain of function mutation in the ENaC channels in the distal tubule. It also causes metabolic alkalosis and hypokalemia by similar mechanisms.

questions.text: Given below is the ECG of a patient who presented to the emergency room with sudden onset palpitations and breathlessness. Which of the following drugs will be useful in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given ECG, the presence of narrow-complex regular tachycardia and P-waves occurring after QRS complexes, known as retro P waves or pseudo-r' waves, (especially prominent in lead V1) point to a diagnosis of paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). Out of the given drugs, Verapamil can be used in the treatment of PSVT.

PSVT is an arrhythmia characterized by sudden onset and offset with rapid ventricular response. It includes atrioventricular nodal reentry tachycardia, junctional tachycardia, and AV reentry tachycardia. Initial management of PSVT is by vagal maneuvers such as carotid massage. If this method is ineffective, intravenous adenosine is used which will terminate the majority of PSVT episodes by blocking the conduction at AV node. Beta-blockers and non-DHP calcium channel blockers like Verapamil and Diltiazem are also able to block AV nodal conduction and can therefore be used in patients with PSVT.

Verapamil is a class IV anti-arrhythmic agent. It is a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It acts by slowing down the SA node automaticity and AV nodal conduction velocity. This decreases the conduction velocity and prolongs the refractory period, leading to the effective termination of the re-entrant current. Additionally, they also decrease cardiac contractility and reduce blood pressure. Diltiazem acts in a similar manner. Side effects of Verapamil include hypotension, bradycardia, constipation, and rarely, worsening of heart failure.

Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers like Nifedipine, Amlodipine, and Cilnidipine do not have any antiarrhythmic properties.

Other options:

Option A: Cilnidipine blocks both N and L-type calcium channels. It is a dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker. It blocks the L-type calcium channels in blood vessels and inhibits the contraction of blood vessels and blocks the N-type calcium channels located at the sympathetic nerve endings, inhibiting the release of norepinephrine. It is used in hypertension, especially in patients with diabetes who present with albuminuria and chronic kidney disease as it has end-organ protective properties.

Option B: Fenoldopam injection is a dopaminergic agonist. It is indicated in adult patients for short-term management of severe hypertension when rapid and reversible reduction of blood pressure is clinically indicated, including for hypertensive emergencies. 

Option D: Nifedipine is a dihydropyridine that acts by blocking L-type calcium channels, having a rapid onset and short duration of action. It results in an abrupt decrease in blood pressure resulting in reflex tachycardia. Increased heart rate increases the O2 demand and might precipitate angina.
