questions.text:
A 21-year-old female patient with psoriasis is undergoing the therapeutic modality shown in the image below. Which of the following statements is incorrect about this therapy?

Ultraviolet A - UVA

Ultraviolet B - UVB

Psoralen with Ultraviolet A - PUVA

choices.text: The UVB  spectrum is between 280 and 320 nm
The UVA  spectrum is between 320 and 400 nm
PUVA has a lesser skin cancer risk than UVB
Can be used to treat cutaneous T-cell lymphoma

questions.solution:
The given image shows phototherapy being used as a treatment modality. UVB is generally preferred over PUVA as it has a lesser skin cancer risk than PUVA. It is also easier to administer and its exposure time is shorter. 

Phototherapy is a form of treatment where nonionizing radiations, commonly ultraviolet radiations are used in a controlled manner over the skin. 

Ultraviolet radiation is divided into three groups based on its wavelength- UVA (320-400nm), UVB (280-320nm), and UVC (<280nm).

UVB- Ultraviolet B rays are the rays that have wavelengths between 280 and 320 nm. If all these wavelengths are used it is called a full spectrum. If only 311–313 nm is used, then it is called narrow-band UVB.  It has anti‐inflammatory, immunosuppressive, and cytotoxic properties.

UVA is used in combination with oral or topical psoralen photosensitizer. This combination treatment is termed as PUVA (psoralen with UVA). This leads to crosslinking of DNA with psoralen leading to inhibition of replication, depletion of Langerhans cells, immunosuppression, and restoration of the Th17/regulatory T cell imbalance. 

Phototherapy is used to treat psoriasis, atopic eczema, cutaneous T cell lymphoma, vitiligo, and polymorphic light eruption. 

Phototherapy is contraindicated in dysplastic nevus syndrome, systemic lupus erythematosus, dermatomyositis, genetic cancer syndrome, bloom syndrome, and medically unfit and uncompliant patients.

questions.text:
A lumbar puncture should be performed for:
  1. A child with signs of meningitis 
  2. Family history of complex febrile seizure 
  3. Family history of simple febrile seizure 
  4. All infants less than 6 months of age presenting with febrile seizure 
  5. A child who has not been pretreated with antibiotics
questions.solution:
Indications for lumbar puncture in a child presenting with a febrile seizure are as follows:

  • First episode of seizures with fever, for all infants <6 months of age (to exclude meningitis)(Statement 4)
  • Clinical signs or symptoms of meningitis.(Statement 1)
  • It is optional in a child 6-12 months of age for whom the immunization status is unknown.
  • In children who have been pre-treated with antibiotics (statement 5)

Febrile seizures occur in children of the age of 6-60 months with a high-grade fever of 38°C (100.4 F) or higher without underlying CNS infections, metabolic abnormality, or prior afebrile seizures.

Major risk factors for the recurrence of febrile seizures are age less than 1 year, duration of fever less than 24 hours, and fever range: 38-39°C (100.4-102.2°F). Minor risk factors include a family history of epilepsy, male gender, daycare, complex febrile seizure, family history of febrile seizures, and lower serum sodium at the time of presentation.

Electroencephalogram and neuroimaging are advised for children with suspected epilepsy or neurological abnormalities.

Acute treatment of febrile seizures includes lorazepam and midazolam for seizures lasting more than 5 minutes. Rectal diazepam is prescribed to use at home as rescue medication if febrile seizures last more than 5 minutes. The use of antipyretics can decrease the discomfort of the child but does not reduce the risk of having a recurrent febrile seizure.

Related Pearl: Skin rashes: 1st to 6th diseases

2nd disease

Scarlet fever

3rd disease

4th disease

Duke’s disease

5th disease

Erythema infectiosum

6th disease

questions.text: The phase of skin graft uptake in which the graft is most at risk for failure is:
questions.solution:
The phase of skin graft uptake during which the graft is most at risk for failure is the inosculation phase.

It is the phase in which the cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses. Graft failure during inosculation phase is due to mechanical shear, the formation of seroma or hematoma, or bacterial contamination. 

Split skin graft survives the transplantation surgery by the following process:

  • The graft survives the first 48 hours because of the imbibition of plasma from the wound bed.
  • After 48 hours, fine anastomotic connections are made, which leads to the inosculation of blood.
  • Neovascularization is the process by which new blood vessels formed will directly invade the graft and restore the pink color of the skin.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text: Rota virus is a __________
questions.solution:
Rotavirus is a nonenveloped, double-stranded (ds) RNA virus.

Rotaviruses appear as cartwheel-shaped structures with short spokes radiating from them. It has 11 segments of double-stranded RNA. They exhibit genetic reassortment due to the presence of this segmented RNA.

Rotavirus is the most common identifiable viral cause of diarrhea in children below the age of 5 years and is most frequent between 6-24 months of age. The incubation period is 1-3 days. Most cases are asymptomatic or with mild symptoms like watery diarrhea, vomiting, low-grade fever, and temporary lactose intolerance. Diagnosis can be made by rapid antigen detection of rotavirus in stool specimens.

Rotavirus vaccine is associated with a potential risk of intussusception, especially when the first dose of these vaccines is given to infants aged >12 weeks. Because of this risk, the rotavirus vaccine is not a part of catch-up immunization programs.

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with a thin white vaginal discharge. Which of the following options does not belong to Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis?

choices.text: Presence of epithelial cells with bacteria adhered around them.
White milky non viscous discharge adherent to vaginal wall.
Fishy odour when mixed with 10% KOH

questions.solution:
The pH of discharge more than 4.5 is included in Amsel's criteria for diagnosing bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis occurs due to an alteration in the normal vaginal flora, specifically the lactobacilli. Lactobacilli are responsible for maintaining vaginal pH and reducing the growth of other pathogenic bacteria. In this condition, the number of lactobacilli is reduced, resulting in an increase in the number of pathogenic organisms like Gardnerella vaginalis, Haemophilus vaginalis, Mobiluncus, and Mycoplasma hominins.

It is diagnosed using Amsel's criteria:

  • White milky non-viscous discharge adherent to the vaginal wall.
  • Vaginal pH > 4.5
  • Amine-like odor on adding KOH - Potassium hydroxide (whiff test positive)
  • Presence of clue cells (>20% of cells) which are epithelial cells with bacteria adhered around them.

Metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or clindamycin cream (2%) applied intravaginally daily at bedtime for 7 days can be used to treat bacterial vaginosis.

The images given below show clue cells:

questions.text: An autopsy of a 38-year-old male patient who died of cardiac failure showed the following histopathological image of the endocardium. Which of the following best describes the form of vegetation found in this condition?

choices.text: Small, warty vegetations along the line of closure of the valve leaflets
Large, irregular masses on valve cusps and chordae
Small, bland vegetations on the line of closure
Small to medium sized vegetations on either sides of the valve

questions.solution:
The clinical vignette with histopathology showing Anitschkow cells and Aschoff bodies are pathognomic of the rheumatic fever (RF) phase of rheumatic heart disease (RHD). It is associated with small, warty vegetations along the lines of closure of the valve leaflets.

RF is an acute, immunologically mediated, multisystem inflammatory disease classically occurring a few weeks after group A streptococcal pharyngitis. RHD is principally characterized by deforming fibrotic valvular disease, particularly the mitral valve.

Important pathological findings in rheumatic fever are:

  • Inflammation in the three layers of the heart can result in endocarditis, myocarditis, pericarditis, or pancarditis.
  • Inflammation of the endocardium and the left side valves can lead to fibrinoid necrosis. Over these areas of necrosis, small vegetations can be seen along the lines of closure, called verrucae.
  • In the subendocardium, irregular thickenings called MacCallum plaques can be present.
  • Aschoff bodies are collections of lymphocytes (primarily T cells), scattered plasma cells, and plump-activated macrophages (called Anitschkow cells). The Anitschkow cells have abundant cytoplasm and nuclei with chromatin that is centrally condensed into a slender, wavy ribbon. Hence they are also called caterpillar cells.
  • Mitral valve in chronic RHD shows leaflet thickening, commissural fusion and shortening, and thickening and fusion of the tendinous cords.This leads to narrowing of the mitral orifice, giving it a fish mouth appearance.

Image: Histology of a rheumatic fever patient showing Aschoff bodies and Anitschkow cells.

questions.text: In which of the following structures, is the click-or-pop sensation encountered during spinal anesthesia?
questions.solution:
The click-or-pop sensation in spinal anesthesia is encountered while piercing ligamentum flavum and dura mater.

The spinal needle is introduced parallel to the midline and is advanced through the layers. There is a characteristic change in resistance felt when the needle passes through ligamentum flavum and dura. On piercing the ligamentum flavum, the first click-or-pop sensation is encountered. On further advancement of the needle, there is a second click or pop sensation encountered on piercing the dura. For spinal anesthesia, the needle is inserted until penetration of the dura-subarachnoid membranes, which is signaled by free-flowing cerebrospinal fluid (CSF).

The following structures are pierced during spinal anesthesia, in that order:

  1. Skin
  2. Subcutaneous tissue
  3. Supraspinous ligament
  4. Interspinous ligament
  5. Ligamentum flavum 
  6. Dura mater
  7. Arachnoid

Related Pearl: Extent of important structures/spaces in the Spinal cord

Structure / Space  Terminal extent 
Spinal cord at birth  L3 upper border 
Spinal cord at 2 years  L1 lower border 
Adult Spinal cord  L1 lower border  
Filum terminale  1st coccygeal segment 
Filum terminale internum , Dural sac S2 lower border 
Filum terminale externum  1st coccygeal segment 
Piamater  1st coccygeal segment 
Subarachnoid sheath and space, Subdural space  S2 lower border 
Cervical enlargement  C3-T2 spinal segments 
Lumbar enlargement  L1-S3 spinal segments 

Related Pearl: Complications of neuraxial (spinal and epidural) anesthesia

Adverse or exaggerated physiological response:

  • Urinary retention
  • High block
  • Total spinal anesthesia (with epidural)
  • Cardiac arrest
  • Anterior spinal artery syndrome
  • Horner's syndrome

Complication related to needle or catheter placement:

  • Backache
  • Dural puncture/leak
    • Post dural puncture headache
    • Diplopia (6th cranial nerve most commonly affected)
  • Neural injury
    • Nerve root/spinal cord damage
  • Bleeding
    • Intraspinal/epidural hematoma
  • Misplacement
    • Inadequate anesthesia
    • subdural block
    • intravascular injection
  • Inflammation 
    • Arachnoiditis
  • Infection
    • Meningitis
    • Epidural abscess

Drug toxicity

  • Systemic local anesthesia toxicity (epidural > spinal)
  • Transient neurological symptoms (Lidocaine, chloroprocaine with preservative)
  • Cauda equina syndrome (Lidocaine)

Related Pearl: Contraindications for Spinal anesthesia

Absolute

  • Infection at the site of injection
  • Patient refusal
  • Increased intracranial pressure
  • Allergy to the anesthetic drugs
  • Coagulopathy or other bleeding diathesis
  • Severe hypovolemia
  • Severe aortic stenosis
  • Severe mitral stenosis

Relative

  • Sepsis
  • Uncooperative patient
  • Preexisting neurological deficits
  • Demyelinating lesions
  • Stenotic valvular heart lesions
  • Left ventricular outflow obstruction (hypertrophic obstructive cardiomyopathy)
  • Severe spinal deformity

questions.text: A newborn was born with the deformity as shown in the image below. You apply a cast as per Ponseti's technique and ask them to return for complete treatment. The patient is however lost to follow-up and is brought to you 2 years later. Which of the following will you do?
questions.solution:
The image shows congenital talipes equinovarus (CTEV). Since the child is less than 3 years old, posteromedial soft tissue release procedures should be done as per the agewise management protocol of CTEV.

The first line of management for CTEV is Ponseti's technique in which gradual correction of deformities is done by plaster cast. The sequence of correction is given as:

C- Cavus 

A- Adduction

V- Varus

E- Equinus

In addition to the above procedure, we can provide the child with CTEV shoes as the child has started walking to retain the correction.

Features of CTEV shoes:

  • Straight inner border prevents adduction
  • Outer shoe raise prevents foot inversion
  • Absence of heel prevents equinus
  • Used once the deformity is corrected and when the child starts walking, upto 5 years of age

Related Pearl: Age wise management of CTEV

Initial treatment starts with Ponseti's POP cast as early as possible, but within 1 year of age.

If deformity gets corrected:

  • Dennis Brown splint is used till 1 year of age
  • After 1 year upto 5 years CTEV shoes are used in day, and Dennis Brown splint is used at night

If deformity is not corrected or untreated previously:

  • 1-3 years: Posteromedial soft tissue release (PMSTR) 
  • 3-5 years: Dillwyn Evans procedure
  • 5-8 years: Dwyer osteotomy
  • 8-10 years: Wedge tarsectomy
  • >10 years: Triple arthrodesis, external fixators

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with a swelling in the skull. The radiological finding was suggestive of lytic lesions. A bone biopsy was performed and the ultrastructure of the biopsied tissue is shown below. Identify the structure seen.
questions.solution:
The scenario with a young child presenting with a skull swelling with lytic lesions on radiography and Birbeck granules on ultrastructure examination suggests a diagnosis of Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH).

LCH is a clonal proliferation of pathological Langerhans cells. Men are more affected than women. Patients present with pain and swelling over the affected areas. Commonly affected sites are the skull, pelvis, femur, and mandible. Radiographs show a lytic lesion with periosteal new bone formation. In the skull, lesions appear as a hole within a hole, and in the vertebra, vertebra plana (flattening of the vertebral body) can be seen. 

Histopathologically, it is characterized by the presence of Langerhans cells. The tumor cells contain abundant cytoplasm with folded or grooved nuclei. Ultrastructurally, they contain tennis-racket-shaped intracytoplasmic inclusions called Birbeck granules. The tumor cells specifically express HLA-DR, S-100, and CD1a and langerin (CD207) markers.

The image below shows a histopathological image of Langerhan cells with folded nuclei.

Other options: 

Options A and B:  Asbestos bodies shown below are a hallmark finding of asbestosis. They appear as golden brown, fusiform, or beaded rods. These are formed when the asbestos fibers are phagocytosed by the macrophages and are coated by iron-containing proteinaceous material derived from phagocyte ferritin. Similar iron-protein complexes coat other inorganic particulates other than asbestos which are termed ferruginous bodies.

Option D: Schaumann bodies are seen in non-caseating granuloma of sarcoidosis. They are laminated concretions composed of calcium and protein.

Related Pearl: Skeletal and Radiological manifestation of Langerhan’s Cell Histiocytosis

Skull:

Solitary or multiple punched out lytic lesion without sclerotic rim.
Double contour or beveled edge appearance may be seen due to asymmetrical involvement of the inner and outer table (hole within a hole sign).
Button sequestra representing residual bone.
Geographic skull.

Spine:

Vertebra Plana:it is the most common cause of vertebra plana in children;mostly seen in the thoracic spine.

Mandible:

Irregular radiolucent areas mostly involving superficial alveolar bone.

Floating tooth: loss of lamina dura.

Long Bones:

  • Permeative and aggressive appearing lesions occur
  • Mainly involves diaphysis or meta diaphysis
  • Endosteal scalloping, Periosteal reaction(in healing phase),cortical thinning,intracortical tunneling and associated soft tissue mass can be seen.

questions.text: A 23-year-old female is advised to take iron supplements as she has mild iron deficiency anemia.  Foods containing which of the following should she be advised to not take along with her iron supplements?
questions.solution:
The absorption of iron is decreased by tannates which are found in tea, and hence they should be avoided. Ascorbic acid, amino acids, and sugars in the diet all help enhance the absorption of inorganic iron from the diet.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting iron absorption

Enhancers:

  • Ascorbic acid
  • Citric acid
  • Amino acid
  • Sugars in the diet

Inhibitors:

  • Tannins
  • Carbonate
  • Oxalate
  • Phosphate

questions.text: A 40-year-old diabetic woman is on an anti-arrhythmic drug after she had ventricular fibrillation 3 months back. During her routine diabetic workup, the ophthalmological examination shows corneal findings as in the image. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the drug implicated in this condition?

choices.text: It is contraindicated in a patient with interstitial lung disease
It belongs to the same class of drugs as propafenone
The most common cutaneous side effect is photosensitivity

questions.solution:
A bilateral whorl-like corneal pattern of golden-brown lines, as shown in the above image, is called vortex keratopathy (corneal verticillata). Corneal verticillata is observed with the use of amiodarone. Amiodarone is a Class III anti-arrhythmic drug whereas propafenone is a class IC antiarrhythmic.

Amiodarone is classified as a class III antiarrhythmic agent. It exerts its function through various mechanisms:

  • Blockade of the transient outward delayed rectifier and inward rectifier K+ currents mainly
  • Blockade of inactivated Na+ channels with a rapid rate of recovery
  • Decreases Ca2+ current
  • Inhibition of cell-to-cell coupling, thus decreasing conduction velocity

Ventricular tachycardia and recurrent ventricular fibrillation are the most important indications for amiodarone. It is also used to maintain sinus rhythm in atrial fibrillation when other drugs have failed.

Amiodarone is known to cause multiple side effects. Photosensitivity in the form of blue-grey discoloration occurs in body areas that are exposed to the sun, as shown in the image below. The most serious side effect is pulmonary fibrosis, which can progress rapidly and be fatal. Hypo- and hyperthyroidism can also occur during chronic amiodarone therapy. Amiodarone is a blocker of CYP3A4 and CYP2C9, and thus, dose modifications of concurrent drugs may be required.

 

Other causes of vortex keratopathy include:

  • Amiodarone
  • Chloroquine and hydroxychloroquine
  • Fabry disease

questions.text: Which of the following shows True Koebner’s phenomenon?
questions.solution:
Lichen Planus shows True Koebner’s phenomenon.

Koebner’s phenomenon/ isomorphic response is the development of lesions in previously normal skin that has been subjected to trauma. If the same response is seen from the spread of an infective agent ( like molluscum contagiosum, viral warts), it's called pseudo-koebner’s phenomenon.

Any of the following can elicit an isomorphic response:

  1. Physical trauma, including friction
  2. Incision and laceration
  3. Skin grafting
  4. Bites
  5. Vaccination skin tests
  6. Burns, freezing, and ultraviolet (UV), and ionizing radiation.

It is seen commonly associated with psoriasis, lichen planus, and vitiligo. Other associated disorders include Darrier’s disease, pityriasis rubra pilaris, lichen nidatus, DLE, necrobiosis lipoidica, and Grzybowski syndrome.

Related Pearl: Koebner phenomenon

Koebner or isomorphic Phenomenon is the development of new lesions along the line of trauma in a previously normal skin. The new lesions have 'iso' (same) and 'morphic' (morphology) as the existing lesions.

The trauma may include mechanical trauma, thermal trauma, allergic or irritant reactants or any treatment procedures.

True Koebner's phenomenon In immune-mediated conditions

Psoriasis

Vitiligo

Lichen planus
False Koebner's phenomenon In infectious diseases

Viral warts

Molluscum contagiosum
     
Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon

Spontaneous repigmentation of vitiligo patches distant from the autologous skin graft sites (trauma)

Generalized granuloma annulare

Vitiligo

Psoriasis

Some rare causes of True Koebner Phenomenon are : Darier's disease, Hailey-Hailey disease, Erythema multiforme, Kaposi's Sarcoma and Lichen sclerosus.

Image: Koebner phenomenon with linear psoriasis patch on the abdomen

questions.text:
Match the following types of thyroplasty procedures with their respective uses.
1. Type I a. To reduce pitch
2. Type II b. Complete unilateral palsy
3. Type III c. To increase pitch
4. Type IV d. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
questions.solution:
The correct match is as follows:

1. Type I b. Complete unilateral palsy
2. Type II d. Bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy
3. Type III a. To reduce pitch
4. Type IV c. To increase pitch

 

Thyroplasty is a surgery done to improve the quality of voice. Isshiki's classification of thyroplasty includes:

Type

Thyroplasty

Uses

I

Medialization

In complete unilateral palsy (recurrent laryngeal nerve and superior laryngeal nerve) - Vocal cord is medialized towards the midline for the opposite cord to meet. Thyroplasty is done by creating a window in the thyroid cartilage and placing silicon or other prostheses to medialize the cord. It can also be used in Abductor dysphonia.

II

Lateralization

In bilateral recurrent laryngeal nerve palsy. It creates a lateral expansion of the larynx
and is similar to vocal cord lateralization. Quality of
voice may not be good

III

Shortening (relax the vocal cord)

To reduce pitch

IV

Lengthening (tighten the vocal cord)

To increase pitch

Note to remember: MLSL

questions.text: A 16-days-old male baby born at 34 weeks is found to have abdominal distention, hematochezia, hypotension, bradycardia, and lethargy. He is fed only artificial formula milk. The abdominal x-ray shows pneumoperitoneum. What is the stage of disease according to Modified Bell's Staging Criteria?
questions.solution:
Abdominal distension and hematochezia in a preterm baby exclusively fed on formula feed are suggestive of necrotizing enterocolitis (NEC). The abdominal X-ray finding of pneumoperitoneum is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIIB, according to the Modified Bell's Staging Criteria. Stage IIIB of necrotizing enterocolitis(NEC) presents with intestinal perforation.

Modified Bell's Staging Criteria:

Stage I - Suspected NEC
Stage II - Proven NEC
Stage III - Advanced NEC

Stage   Intestinal signs Systemic signs Radiological signs  
IA Suspected NEC Mild abdominal distention, emesis, guaiac-positive stool Temperature instability, apnea, bradycardia, lethargy Normal or intestinal dilatation, mild ileus  
IB   IA + Bright red blood from the rectum Same as IA Same as IA  
IIA Mildly ill Absent bowel sounds Same as IA  Pneumatosis intestinalis, ileus  
IIB Moderately ill  IIA + definite abdominal tenderness IA+ Metabolic acidosis and thrombocytopenia   IIA + portal venous gas, with or without ascites  
IIIA Severely ill, bowel intact  IIB + peritonitis with marked tenderness, and abdominal distension  IIB+ hypotension, bradycardia, acidosis, DIC, neutropenia  IIB + definite ascites   
IIIB Severely ill, bowel
perforated		  Same as III A Same as IIIA   IIB +pneumoperitoneum  

Necrotizing enterocolitis:

It is the most common life-threatening gastrointestinal disorder in the newborn period. It is characterized by various degrees of mucosal or transmural inflammation and necrosis of the intestinal tract. It most commonly affects the distal ileum and proximal colon. 

Three major risk factors implicated are:

  • Prematurity is the greatest risk factor
  • Formula feeding
  • Bacterial colonization of the intestine

Incidence and mortality increase with decreasing birth weight and gestational age. It usually presents within the 2nd or 3rd week of life with abdominal distension and tenderness, feed intolerance, and occult/gross blood in the stool. Systemic features include hypotension, bradycardia, lethargy, and temperature instability.

Diagnosis can be made with a plain abdominal X-ray. The important signs are :

  • Pneumatosis intestinalis (air in the bowel wall) is diagnostic. It corresponds to stage IIA.
  • Portal vein gas is a sign of severe disease and corresponds to stage IIB.
  • Pneumoperitoneum indicates perforation and corresponds to stage IIIB.

Management of NEC includes supportive measures - nil per oral, nasogastric decompression, intravenous fluids, broad-spectrum antibiotics, and inotropic support if indicated. Perforation is an absolute indication of surgery. The most effective preventive strategy is the use of human milk. Prebiotics and synbiotics can be used with variable efficacy in the use of probiotics.

The given X-ray shows pneumatosis intestinalis (black arrows). It is seen as a characteristic train-track lucency appearance within the bowel wall due to the gas produced by bacteria.

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of pain in the hip. There is no history of any trauma. An x-ray was taken which appears as given below. All of the following can result in this condition except
questions.solution:
X-ray showing a crescent sign in a patient with hip pain with no history of trauma is suggestive of avascular necrosis. Rheumatoid arthritis is not a cause of avascular necrosis.

Causes of avascular necrosis  

Trauma

 

Hemoglobinopathy
  • Sickle-cell disease

Storage disorders
  • Gaucher’s disease

Caisson disease
  • Dysbaric osteonecrosis

Coagulation disorders
  • Familial thrombophilia
  • Hypofibrinolysis
  • Hypolipoproteinaemia
  • Thrombocytopenic purpura

Infections
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Septic arthritis
Other
  • Perthes’ disease
  • Cortisone administration
  • Alcohol abuse
  • Systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE)
  • Pregnancy 
  • Anaphylactic shock
  • Ionizing radiation

The image below shows the crescent sign, which is caused by the necrotic and repair processes that occur during avascular necrosis.

Related Pearl: Avascular Necrosis (AVN)

It is a rare but severe complication of certain fractures when the blood supply to a segment of bone is affected. 

Common sites of AVN are:

  • Head of the femur in fracture neck of femur and posterior dislocation of the hip
  • Body of talus in a fracture through the neck of talus
  • Proximal pole of the scaphoid in a fracture through the waist of the scaphoid
  • Head of the humerus
  • The capitulum

Non-traumatic causes of AVN are:

  • Idiopathic
  • Steroids
  • Sickle cell disease
  • Caisson's disease
  • Gaucher's disease
  • Lupus Erythematosus
  • Radiation therapy
  • Alcoholism
  • Hyperlipidemia

Important signs related to avascular necrosis:

  • Crescent sign- Seen in osteonecrosis of the femoral head. It is a subchondral fracture overlying the necrotic segment of the femoral head.
  • Hawkin's sign- Seen secondary to the fracture of the neck of the talus. It refers to subchondral lucency of the dome of the talus due to subchondral atrophy. The presence of this sign indicates that the blood supply to the talus is adequate and chances of avascular necrosis are low.

questions.text:
A teenager developed swelling of the face, lips, and tongue and also found it difficult to breathe within a few minutes of consumption of prawns. What are the major cytokines produced in this condition? (IL- Interleukin, IFN-γ -Interferon gamma)
  1. IL-4
  2. IL-5
  3. IL-6
  4. IL-13
  5. IL-17
  6. IFN-γ
questions.solution:
Anaphylaxis following consumption of prawns is an example of IgE-mediated reaction or Type 1 hypersensitivity where the major cytokines involved are IL-4, IL-5 and IL-13.

Immediate (Type I) hypersensitivity reactions refer to allergic reactions or allergies. It is a rapid immunologic reaction that is triggered by the binding of an antigen to IgE antibody on the surface of mast cells. It occurs in a previously sensitized individual. These reactions are induced by environmental antigens (allergens) that stimulate strong TH2 responses and IgE production in genetically susceptible individuals. 

Activation of TH2 cells is mediated by IL-4 and in turn, TH2 cells produce IL-4, IL-5, and IL-13. These cytokines act on B cells to stimulate IgE and activation of eosinophils. IgE coats mast cells by binding to the FcεRI receptor. Re-exposure to the allergen leads to cross-linking of the IgE and FcεRI which in turn causes activation of mast cells releasing powerful mediators. The principal mediators are:

  • Histamine
  • Proteases
  • Prostaglandins
  • Leukotrienes
  • Cytokines like TNF, IL-1, and chemokines. 

The clinical manifestations may be local or systemic and range from mildly annoying rhinitis to fatal anaphylaxis. It occurs in two phases: 

  • The immediate phase is characterized by vasodilation, vascular leakage, smooth muscle spasm (in asthma), or glandular secretions. These changes occur within minutes after exposure to an allergen and subside in a few hours.
  • Late-phase reaction is characterized by infiltration of tissues with eosinophils, neutrophils, basophils, monocytes, and CD4+ T cells. Late-phase reaction sets in 2 to 24 hours later and may last for several days.

Image: Sequence of events in immediate (type 1) hypersensitivity.

Other options:

  • IL-6 is a principal mediator of inflammation.
  • IL-17 secreted by T lymphocytes is plays a role in acute and chronic inflammation by recruiting of neutrophils and monocytes.
  • IFN-γ activates macrophages and is a mediator of chronic inflammation.

Related Pearl: Disorders Caused by Immediate Hypersensitivity

Clinical Syndrome

Clinical and Pathologic Manifestations

Anaphylaxis (may be caused by drugs, bee sting, food)

Fall in blood pressure (shock) caused by vascular dilation; airway obstruction due to laryngeal edema

Bronchial asthma

Airway obstruction caused by bronchial smooth muscle hyperactivity; inflammation and tissue injury caused by late-phase reaction

Allergic rhinitis, sinusitis (hay fever)

Increased mucus secretion; inflammation of upper airways, sinuses

Food allergies

Increased peristalsis due to contraction of intestinal muscles

Related Pearl: Types of Hypersensitivity

Type of reaction Clinical Syndrome Time for manifestation Mediators
Type I:
IgE type

1. Anaphylaxis

2. Atopy

 Minutes IgE: histamine and other pharmacological agents
Type II:
Cytolytic, cytotoxic

Antibody-mediated damage: e.g. thrombocytopenia, agranulocytosis, hemolytic anemia

 Hours to days IgG, IgM
Type III:
Immune complex

1.Arthus-reaction

2.Serum-sickness

 Hours to days IgG, IgM, leucocytes
Type IV:
Delayed hypersensitivity

1. Tuberculin

2. Contact dermatitis

 Hours to days T cells, lymphokines, macrophages.

Related Pearl: Mechanisms of Hypersensitivity Reactions

Type

Immune Mechanisms

Histopathological lesions

Immediate
 hypersensitivity
(type I)

  • Anaphylaxis
  • Allergies
  • Bronchial asthma
  • Atopic dermatitis

Production of IgE antibody →immediate release of vasoactive amines from mast cells

Vascular dilatation, edema, smooth muscle contraction, mucus production, tissue injury, inflammation

Antibody-mediated hypersensitivity
(type II)

  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia
  • Goodpasture syndrome

Production of IgG, IgM → binds to antigen on target cell or tissue → phagocytosis or lysis of target cell by activated complement or Fc receptors; recruitment of leukocytes

Phagocytosis and lysis of cells; inflammation;

Immune complex-mediated hypersensitivity
(type III)

  • SLE
  • Serum sickness
  • Arthus reaction

Deposition of antigen-antibody complexes → complement activation →recruitment of leukocytes by complement products and Fc receptors → release of enzymes and other toxic molecules

Inflammation, necrotizing vasculitis (fibrinoid necrosis)

Cell-mediated hypersensitivity
(type IV)

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Multiple sclerosis
  • Type 1 diabetes
  • Tuberculosis

Activated T lymphocytes →

1. Release of cytokines, inflammation, and macrophage activation

2. T-cell-mediated cytotoxicity

Perivascular cellular infiltrates; edema; granuloma formation; cell destruction

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presented with severe restlessness, palpitations, facial flushing, and sweating. The patient had an episode of dysentery 2 days prior and had been prescribed medication for that. The patient reports taking alcohol 2 hours after his medications. Which of the following drug does not cause similar effects?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient developing symptoms like restlessness and flushing after taking alcohol after medication is suggestive of a disulfiram-like reaction. Among the given drugs, ofloxacin is not associated with a disulfiram-like reaction.

Some important drugs which cause a disulfiram-like reaction are:

  • Metronidazole, Tinidazole
  • Some cephalosporins like cefoperazone
  • 1st generation sulfonylureas like tolbutamide
  • Procarbazine

These drugs inhibit aldehyde dehydrogenase, similar to disulfiram. When alcohol is combined with these drugs, acetaldehyde accumulates and causes unpleasant symptoms like flushing, sweating, tachycardia, hypotension, nausea, vomiting, dizziness, and headache.

questions.text:
Which of the following is seen in freshwater drowning?

1. Haemodilution
2. Hypokalemia
3. Hyponatremia
4. Arrhythmia
questions.solution:
In cases of freshwater drowning, hyperkalemia is seen due to hemolysis of swollen RBCs and not hypokalemia.

Freshwater is hypotonic to plasma and is rapidly absorbed from the alveoli and into the RBCs. The RBCs finally swell up and lyse resulting in the release of intracellular potassium causing hyperkalemia. Increased intravascular blood volume combined with hyperkalemia causes arrhythmia. 

Seawater is hypertonic to plasma and causing a shift of fluid from the blood to alveoli causing pulmonary edema. There is a net decrease in blood volume causing a fall in blood pressure.

The table below summarises the cause of death in different types of drowning.

Type of drowning           Cause of death

Freshwater drowning

Seawater drowning

 Disruption of surfactant 

Dry drowning

 Laryngeal spasm/Vagal inhibition
Post immersion Syndrome / Secondary drowning

Cerebral anoxia

Pneumonia

Pulmonary edema

Chemical pneumonitis

Metabolic acidosis

questions.text:
A patient is on mechanical ventilation for the past week. He is now hemodynamically stable and has the following values. What is the best course of management for this patient?
  1. pH - 7.45
  2. Arterial oxygen saturation- 95% on 40% O2.
  3. RSBI- 125
  4. Tidal volume- 6ml/Kg

RSBI- Rapid shallow breathing index.

choices.text: Wean from ventilatory support and extubate over next 6 hours.
Increase the PEEP by 50% for next 6 hours and then extubate.
Increase the O2 to 100% and recheck the values after an interval of 6 hours.

questions.solution:
Amongst the given choices, the best course of management for this patient is to retain mechanical ventilatory support. 

Patients with an RSBI <100 are eligible candidates for successful extubation. Since this patient has a higher value (RSBI >120) he will need some degree of mechanical ventilator support.

A patient on mechanical ventilation should be tried to wean off when the patient no longer meets the criteria for the ventilator. This condition is usually met when the patient can 

  • Breathe spontaneously 
  • Hemodynamically stable
  • Arterial oxygen saturation >90% on 40–50% O2 with <5 cm H2O of PEEP.
  • pH >7.25.

Additional criteria include,

  • Inspiratory pressure: < -25 cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: >5 ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: <10L.
  • Rapid shallow breathing index(RSBI): <100

Patients are weaned off from the ventilator with the help of techniques such as pressure support, synchronized intermittent mandatory ventilation (SIMV), and periods of spontaneous breathing (either on a Τ-piece or on a low setting of CPAP).

Related Pearl: Mechanical Criteria for Weaning or Extubation

  • Inspiratory pressure: -20 to -30cm H2O
  • Tidal volume: 4-6ml/kg
  • Vital capacity: >10 mL/kg
  • Minute ventilation: 10L/min
  • Rapid shallow breathing index: <100

questions.text: A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region with a history of thorn prick presents to the OPD with the following lesions. Which of the following statements is not-true regarding this condition?

choices.text: The causative organism is a thermally dimorphic fungus.
Sclerotic bodies can be seen on microscopy
Itraconazole is the preferred drug for this condition.
The nodules appear along the lymphatics.

questions.solution:
The given image shows the distribution of the nodules along lymphatics. This distribution along the lymphatics with the history of thorn pick is suggestive of sporotrichosis, caused by the causative agent Sporothrix schenkii. Asteroid bodies are seen in sporotrichosis

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is usually followed by spread along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes. 

It is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It is in the yeast phase in tissues and in cultures at 37°C, and in the mycelia phase in nature and cultures at 25°C. When it is cultured, the colonies are blackish-brown and fuzzy. The organism produces branching, septate hyphae, and microconidia clustered at the ends of conidiophores. It exists as cigar-shaped yeast cells. Stains used for identifying yeast forms: 

  • Gomori methenamine silver-cell wall appears black
  • Periodic acid-Schiff stain - cell wall appears red 
  • Fluorescent antibody staining

The image given below shows, (A)- (i) culture at 37°C (ii) culture at 25°C. (B) fungi with clustered microconidia with conidiophore.  (C) Magnified image showing branching and septate hyphae.

Direct microscopic examination of necrotic material in KOH mount or histopathological examination of tissue sections stained by methenamine silver stain shows the asteroid body. Asteroid body is a rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like body 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell.

Clinical features: The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules. Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Treatment: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis. 

Other treatment options for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis:

  • Terbinafine
  • SSKI- Saturated solution of potassium iodide
  • Fluconazole
  • Local hyperthermia

Amphotericin B can be used for disseminated infections.

Sclerotic bodies are seen in chromoblastomycosis. Traumatic implantation is the mode of infection. Patients present with warty cauliflower-like cutaneous nodules on the feet and lower legs. Species of the fungal genus Fonsecaea are implicated as the causative agents. Diagnosis is made by the demonstration of sclerotic bodies (copper-penny bodies) in tissue sections. Sclerotic bodies appear as round or irregular, dark brown bodies with septae.

Related Pearl: Common names of various fungal infections

Disease

Common name

Histoplasmosis

Darling’s disease

Sporotrichosis

Rose-thorn or Rose gardener’s disease

Para-coccidioidomycosis

South American blastomycosis

Coccidioidomycosis

Valley fever or desert rheumatism

Blastomycosis

North American blastomycosis, Gilchrist's disease

questions.text: A 38-year-old male patient presented to surgery OPD with a history of intermittent purulent discharge with a slight blood tinge from an external opening located in the perianal region. On examination, the location of the external opening was at 8’O clock position. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this disease?

choices.text: MRI is the gold standard modality of investigation
Seton's technique induces fibrosis and  has very good evidence of healing
Sphincter division can lead on to sphincter dysfunction and incontinence
Laying open fistulotomy shows improvement but does not eradicate the disease

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of fistula-in-ano. Laying open fistulotomy is the definitive management method to eradicate the disease. 

A fistula-in-ano is an abnormal hollow tract or cavity that is lined with granulation tissue and that connects a primary opening inside the anal canal to a secondary opening in the perianal skin. The most common cause is perianal abscess. Other causes include tuberculosis or Crohn's disease.

Symptoms include perianal pain and intermittent purulent discharge (which may be bloody) 

Goodsall’s rule can be used as a guide in determining the location of the internal opening of the fistula.

  • Fistulas with an external opening anteriorly connect to the internal opening by a short, radial tract.
  • Fistulas with an external opening posteriorly track in a curvilinear fashion to the posterior midline.

However, exceptions to this rule often occur: Fistulas with an anterior external opening greater than 3 cm from the anal margin usually track to the posterior midline.

The investigations done for fistula-in-ano are as follows:

  • Fistulogram
  • Endoanal ultrasound
  • MRI
  • Computed tomography (CT) scan
  • Endocoil MRI
  • Hydrogen peroxide–enhanced 3-D endoanal ultrasonography

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) is the gold standard investigation for fistula imaging. It helps us to identify the secondary extensions of the track, which when missed may cause the persistence of the fistula. (Option-A)

Treatment:

  • Control of constipation
  • Sitz bath
  • Fistulotomy
  • Fistulectomy
  • Ligation of intersphincteric fistula tract (LIFT)
  • Setons
  • Advancement flaps

 

Option B: Seton’s technique is used in the management of fistula-in-ano. The seton should be non-absorbable, non-degenerative, and comfortable. A seton is a drain placed through a fistula to maintain drainage and/or induce fibrosis. It is left in place for 3 months. Seton's technique induces fibrosis and has very good evidence of healing. If there is evidence of good healing it is removed.

For fistulas that involve more than 30% of the sphincter or those which are distal to the dentate line, loosely placement of seton through the track helps to facilitate drainage of any sepsis and to preserve the sphincter.

This may be converted to a cutting seton by gradually tightening at regular intervals to promote fibrosis and to slowly cut through the involved sphincter muscle, thus helps in eliminating the fistula while maintaining the continuity of the sphincter.

Option C: Laying open is the surest method of eradication, but sphincter division may result in incontinence due to sphincter dysfunction.

questions.text: Unconsciousness at surgical planes is unlikely to be associated with:
questions.solution:
Beta oscillations (13-25 Hz) oscillations are seen in an arousable state of sedation.

EEG waves are used to track the level of unconsciousness of patients receiving general anesthesia and sedation.

  • Slow (0.1-1 Hz), delta (1-4 Hz), and alpha (8-12 Hz) oscillations are commonly seen during unconsciousness at surgical planes.
  • Slow oscillations are typically recorded during deep sedation.
  • Isoelectric EEGs are commonly observed in brief periods during normal maintenance, in an anesthetic-induced coma, and in profound hypothermia.

questions.text: What is the effect on resting membrane potential when the serum potassium is 3 mEq/L?

choices.text: RMP becomes more negative, cell is more excitable
RMP becomes more positive, cell is more excitable
RMP becomes more negative, cell is less excitable
RMP becomes more positive, cell is less excitable

questions.solution:
A potassium level of 3 mEq/L means there is hypokalemia. The resting membrane potential becomes more negative and the cell is less excitable in hypokalemia.

The resting membrane potential represents an equilibrium situation where the concentration gradient of ions across the membrane is equal and opposite to the electrical gradients. At a normal potassium concentration of 3.5–5.5 mEq/L, the equilibrium potential for potassium is −90 mV. This is close to the resting membrane potential of neurons, which is about –70 mV.

A decrease in the extracellular sodium concentration reduces the size of the action potential but has little effect on the resting membrane potential. However, the intracellular and extracellular potassium (K+) concentrations are the major determinants of the RMP.

This is because

  • At rest, there are more open K+ channels than Na+ channels; therefore, the membrane permeability of K+ is greater.
  • The RMP is close to the equilibrium potential of K+.

In hypokalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is reduced. Thus, the RMP is reduced or becomes more negative and the nerve is hyperpolarized.

In hyperkalemia, the extracellular level of K+ is increased. Thus, the RMP moves closer to the threshold to elicit an action potential, leading to a more excitable nerve. This means the RMP has become more positive. 

Related Pearl: Resting membrane potential (RMP) in tissues

Tissue

RMP(mV)

Neuron

-70

Skeletal muscle

-90

Myocardial muscle

-90

Smooth muscle

-20 to -65

questions.text: A 30-year-old athlete injures his leg. He complains of pain in his knees. The following technique has been employed to alleviate his pain. This technique relieves pain using which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The given image shows transcutaneous electrical nerve stimulation (TENS) used for pain relief. It is based on the gate control theory of pain. This method uses electrodes to activate Aα and Aβ fibers near the injury to relieve pain.

Gate control theory is based on the inhibition of pain pathways in the spinal cord. Various sensory inputs from a particular dermatome reach the dorsal horn of the spinal cord. The pain is transmitted via A-delta and C fibers, whereas, A-beta fibers carry tactile sensations (touch, pressure) and A-alpha fibers carry proprioception.

When these large-diameter A-beta/A-alpha fibers are stimulated, they inhibit the pain pathway in the spinal cord. This inhibition is thought to result from the local lateral inhibition of interneurons in the spinal cord.

Gate control theory operates at the substantia gelatinosa of the dorsal horn of the spinal cord.

The given image depicts the gate control theory of pain:

questions.text: A 58-year-old female with type 2 diabetes mellitus is brought to the ER with lethargy and deep breathing. She had undergone a contrast-enhanced CT scan one day prior. Biochemical examination showed lactic acidosis. Which of the following drugs is responsible?
questions.solution:
The most likely drug responsible for causing lactic acidosis in a diabetic patient with impaired renal function (due to contrast medium used in CECT) is metformin.

Lactic acidosis is seen with metformin when there are concomitant conditions that can impair tissue perfusion. Such conditions include heart failure, myocardial infarction and sepsis. Furthermore, metformin should be discontinued in diabetic patients who are being planned radiographic procedures that require contrast enhancement. Reduced GFR — as a result of chronic kidney disease, or because of contrast dye — leads to a reduction in the clearance of metformin. The levels of metformin rise above the therapeutic range and cause lactic acidosis.

Canagliflozin (option A) is an SGLT2 inhibitor. They lead to an increase in the incidence of urinary tract infections and genital fungal infections. Because of the increased diuresis, there may be hypotension. There may be an increased risk of fractures with these drugs. The adverse effects of pioglitazone (option B) include weight gain and edema. It causes an increase in fat deposition in the body. Since it causes fluid retention, it is contraindicated in patients with heart failure. Glibenclamide (option C) is a sulfonylurea. It can frequently cause hypoglycemia and weight gain. Being a sulfa-derivative, it can cause hypersensitivity reactions and hemolytic anemias. It can also cause a disulfiram-like reaction on concomitant consumption of alcohol.

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

Paraldehyde Extra chloride (Hyperalimentation)
Iron tablets, INH Diarrhea
Lactic acidosis Carbonic anhydrase inhibitor (acetazolamide)
Ethylene glycol Addison's disease
Salicylates Renal tubular acidosis

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is not used in the treatment of obesity?
questions.solution:
Sibutramine is a serotonin and norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor that was previously used for the management of obesity. However, due to its cardiovascular adverse effects, it has been banned in many countries, including India. It is no longer used in the management of obesity.

Antiobesity medications can be considered in patients with a BMI of ≥30, or a BMI of ≥27 with comorbidities related to weight. The patients should be counseled that the medications should be viewed as an additional measure rather than a replacement for a healthy diet and exercise. 

The drugs that are currently approved for the management of obesity include:

  • Phentermine: adrenergic agonist
  • Orlistat: inhibitor of intestinal lipase; reduces dietary fat absorption
  • Phentermine plus topiramate: adrenergic agonism and appetite suppression
  • Naltrexone plus bupropion: reduction of appetite and food cravings
  • Liraglutide, Tirzepatide, semaglutide: GLP-1 agonists

questions.text: During the examination of a gunshot victim, the skin around the entry wound shows marks from the grease, soot, and debris from the barrel of the gun. What is this referred to as?
questions.solution:
The skin around the entry wound showing marks from the grease, soot, and debris from the barrel of the gun is referred to as grease collar/ dirt collar/ bullet wipe.

While examining the clothing of a victim of a bullet injury, there is a deposition of various residues surrounding the entrance defect at various ranges, known as Bullet wipe. It helps in determining the wounds of inlet and outlet upon the body.

Bullet graze/ Bullet slap: the bullet just hits the skin only at an angle and goes off from the site, without any penetration or wound of entry. It produces an abrasion or a laceration depending on the thickness of the skin involved.

Bullet bruise: the bullet here just hits the skin only and drops down to the ground, without any penetration or wound of entry. It produces a bruise alone at the site of impact.

Fouling: refers to tiny lesions surrounding the entry wound which are caused by fragments of metal that are expelled by the discharge wither from the surface of the missile itself or from the interior of the barrel. A black ring around the bullet hole is seen in infrared photography.

Related Pearl: Difference between Wound of Entry and Exit

Wound of entry

Wound of exit

Smaller than the diameter of the bullet.

In close discharge, skin is torn, hence size is increased.

Bigger than the diameter of the bullet.

Everted

-ve

+ve

-ve

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

From left to right : Blank with frangible wooden bullet, ball, tracer and incendiary bullets

questions.text: A 35 -year-old male presented with a chronic non-healing ulcer over the leg. He gives a history of gall stones, attacks of severe pain in the digits of hands and feet. His medical records reveal he has had an episode of salmonella osteomyelitis. His peripheral smear is shown in the figure. What is the most likely underlying defect?

choices.text: Nonsense mutation causing premature termination of β-globin gene translation
Point mutation in the sixth codon of β-globin

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with repeated vaso-occlusive crises, gall stones, and salmonella osteomyelitis, and the peripheral smear showing sickle cells, target cells, and polychromasia are suggestive of sickle cell anemia. Sickle cell disease is caused by a point mutation in the sixth codon of β-globin that leads to the replacement of a glutamate residue with a valine residue.

HbS molecules stack into polymers when deoxygenated. With continued deoxygenation HbS molecules assemble into long needle-like fibers within red cells, producing a distorted sickle or holly-leaf shape. Polymerization of deoxygenated hemoglobin, leading to red cell distortion, hemolytic anemia, microvascular obstruction, and ischemic tissue damage.

Peripheral blood smear demonstrates -  Irreversibly sickled cells, reticulocytosis, and target cells, which result from red cell dehydration with Howell-Jolly bodies.

The major pathologic manifestation is chronic hemolysis, microvascular occlusions, and tissue damage. Increased breakdown of hemoglobin is responsible for pigment gallstones and hyperbilirubinemia. Splenomegaly can be seen in early childhood, but fibrosis and progressive shrinkage of the spleen may occur in adolescence known as autosplenectomy. Priapism affects up to 45% of males. Leg ulcers may also be seen. Stroke and retinopathy leading to loss of visual acuity and even blindness.

Vaso-occlusive crises, or pain crises are characterized by episodes of hypoxic injury and infarction that cause severe pain in the affected region, hand-foot syndrome, or dactylitis. Osteomyelitis in a sickle cell anemia patient is commonly caused by Salmonella and it most likely affects the diaphysis of bones. Acute chest syndrome is a vaso-occlusive crisis involving the lungs with fever, cough, chest pain, and pulmonary infiltrates. Sequestration crises is seen in children with intact spleens. Massive entrapment of sickle red cells leads to rapid splenic enlargement, hypovolemia, and sometimes shock. Aplastic crises occur due to the infection of red cell progenitors by parvovirus B19, which causes a transient arrest of erythropoiesis and a sudden worsening of the anemia.

Increased susceptibility to infection with encapsulated organisms is another risk due to altered splenic function. Pneumococcus and Haemophilus influenzae septicemia and meningitis are common, particularly in children, but can be reduced by vaccination and prophylactic antibiotics. Hemoglobin electrophoresis is also used to demonstrate the presence of HbS.

Other options:

Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH) is a disease that results from acquired mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A gene (PIGA), which is required for the synthesis of phosphatidylinositol glycan (PIG). These cells lack the ability to synthesize proteins that limit the activity of complement. As a result, they are sensitive to lysis by the complement C5b-C9 membrane attack complex

Hereditary spherocytosis is caused by mutations that most frequently involve ankyrin, band 3, or spectrin (i.e. inherited defects in the membrane skeleton).

A nonsense mutation is a point mutation in a sequence of DNA that results in a premature stop codon. For example, a point mutation affecting the codon for glutamine (CAG) creates a stop codon (UAG) if U is substituted for C. This change leads to premature termination of β-globin gene translation, and the short peptide that is produced is rapidly degraded. The resulting deficiency of β-globin chains can give rise to a severe form of anemia called β0 thalassemia.

questions.text:
Which of the following agglutination patterns in the Weil-Felix Reaction will be seen in a patient diagnosed with scrub typhus?
  OX 19 OX 2 OX K
1. +++ + -
2. +++ +/- -
3 ++ ++  -
4. - - +++
questions.solution:
OX K agglutination in a Weil-Felix Reaction will be seen in a case of scrub typhus.

Scrub typhus is also known as chigger-borne typhus, which is caused by O. tsutsugamushi. The vector is trombiculid mite. Humans are infected when they are bitten by the mite larvae known as chiggers. 

The incubation period is 1–3 weeks. The patient typically develops a characteristic eschar at the site of the mite bite, with regional lymphadenopathy and maculopapular rash.

Weil-Felix reaction is a heterophile agglutination reaction, wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain Proteus strains—Proteus vulgaris - OX 19 and OX 2 and Proteus mirabilis OX K. The basis of the test is sharing an alkali-stable carbohydrate antigen by some Rickettsiae and by some strains of Proteus. OX K is agglutinated only in scrub typhus.

questions.text: A patient fell with his arm in the flexed and adducted position. He is unable to move his shoulder due to severe pain. On examination, the front of the shoulder looks flat, with a prominent coracoid. X-ray done is given below, what could be the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the Light bulb sign in the X-ray is suggestive of posterior dislocation of the shoulder.

In the posterior dislocation of the shoulder, the humerus rotates internally. This causes changes to the normal radiographic contour of the head of the humerus. The humerus appears similar to a lightbulb in AP views.

Posterior dislocation of the arm most commonly occurs during a convulsion, or after an electric shock. It can also happen after a fall on the flexed, adducted arm, either by a direct blow to the front of the shoulder or due to a fall on the outstretched hand. 

The classical attitude of the arm is internal rotation and locked in that position. The examiner will be unable to externally rotate the arm back to its normal position.  

Other radiological signs described in posterior dislocation of the shoulder in the AP view are as follows:

  • The rim sign: Widening of the glenohumeral joint space > 6 mm.
  • The vacant glenoid sign: The glenoid fossa looks empty as the humeral head has moved away from it.
  • The trough sign: A vertical line is seen on the anteromedial part of the humeral head due to the impression fracture by the glenoid labrum.

questions.text: Which of the following images correctly represent the regulation of the most abundant anterior pituitary hormone?
questions.solution:
Growth hormone (GH), produced by the acidophil cells of the anterior pituitary is the most abundant hormone of the pituitary, and Option C represents the correct regulation of growth hormone secretion.

The following inferences can be made out from the image given as option C.

  • Growth hormone-releasing hormone secreted from the hypothalamus acts on the anterior pituitary to release growth hormone.
  • The released growth hormone increases the circulating levels of IGF -1 which exerts its effect on the tissues.
  • Ghrelin promotes the secretion of growth hormone from the anterior pituitary.
  • Somatostatin secreted from the hypothalamus is an inhibitory effect on the GH secretion from the anterior pituitary.
  • Similarly, IGF -1 exerts negative feedback on GH secretion and positive feedback on somatostatin secretion, which in turn inhibits GH secretion.

Related Pearl: Cells of Anterior Pituitary

questions.text: A  patient with elevated blood pressure even after the medical intervention is found to have a solitary adrenal adenoma on imaging studies. A tissue sample of the adenoma taken during laparoscopic adrenalectomy is sent to the laboratory for you to examine. The histopathological picture is as shown below. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: More common in men than women
The image is showing spironolactone bodies

questions.solution:
The given image shows the presence of eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions, known as spironolactone bodies which are found after treatment with spironolactone and the presence of a solitary adenoma is indicative of Conn syndrome. This is more common in females than males. 

Hyperaldosteronism is the increased secretion of aldosterone. It can be primary or secondary. Primary hyperaldosteronism is autonomous overproduction of aldosterone, with suppression of the renin-angiotensin system and decreased plasma renin activity. The two primary causes of primary hyperaldosteronism are adrenocortical adenoma and bilateral adrenal hyperplasia. 

When primary hyperaldosteronism is caused by a solitary aldosterone-secreting adenoma, the condition is referred to as Conn syndrome. This occurs most frequently in mid-adult life. Up to half of the cases have somatic mutations of KCNJ5 which encodes a potassium channel protein.

Pateints with primary hyperadlosteronism primarily present with hypertension and hypokalemia. The diagnosis of primary hyperaldosteronism is confirmed by elevated ratios of plasma aldosterone concentration to plasma renin activity.

Aldosterone-producing adenomas show the presence of eosinophilic, laminated cytoplasmic inclusions, known as spironolactone bodies. These spironolactone bodies are found after treatment with the antihypertensive drug spironolactone.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old child with a history of repeated, multiple, long bone fractures is diagnosed with osteogenesis imperfecta. Which of the following structures contains the type of collagen that is defective in this disease?
  1. Tendon
  2. Basement membrane
  3. Elastic cartilage
  4. Skin
  5. Sclera
questions.solution:
Osteogenesis imperfecta is a connective tissue disorder that occurs due to abnormal type 1 collagen production. Type 1 collagen is also present in the skin, tendons, and Sclera (1, 4, 5) apart from bones.

Remember:

  • Type I collagen is seen in the bone, dermis, tendon, ligaments, fibrocartilage, and sclera of the eyeball.
  • Type II collagen is seen in hyaline and elastic cartilage (Option 3) and the vitreous body of the eye. 
  • Type III collagen is seen in reticulin fibers, smooth muscle, endoneurium, arteries, uterus, kidney, spleen, and liver.
  • Type IV collagen is seen in epithelial and endothelial basal laminae and basement membranes. (Option 2)

questions.text:
The below statements describe the steps occurring during the skeletal muscle contraction. What is the correct sequence of these events?
  1. Binding of calcium to the troponin and tropomyosin complex
  2. Detachment of head from actin
  3. Release of active sites in actin and binding of myosin with actin
  4. Release of ADP and phosphate from the myosin head
  5. Cleaving of ATP to ADP and phosphate by myosin head
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of contraction is 5, 1, 3, 4, 2.

Chemical Events during Muscle Contraction

  • Before contraction begins, the heads of the cross-bridges bind with ATP. The myosin head has ATPase activity which cleaves ATP to form ADP and phosphate. These products remain attached to the head in a "cocked" position.
  • When the troponin-tropomyosin complex binds with calcium ions, active sites on the actin filament are uncovered and the myosin heads then bind with these sites. 
  • The bond between the head of the cross-bridge and the active site of the actin causes a conformational change in the head and the power stroke occurs. The energy to the power stroke is derived from the energy which was stored like a cocked spring due to the cleavage of ATP in step 1.
  • Once the head of the cross-bridge tilts, the ADP and phosphate ions that were previously attached to the head are released and a new ATP molecule binds in that place, and the myosin head is "re-cocked".
  • The binding of the new ATP molecule causes detachment of the head of the myosin from the actin. This cycle is then repeated.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text:
Which of the following are AIDS-defining illnesses?
  1. Primary brain lymphoma
  2. Toxoplasmosis of brain
  3. Oral candidiasis
  4. Wasting syndrome
  5. Invasive aspergillosis
questions.solution:
Out of the given conditions, primary brain lymphoma, toxoplasmosis of the brain, and wasting syndrome are considered AIDS-defining illnesses. 

While candidiasis of the respiratory tract (trachea, bronchi, and lungs) and esophagus is considered to be an AIDS-defining illness, oral candidiasis (oral thrush) is not AIDS-defining. Similarly, invasive aspergillosis is not seen in patients with AIDS unless there is concomitant neutropenia or glucocorticoid administration.

Generalized wasting is also an AIDS-defining condition. It is defined as involuntary weight loss of >10% body weight with fever and chronic diarrhea lasting >30 days without any other cause. Severe muscle wasting with myofiber degeneration is seen in this condition. The most severe form of neurocognitive disorder associated with HIV, HIV-associated dementia, is also considered to be an AIDS-defining condition.

Related Pearl: AIDS-defining opportunistic infections and neoplasm

Infections:

  • Protozoal and helminthic infections-
    • Cryptosporidiosis or Isosporiasis (cystoisosporiasis) - Chronic intestinal
    • Toxoplasmosis (pneumonia or CNS infection)
  • Fungal infections-
    • Candidiasis (esophageal, tracheal, or pulmonary)
    • Cryptococcosis (CNS infection)
    • Coccidioidomycosis (disseminated)
    • Pneumocystosis (pneumonia or disseminated infection)
    • Histoplasmosis (disseminated)
  • Bacterial infections-
    • Mycobacteriosis (“atypical,” e.g., Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare) disseminated or extrapulmonary
    • Mycobacterium tuberculosis (pulmonary or extrapulmonary)
    • Nocardiosis (pneumonia, meningitis, disseminated)
    • Salmonella infections, disseminated
  • Viral infections-
    • Cytomegalovirus (pulmonary, intestinal, retinitis, or CNS infections)
    • Herpes simplex virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Varicella-zoster virus (localized or disseminated infection)
    • Progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy

Neoplasms:

  • Kaposi sarcoma
  • Primary lymphoma of brain
  • Invasive cancer of uterine cervix

questions.text: What is the approximate blood loss in a patient with an increased pulse pressure?
questions.solution:
Increased pulse pressure can be seen in Class I hemorrhage, where the blood loss is usually less than 15% of blood volume.

The physiological effects of hemorrhage are divided into four classes, based on clinical signs, which are useful for estimating the percentage of acute blood loss.

Class I hemorrhage is characterized by <15% blood volume loss. The clinical symptoms of volume loss with class I hemorrhage are minimal.

Only in class I, pulse pressure is either increased or normal. In all other classes, it is decreased.

Related Pearl: Classification of hemorrhagic shock

Parameters Class I Class II Class III Class IV
Blood loss in % <15 15–30 30–40 >40
Pulse rate <100 100–120 120–140 >140
Blood pressure Normal Normal Decreased Greatly decreased
Pulse pressure Normal or increased Decreased Decreased Decreased
Respiratory rate 14–20 20–30 30–40 >35
Mental status Slightly anxious Mildly anxious Anxious, confused Confused, lethargic
Urine output (mL/hr) >30 20–30 5–15 Minimal

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient is diagnosed to have bilateral sensorineural hearing loss. He struggles to hear and understand speech despite appropriately fit hearing aids. The ENT specialist decided that a cochlear implant would be the best treatment for this patient. What is the site in which the electrode is placed?
questions.solution:
The electrode of a cochlear implant is placed in the scala tympani.

A cochlear implant is an electronic device that replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve. In cochlear implant surgery, the electrode array is placed within the scala tympani of the cochlea. Thus, an intact vestibulocochlear (CN VIII) nerve and the higher auditory pathway a prerequisites for cochlear implant surgery.

It is indicated in severe to profound sensorineural hearing loss and in those who cannot benefit from hearing aids.

Note:

The auditory brainstem implant is placed in the lateral recess of the 4th ventricle. 

Related Pearl: Cochlear implant

A cochlear implant replaces the organ of Corti i.e. when hair cells of the organ of Corti are severely damaged these implants bypass it and directly stimulate the auditory nerve.

Indication: Bilateral severe sensorineural hearing loss i.e. > 70 dB.

Components:

Preoperative investigation: Complete audiological evaluation and HRCT and MRI (to detect the structure of cochlea, cochlear nerve and CNS abnormalities).

Surgical approach: Two surgical techniques to approach the cochlea for implantation are the facial recess approach (via facial recess) and the pericanal technique (via EAC).

Postoperatively: Activation of the device after 3-4 weeks and evaluation is by HRCT (MRI is contraindicated).

Contraindications:

  • Absence of cochlea (Michel aplasia)
  • Deafness due to absent cochlear nerve, lesions of cochlear nerve or lesions of the central auditory pathway

questions.text: A 40-year-old lady came from the UK after a long flight. She suffered from breathing difficulty and her oxygen saturation was measured to be low. She has a past history of deep vein thrombosis. Her CT scan was done as shown below. Which of the following is true regarding her V/Q ratio?
questions.solution:
The given patient with a classical history of dyspnea and CT thorax showing a saddle embolus (red arrows) in the pulmonary artery. The V/Q ratio will be infinity.

V/Q ratio is the ratio of pulmonary ventilation (V) and Pulmonary blood flow or perfusion (Q). The normal V/Q ratio is 0.8 for the whole lungs at rest.

In this case, as the blood flow to the lung will be impeded due to embolus, the perfusion will become zero or very low. As a result of a decrease in the denominator of V/Q, the ratio will become infinity.

In contrast to this, Whenever the V/Q is below normal, there is inadequate ventilation to provide the O2 needed to fully oxygenate the blood flowing through the alveolar capillaries (i.e. alveolar Po2 is low). Therefore, a certain fraction of the venous blood flowing through the pulmonary capillaries does not become oxygenated.

In either case, the blood will not be saturated with oxygen as a result of either wasted ventilation or wasted perfusion.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman with diabetes and a BMI of 46 kg/m2 undergoes the following laparoscopic procedure as shown in the image below. On the second postoperative day, she develops a fever and tachycardia, and her CBC report shows leucocytosis. What is the next best step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of fever, tachycardia, and leucocytosis in a postoperative patient of LSG (Laparoscopic sleeve gastrectomy) should raise suspicion for leak along the gastric staple line. The next best step in the management of this patient is to perform a contrast-enhanced CT to confirm the diagnosis. 

Leaks following LSG most commonly occur in the proximal third of the stomach, close to the angle of His. Early leaks are due to tissue trauma and staple misfire, and late leaks are usually due to ischemia and high intragastric pressure.

Management of the leak involves providing nutritional support to the patient and adequate drainage. Once the leak is diagnosed, the patient should be kept nil per oral. Total parenteral nutrition and antibiotic therapy should be started in the patient. Drainage can be done either by CT-guided percutaneous catheter placement, endoscopic stenting, or operative procedures.

Note:

Since the leaks following LSG are often difficult to treat, they are called the Achilles heel of the operation.

Sleeve gastrectomy is the most commonly performed bariatric surgery in recent years. It has become the most common primary procedure for bariatric surgery.

A vertical sleeve is created, resecting most of the greater curvature
↓ 
Restriction of stomach capacity
↓ 
Early satiety
↓ 
Reduced consumption of food
↓ 
Weight loss

Advantages of sleeve gastrectomy:

  • Less challenging procedure
  • Preservation of pylorus (avoids gastric dumping)
  • No need for serial adjustments (as seen with gastric banding)
  • Reduction in internal hernias (as seen with Roux-en-Y gastric bypass)  

Complications of sleeve gastrectomy:

  • Bleed from the staple line
  • Leakage from staple line (close to the angle of His)

The image attached below shows the various bariatric surgical procedures commonly performed.
