questions.text: Which of the following drugs blocks the binding of gp120 HIV protein to the CCR5 receptor?
questions.solution:
Maraviroc blocks HIV envelope protein gp120 from binding to the CCR5 receptor. 

During the entry of the HIV virus into the host cell, gp120 anchors the virion to the host cell by binding to CD4. Further, gp120 binds to CCR5 chemokine receptors to stabilize the entire complex. Gp41 then mediates the fusion of the viral membrane with the cell membrane of the target cell. Maraviroc is an entry inhibitor that is used for the treatment of HIV. Maraviroc binds to CCR5 receptors and prevents viral entry into the cell. 

Enfuvirtide (option A) is another entry inhibitor that binds to certain domains of gp41 HIV protein and prevents membrane fusion and viral entry into the cell. It is the only antiretroviral drug that is given parenterally (subcutaneous or intravenous). 

Lopinavir (option C) is a protease inhibitor. This class of drugs inhibits the viral protease that is essential for conversion of the inactive protein precursors into functional proteins.

Raltegravir (option D) is an integrase inhibitor. It prevents the formation of covalent bond — and thus the integration — of the HIV DNA and the host cell DNA.

Related Pearl: Classification of antiretroviral drugs

CLASS DRUGS
Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Zidovudine, Stavudine, Lamivudine, Abacavir, Emtricitabine, Didanosine
Nucleotide Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Tenofovir
Non-nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors Nevirapine, Efavirenz, Delavirdine, Etravirine
Protease Inhibitors Saquinavir, Indinavir, Ritonavir, Nelfinavir, Lopinavir, Atazanavir, Tiprinavir, Darunavir
Entry Inhibitors Enfuvirtide, Maraviroc
Integrase Inhibitors Raltegravir, Elvitegravir, Dolutegravir

 

 

Related Pearl: NACO ART Guidelines- 2021

ART regimen

First-line for:

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who are age >10 years and body weight >30 kg with HIV-1, HIV-2, HIV 1&2 co-infection who have not received any ART 
  • Those with HIV-TB and HIV hepatitis co-infections
  • Pregnant women, pregnant women presenting in active labour and breastfeeding women

Abacavir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz
  • All PLHIV with abnormal serum creatinine values 
  • All PLHIV with bodyweight less <30 kg

Tenofovir + Lamivudine + Efavirenz /Lopinavir /Ritonavir
  • Women of childbearing age group who do not wish to take Dolutegravir
  • All PLHIV who were on the previous recommended regime (Tenofovir+Lamivudine+Efavirenz) to be counselled to switch to new regime. Continue older regime if response is good
  • Women in child-bearing age group to be counselled about Dolutegravir with opt-out option before switching to new regime

*PLHIV: People living with HIV

Related Pearl: 2021 NACO Guidelines on Post-exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) for HIV

Exposure Codes

  • EC1: Mild exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with small volumes/eyes or mucous membrane or subcutaneous injections following small-bore needles
  • EC2: Moderate exposure: mucous membrane/non-intact skin with large volumes or percutaneous superficial exposure with a solid needle

HIV Source Codes

  • SC 2- HIV +ve, symptomatic, CD count low, high viral load
  • SC unknown: HIV status unknown

Recommended PEP regimens

1) Adolescents and Adults (>10 years of age and >30 kg weight): Tenofovir 300 mg + Lamivudine 300 mg + Dolutegravir 50 mg

2) Children (>6 years of age and >20 kg weight): Zidovudine (dosage as per weight band) + Lamivudine (dosage as per weight band) + Dolutegravir 50 mg

  • PEP must be initiated ideally within 2 hours and certainly within 72 hours.
  • Duration of PEP: 28 days/4weeks

questions.text: A patient presented with swelling in the buccal cavity. A biopsy of the tissue was done and the histological image is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histological image shows both epithelial (left) and mesenchymal cell components (right), which is suggestive of pleomorphic adenoma.

Pleomorphic adenomas are the most common salivary gland neoplasms. The parotid gland is the most common site. The submandibular and minor salivary glands are the less common sites. They present as painless, slow-growing, mobile, discrete masses within the parotid or submandibular areas or in the buccal cavity.

Gross features- The tumors are rounded and well-demarcated. They are usually encapsulated, except in some areas such as the palate. The cut surface is gray-white with myxoid and blue translucent areas of the chondroid (cartilage-like) stroma.

Microscopic features consist of:

  • The epithelial elements- They resemble ductal cells or myoepithelial cells. They are arranged as ducts, acini, irregular tubules, strands, or sheets of cells.
  • Mesenchymal elements consisting of loose myxoid and hyaline tissue containing islands of cartilage and, rarely, foci of bone.

Other options: 

Option A - Oncocytomas arise from the kidneys. They are epithelial neoplasms that are composed of large eosinophilic cells with small, round, benign-appearing nuclei with large nucleoli. 

 

Option B - Ductal papillomas arise from the ductal epithelium of the breast. They have multiple branching fibrovascular cores with epithelial hyperplasia and apocrine metaplasia. The following image shows the histological appearance of ductal papilloma. 

 

Option D - Warthin tumors are benign neoplasms of the parotid gland. They appear as round to oval encapsulated masses. Histologically, they have a dense lymphoid stroma with germinal centers, the spaces are narrowed by polypoid projections of lymphoepithelial elements. The upper later has palisading columnar cells and the lower layer has cuboidal to polygonal cells. The following image shows a Warthin tumor. 

Related Pearl: Salivary gland tumors and their frequency

  • Most (90%) of the minor salivary gland tumors are malignant, whereas parotid gland tumors (90%) are benign.
  • Pleomorphic adenoma is the most common tumor of the parotid.  It is a benign tumor.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is not associated with elevated brain natriuretic peptide (BNP)?
questions.solution:
Out of the given conditions, the elevation of BNP is not seen in asthma.

Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) are stored in the atrial and the ventricular myocytes respectively. They are released from these cells when there is distension of the respective chambers because of fluid overload. These peptides cause the excretion of sodium and water by preventing their reabsorption in the renal tubules, and by inhibiting the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). They also cause vasodilation of the systemic arteries.

ANP and BNP thus oppose sodium and water retention in hypervolemic states. However, their actions are not sufficient to prevent edema. Elevated levels of ANP and BNP will be seen in any case when there is fluid overload, such as heart failure (option D) and cirrhosis with ascites (option C).

COPD is characterized by the destruction of the alveolar septa and airway inflammation. Improper gas exchange causes pulmonary vasoconstriction, and over a period of time, there is development of pulmonary hypertension. The right ventricle now has to pump against increased resistance. This leads to decompensation and eventually right heart failure, termed cor pulmonale. Levels of BNP correlate with the severity of right heart dysfunction. 

Other conditions that might be associated with elevated BNP:

  • Myocarditis and cardiomyopathy
  • Valvular heart disease
  • Acute pulmonary embolism (due to right heart failure)
  • Renal insufficiency
  • Hyperaldosteronism

Related Pearl: Cardiac Biomarkers

  Time to initial elevation Mean time to peak elevation Time to return to normal range
Myoglobin 1- 4 h 12 h 24 h
CK-MB 4-8 h 24 h 48-72 h
cTnI 3-12 h 24 h 7-10 d
cTnT 3-12 h 12h – 2d 7-10 d 

CK-MB: Creatine kinase-MB; CTnI: Cardiac-specific troponin I; CTnT: Cardiac-specific troponin T

questions.text: The image given below depicts the lifecycle of ________
questions.solution:
The given lifecycle is that of Paragonimus westermani.

Paragonimus westermani (lung fluke - trematode) infection is acquired by consuming freshwater crab/ crayfish containing metacercariae. It causes pulmonary symptoms similar to pulmonary tuberculosis (coughing and hemoptysis).

  • Definitive host: Men, cats, tigers, leopards, foxes, dogs, pigs, beavers, and domestic animals.
  • First intermediate host: Freshwater snail.
  • Second intermediate host: Freshwater crab or crayfish.

The adult worms live in the respiratory tract of the definitive host in cystic spaces surrounded by a fibrous capsule formed by the host tissues. Unembryonated eggs escape into the bronchi and are coughed up and voided in sputum or swallowed and passed in feces.

Praziquantel (25 mg/kg TDS for 1–2 days) is the drug of choice.

Other options:

Option B: Ascaris lumbricoides is an intestinal nematode that causes ascariasis. Infection occurs through food or water contaminated with nightsoil or human feces having eggs of Ascaris that contain the infective rhabditiform larva. 

Man is the only natural host. There is no intermediate host.

Adult worms can be occasionally detected in the stool or sputum of the patient. A definitive diagnosis is made by demonstration of eggs in feces. Fertilized eggs are always bile stained. 

Effective and safe drugs for the treatment of ascariasis are Pyrantel pamoate 11 mg/kg once, Albendazole 400 mg once, Mebendazole 100 mg twice daily for 3 days, Ivermectin 150-200 mcg/kg once.

The image below shows the life cycle of Ascaris lumbricoides: 

Option C: Fasciola hepatica is a liver fluke (trematode) that resides in the liver and the lumen of the biliary passages and causes fascioliasis. It mainly affects sheep and other domestic animals. Infection in sheep and man is acquired by ingestion of metacercariae encysted on aquatic vegetation.

  • Definitive host: Sheep, goat, cattle, and man.
  • Intermediate host: Snails of the genus Lymnaea and Succinea. Encystment occurs on aquatic plants, which act as the second intermediate host.

Oral triclabendazole (10 mg/kg once) is the treatment of choice.

Life cycle of Fasciola hepatica:

Option D: Brugia malayi is a nematode that also causes filariasis in man. The intermediate hosts of Brugia are vectors of the genera Mansonia, Anopheles, and Aedes. In India, the main vectors are Mansonia annulifera and Mansonia uniformis.

Diethylcarbamazine is found to reduce the microfilarial count.

Life cycle of Brugia malayi:

questions.text: A child presents with severe neurological symptoms,  polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness, and cerebellar ataxia. His symptoms regress with restricted dietary intake of phytanic acid. What can be the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Refsum’s disease which occurs due to a defect in the alpha oxidation of fatty acids.

Refsum’s disease: It is a neurologic disorder that results from the defect in alpha oxidation of phytanic acid in the peroxisome. The enzyme phytanoyl CoA oxidase(Alpha hydroxylase) is defective. Accumulation of phytanic acid will affect membrane function, protein prenylation, and gene expression.

The patient presents with severe neurological symptoms, polyneuropathy, retinitis pigmentosa, nerve deafness, and cerebellar ataxia. Management includes restricted dietary intake of phytanic acid. Sources of phytanic acid such as dairy products, meat, and green leafy vegetables should be avoided.

Other options:

Option B: Usher syndrome - Sensorineural deafness + Retinitis pigmentosa (but symptoms are not affected by restricting phytanic acid)

Option C: Zellweger Syndrome  - also known as Cerebrohepatorenal syndrome 

Caused by mutations in the PEX family of genes -also called peroxins involved in Peroxisome Biogenesis /Peroxisomal enzymes themselves 
Biochemical findings :

    • Accumulation of very-long-chain fatty acids
    • abnormalities of the synthesis of bile acids
    • marked reduction of plasmalogens

Option D: Adrenoleukodystrophy is an X-linked recessive disorder of β-oxidation of fatty acids. There is an accumulation of very large chain fatty acids in the adrenal glands, the white matter of the brain, and the testes. It is a progressive disease that can lead to adrenal gland crisis, coma, and death.

questions.text:
Which of the following are major criteria to diagnose infective endocarditis?
  1. Phase I IgG antibody titer for Coxiella >1:800
  2. Single positive blood culture for coagulase-negative Staphylococci
  3. New onset valvular regurgitation
  4. IV drug abuse
  5. Janeway lesions
questions.solution:
Phase I IgG antibody titer >1:800 for Coxiella and new onset valvular regurgitation are major criteria in the Modified Duke criteria for infective endocarditis.

Single positive blood culture for coagulase-negative Staphylococci (statement 2) is likely to be due to contamination of the blood culture sample during sample collection. One set of samples taken for infective endocarditis consists of 2 bottles of blood culture (one for aerobic and one for anaerobic culture). Three such sets are taken from different venipuncture sites over 1-2 hours. At least two of these cultures have to be positive for the positive blood culture criteria to be considered positive in the Duke criteria. Antibody titers to Coxiella are included in the major criteria because it is difficult to recover the organism by blood culture.

Predisposing factors such as IV drug abuse (statement 4) and certain congenital heart diseases and vascular phenomena such as Janeway lesions are included in the minor criteria. 

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text:
Arrange the following events in sequence as they occur during the activation of a G-protein coupled receptor.
  1. Binding of ligand
  2. Hydrolysis of GTP
  3. GDP release
  4. Stimulation of adenylyl cyclase
questions.solution:
In the absence of any ligand binding to the G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs), the receptor and the trimer of α, β and γ proteins form a complex. The α subunit is bound to GDP. This resting state of the GPCR is shown below: 

 

The events that occur during the activation of GPCR are as follows:

  1. Binding of ligand.
  2. The receptor and the α subunit undergo a conformational change, leading to the release of GDP, binding of GTP, and the dissociation of the complex.
  3. The activated GTP-bound α subunit and the βγ dimer bring about the downstream changes by activating or inhibiting different effectors such as adenylyl cyclase and phospholipase C.
  4. The system is returned to the resting state by hydrolysis of GTP on the α subunit.

Related Pearl: Membrane receptors and their mechanisms

1. G protein coupled receptor(GPCR)

   Effect 2nd messenger  Action
Gs Activates adenylate cyclase Stimulation of cAMP production Activates protein kinase A
Gi Inhibits adenylate cyclase Inhibition of cAMP production -
Gq Activates phospholipase C Liberate DAG and IP3 which mobilize Ca2+ from endoplasmic reticulum Activates protein kinase C


2. Guanylyl cyclase receptor

Effector 2nd messenger
Guanylyl cyclase Stimulation of cGMP production


3. Receptor tyrosine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger

4. Cytokine receptor tyrosine kinase

Effector 2nd messenger

Effector 2nd messenger
Serine kinase Smads

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with burns injury. His face and neck are covered with burns along with both the arms and sides of the chest. He requires both crystalloids and colloid resuscitation. Which of the following will you not follow while resuscitating the patient in the first 24 hours?

choices.text: Human albumin solution (HAS) is  commonly used
Muir and Barclay formula is used for calculation of colloids
Urine output should be between 0.5 to 1 ml/kg body wt/hour
Proteins should be given within the first 12 hours of burn

questions.solution:
Proteins should be given after the first 12 hours of burn because proteins leak out of the cells due to intravascular fluid shifts in the first 12 hours of burn. 

Human albumin solution (HAS) is commonly used for colloid resuscitation.

The most common colloid-based formula is the Muir and Barclay formula. It is calculated as -0.5 × percentage body surface area burnt × weight = one portion.

Urine output is a commonly used parameter to monitor resuscitation and it should be between 0.5 to 1 ml/kg body weight per hour.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text:
A 72-year-old male patient presents with a two-month history of abdominal pain.

It is associated with constipation and bloating. He has lost 10 kg weight over this period of time. His vitals are: temperature 98.6°F, HR 92 bpm, and BP 118/70 mmHg. Laboratory investigations show: hemoglobin 8g/dL and MCV 60 fL. His stools are positive for fecal occult blood. A colonoscopy was done and it showed a growth at the hepatic flexure of the colon. CECT showed lymph node involvement and pulmonary metastasis.

What is the most appropriate management for this patient?

choices.text: Right hemicolectomy + chemotherapy + resection of pulmonary metastases

questions.solution:
The most appropriate management for this patient is right hemicolectomy + chemotherapy + resection of pulmonary metastases.

Procedures performed for tumors of the colon are summarized below:

Tumor location Procedure of choice
Cecum/Ascending colon 

Right hemicolectomy 

  • Ligation and division of the ileocolic, right colic, and right branch of the middle colic vessels 
  • Resection of cecum + approx 10 cm of the terminal ileum with ileocecal junction + ascending colon + hepatic flexure 
Hepatic flexure/Transverse colon

Extended right hemicolectomy

  • Ligation and division of the ileocolic, right colic, and base of middle colic vessels 
  • Resection of the cecum + approx 10 cm of the terminal ileum with ileocecal junction + ascending colon + hepatic flexure + proximal transverse colon (distal transverse colon and splenic flexure are also sometimes removed)
Splenic flexure/ Descending colon

Left hemicolectomy 

  • Ligation and division of the left branch of the middle colic vessels, the left colic vessel, and the first branches of the sigmoid vessels 
  • Resection of the transverse colon (left MCA territory) + Splenic flexure + Descending colon up to the sigmoid colon
Sigmoid colon Sigmoid colectomy, or LAR (Low anterior resection)
  • Ligation and division of the sigmoid branches of the inferior mesenteric artery.
  • Removal of the entire sigmoid colon and rectum

 

Chemotherapy following surgical treatment is given in patients with node-positive disease. Hepatic and pulmonary metastases can be resected, and have been shown to improve the survival of patients.

questions.text:
Match the following types of fever with their respective temperature variations.
Type of fever Temperature variation
1. Persistent A. Temperature >38°C on multiple occasions; no localizing signs
2. Remittent B. Temperature elevated multiple times a day; touches baseline
3. Intermittent C. Temperature fluctuates <1°C during a day; always above baseline
4. PUO D. Temperature fluctuates >2°C during a day; always above baseline
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Type of fever Temperature variation
1. Persistent C. Temperature fluctuates <1°C during a day; always above baseline
2. Remittent D. Temperature fluctuates >2°C during a day; always above baseline
3. Intermittent B. Temperature elevated multiple times a day; touches baseline
4. PUO A. Temperature >38°C on multiple occasions; no localizing signs

 

A temperature of >99.9°F or >37.7°C defines a fever. Body temperature also has a diurnal and seasonal variation, being higher in the winters and late afternoons, and lower in the summers and mornings. Rectal temperature measurements are higher than the oral readings and the unadjusted tympanic membrane temperature measurements. 

While monitoring the temperature readings in in-patients at the hospital, the following types of patterns can be noticed:

  • Persistent fever is the one where the temperature remains above the baseline throughout the day and it doesn't fluctuate by >1°C during this time.
  • Remittent fever is the one where the temperature remains above the baseline throughout the day, but it fluctuates by >2°C during this time.
  • Intermittent/spiking fever is one where the temperature is above the baseline only on a few occasions throughout the day, but is normal at other times. 

There is an entity known as pyrexia of unknown origin (PUO). It has been defined as a temperature >38°C (101°F) on two occasions but without a certain diagnosis despite 1 week of inpatient evaluation. There are no localizing signs present to point to the origin of the fever. In developing countries, infections (such as tuberculosis) remain the most prominent cause of PUO. Other causes include autoimmune diseases (such as systemic lupus erythematosus, rheumatoid arthritis, vasculitis) and hematological and solid organ malignancies.

questions.text: A patient was referred to the ICTC for HIV screening. He turned out to be positive by HIV spot test. A confirmation regarding the type of HIV was done using immunoblot for ART selection. Presence of which of the following proteins differentiates HIV2 compared to HIV1?
questions.solution:
Presence of gp36 points towards a diagnosis of HIV2.

HIV2 is genetically similar to HIV1 by only 40%. Moreover, it is intrinsically resistant to NNRTI, hence it should be differentiated from HIV1 for optimum ART prescription. Its prevalence is low in India (less than 3%), however widespread studies are needed. Clinically, HIV2 is slower to progress than HIV1

Western blot (WB) detects specific antibodies against multiple proteins of all 3 major HIV genes - gag, pol, and env. WB has a high specificity and is therefore used as a confirmatory test.

Note: In India, NACO provides western blot confirmatory testing only to resolve indeterminate results on previous serological testing and not for routine confirmation after a positive result on screening tests. Drawbacks of WB include low rates of detection during acute HIV infection and misclassification of HIV-2 infection.

Apart from Western blot, Line immunoassays (LIA) and PCR to detect vpu or vpx genes, in HIV1 and HIV2 respectively can be carried out for confirmation.

questions.text: The differential diagnosis for the following clinical findings should include all except:
questions.solution:
The image shows velvety dark patches in axilla suggestive of acanthosis nigricans. Acanthosis nigricans is not seen in Goodpasture’s syndrome.

Acanthosis nigricans is an asymptomatic symmetrical darkening of the skin of intertriginous areas, in particular the axillae, groins, submammary folds, and neck.

Disorders associated with acanthosis nigricans:

  • Acromegaly and gigantism
  • Dermatomyositis
  • Diabetes
  • Hashimoto thyroiditis
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Phenylketonuria
  • Polycystic ovary syndrome
  • Systemic sclerosis
  • Wilson syndrome
  • Gastric cancer
  • Gallbladder and bile duct cancer
  • Bladder cancer
  • Breast cancer
  • Gynecological cancer

questions.text: Which of the following is an intermediate filament?
questions.solution:
Cytokeratin is an intermediate filament. There are three major classes of cytoskeletal proteins, which include intermediate filaments, microfilaments, and microtubules.

Intermediate filaments:

These rope-like intermediate filament fibers are found predominantly in a polymerized form within cells and do not actively reorganize like actin and microtubules. They impart tensile strength and allow cells to bear mechanical stress. They are:

  • Lamin A, B, and C
  • Vimentin
  • Desmin
  • Neurofilament
  • Glial fibrillary acidic protein
  • Cytokeratins

Microtubules:

These are formed by non-covalent polymerization of a dimer of two globular proteins, alpha-tubulin, and beta-tubulin.  The microtubules in most cells extend outward from a microtubule-organizing center (MTOC), in which the minus ends of microtubules are anchored.

Actin microfilaments:

These fibrils formed from the globular protein actin (G-actin) noncovalently polymerize into long filaments (F-actin) that intertwine to form double-stranded helices.

Clinical significance: Each intermediate filament is a tumor marker for well-differentiated tumors, arising from the corresponding site of distribution.

Other option:

Laminins are high molecular weight proteins of the extracellular matrix. They form the major component of the basal lamina.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication for the surgery in which the following instrument is used?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a myringotome and myringotomy/tympanostomy is done by a sharp myringotome. An intratympanic glomus tumor is a contraindication for myringotomy.

Myringotomy refers to the incision made on the tympanic membrane with the purpose to drain suppurative or nonsuppurative effusion of the middle ear or to provide aeration in case of a malfunctioning eustachian tube.

Indications of myringotomy:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media and its complications
  • Recurrent acute otitis media
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the Eustachian tube)
  • Atelectatic ear (treated along with grommet insertion)

Contraindication of myringotomy: It is contraindicated in suspected cases of intratympanic glomus tumor, as it can cause profuse bleeding in such patients.

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: An 8 month-old baby is brought to the pediatric clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss and failure to thrive. On clinical examination, there is inflammation of the skin around the mouth and the perianal region as shown in the image. What is the preferred drug to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
A child with symptoms of diarrhea, hair loss, and eczematous rash typically in the perioral and perineal region is characteristic of acrodermatitis enteropathica. It is due to zinc deficiency. Oral zinc therapy is the preferred drug.

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a mutation in the intestinal zinc transporter gene, SLC39A4, found on chromosome 8q24.3, which leads to zinc deficiency.

Children commonly present with symmetrical, eczematous plaques that become vesicular, bullous, pustular, or erosive with characteristic crusting at the edges. The perioral eruption usually spares the upper lip.

Diagnosis by clinical features and low plasma zinc levels. Oral zinc therapy is the treatment of choice (3 mg/kg/24 h). 

Mnemonic- DEAL for Acrodermatitis enteropathica:

D – Diarrhoea

E – Eczematous dermatitis

A - Alopecia

L – Lethargy

questions.text:
Match the following
1. Barrett's esophagus a. Perl's Prussian blue
2. Whipple's disease b. Masson–Fontana stain
3. Hemochromatosis c. Alcian blue
4. Nevus d. PAS stain
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1- c, 2- d, 3- a, 4- b.

1. Barrett's esophagus c. Alcian blue
2. Whipple's disease d. PAS stain
3. Hemochromatosis a. Perl's Prussian blue
4. Nevus b. Masson–Fontana stain
 

Goblet cells are diagnostic of Barrett esophagus and have distinct mucous vacuoles. These vacuoles with mucin stain pale blue with Alcian blue and give it a wine goblet appearance.

Whipple's disease has an accumulation of foamy macrophages containing Periodic acid Schiff stain (PAS)-positive granules. PAS stain is used for the detection of glycogen in tissues such as the liver, skeletal muscle, etc., and also in tumor cells.

The foamy macrophages in Whipple's disease stain positive with periodic acid–Schiff (PAS) are shown below.

Perl's Prussian blue stain is used in histopathological studies to detect the presence of iron in the specimen. Iron is stained blue with this stain. It is used in hereditary hemochromatosis to stain liver tissue, which shows hepatocellular iron. It also stains the iron-laden mitochondria of ring sideroblasts seen in lead toxicity and myelodysplastic syndrome.

The following image shows the blue staining of iron (in the form of hemosiderin) deposited in hepatocytes:

The stain used for melanin in the below image is the Masson Fontana stain. It may be used in a case of nevus to detect melanin.

questions.text:
Arrange the fibers passing through the internal capsule in order through the anterior limb, genu, posterior limb, and the retro-lenticular parts respectively.
  1. Frontopontine fibers
  2. Corticospinal tract
  3. Occipitopontine fibers
  4. Corticonuclear tract
questions.solution:
The fibers passing through the internal capsule in order from the anterior limb towards the retro-lenticular part are:

1. Frontopontine fibers (anterior limb)
4. Corticonuclear tract (genu)
2. Corticospinal tract (posterior limb)
3. Occipitopontine fibers (retrolenticular part)

The internal capsule is a component of the white matter of the brain. They contain projection fibers. It can be divided into the following parts:

  • anterior limb
  • genu
  • posterior limb
  • retrolenticular/ retrolentiform portion
  • sublenticular/ sublentiform portion

The anterior limb of the internal capsule carries the fronto-pontine fibers, while the genu carries the corticonuclear tract. 

The posterior limb of the internal capsule carries cortico-spinal motor fibers in the anterior part. The posterior part of the posterior limb of the internal capsule carries sensory fibers.

The retrolenticular part contains the parietopontine, occipitopontine and occipitotectal fibres and the sublenticular part contains temporopontine and some parietopontine fibres.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: Nifedipine is indicated in the management of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction.

Reason: Nifedipine improves LV filling by prolonging the diastolic filling period and reduces obstruction of the outflow tract due to a negative inotropic effect

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true and reason is false
Both assertion and reason are false

questions.solution:
Both assertion and reason are false. 

Nifedipine is contraindicated in hypertrophic cardiomyopathy(HCM) with left ventricular outflow tract obstruction (LVOT). Dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers (nifedipine) cause vasodilation and are avoided in such patients as they can produce a fall in peripheral resistance, thus increasing LVOT obstruction. 

Hypertrophic cardiomyopathy:

Clinical features - While most patients are asymptomatic, some may develop the following symptoms: dyspnea on exertion, fatigue, atypical or anginal chest pain, presyncope and syncope, and palpitation.

HCM is associated with a mid-systolic murmur with the following features:

  • Loudest along the left sternal border
  • Increases in intensity by maneuvers that result in increasing degrees of outflow tract obstruction:
    • Reduction in preload or afterload: Valsalva, standing, vasodilators
    • Increased contractility: inotropic stimulation  
  • Decreases in intensity when there is
    • Increase in preload: squatting, passive leg raising, volume administration
    • Increase in afterload: squatting, vasopressors
    • Reduced contractility: β-adrenoreceptor blockers

Diagnosis - 

  • ECG - findings include -
    • Prominent abnormal Q waves
    • P wave abnormalities 
    • Left axis deviation
    • Deeply inverted T waves 
  • Echocardiography -
    •  LV wall thickness ≥15 mm
    • Systolic anterior motion of the mitral valve
    • LVOT obstruction

Treatment -

  • Patients with LVOT obstruction - beta-blockers, non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blockers, and disopyramide may be used. Vasodilators and diuretics must be avoided in patients with LVOT obstruction.
  • Patients without LVOT obstruction with LVEF ≥50 percent - Initial monotherapy with either a beta-blocker or a non-dihydropyridine calcium channel blocker is started. Diuretics may be used as needed.

Related Pearl: Dynamic auscultation of murmurs

Bedside Manoeuvre Effect

Inspiration

(↑venous return to right atrium)
  • ↑ intensity of right-sided sounds

Handgrip

(↑afterload )
  • ↑ intensity of MR, AR, and VSD murmurs
  • ↓ hypertrophic cardiomyopathy and AS murmurs
  • MVP: delayed onset of click/murmur

Valsalva-Phase II, standing up

(↓ preload)
  • ↓ intensity of most murmurs (including AS)
  • ↑ intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • MVP: earlier onset of click /murmur

Rapid squatting

(↑venous return,↑preload,
↑ afterload)
  • ↓intensity of hypertrophic cardiomyopathy murmur
  • ↑ intensity of AS, MR, and VSD murmurs
  • MVP: later onset of click/murmur

questions.text:
Arrange the following events of normal labor in the sequence of their occurrence from earliest to latest:

1. Restitution
2. Delivery of the shoulders and trunk
3. Crowning
4. Engagement
5. External rotation
6. Internal rotation of occiput
7. Delivery of the head by extension
8. Flexion of the head
questions.solution:
The cardinal movements of labor in order are engagement-crowning-restitution-external rotation.

The specific cardinal movements of labor are:

  • Engagement is the mechanism by which the biparietal diameter (in occiput presentation) passes through the pelvic inlet.
  • Descent is a continuous process that is completed with the expulsion of the fetus.
  • Flexion of the head occurs as soon as the descending head meets resistance from the pelvic floor/pelvic walls/cervix.
  • Internal rotation is the mechanism by which the occiput gradually turns away from the transverse axis. Crowning occurs after internal rotation.
  • Crowning occurs when the vulval outlet is stretched by the maximum diameter of the head and there is non recession of the head after the contraction is over.
  • Extension occurs when the flexed head reaches the vulva.
  • Restitution is the passive movement of the head due to untwisting of the neck that occurred in internal rotation.
  • External rotation is the visible movement of the delivered head occurring due to internal rotation of the shoulders.
  • Expulsion is the process by which the anterior shoulder comes under the pubic symphysis to be delivered and is followed by the posterior shoulder and the rest of the fetal body.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the following procedure carried out in a neonate?

choices.text: 0.5 mg Vitamin K1 is administered for babies weighing <1000g by this method
1 mg Vitamin K1 is administered for babies weighing >1000g by this method
0.5ml Hepatitis B vaccine is administered by this method
Administration should be done on anteromedial aspect of thigh

questions.solution:
The procedure shown is the IM injection which is being carried out in the anterolateral aspect of the thigh. It should not be done on the anteromedial aspect of the thigh.

Administration of Vit. K1 and Hepatitis B vaccination are carried out using this method in the newborn. 0.5 mg Vitamin K1 is administered for babies weighing <1000g and 1 mg Vitamin K1 is administered for babies weighing >1000g

questions.text: A 23-year-old survivor of a terrorist attack that happened 2 weeks ago comes to the psychiatry OPD with complaints of persistent flashbacks about the incident. She has been unable to sleep properly and is avoiding going to crowded places. She is no longer interested in doing activities with her friends. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this patient is acute stress disorder, because the symptoms have been present for less than one month.

Post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD) and acute stress disorder both present with the same set of symptoms:

  • Intrusive symptoms such as recurrent nightmares and flashbacks of the event, psychological distress due to stimuli that are reminders of prior trauma
  • Avoidance of external reminders of trauma
  • Negative mood or cognition related to the trauma, such as diminished interest in activities and withdrawal
  • Altered level of arousal, such as sleep disturbances and hypervigilance

A diagnosis of PTSD is made if these symptoms present ≥1 month following the traumatic event. If these symptoms are present prior to 1 month, then a diagnosis of acute stress disorder is made.

The treatment modalities for PTSD and acute stress disorder include trauma-focused cognitive behavioral therapy, eye movement desensitization and reprocessing therapy (EMDR), and SSRIs. 

Adjustment disorder (option B) is diagnosed when the patient has emotional or behavioral changes following a stressor in his life. However, the distress is out of proportion to the stressor itself — that is, the feeling of distress is subjective.

Major depressive disorder (option C) presents with low mood, loss of interest in pleasurable activities, and decreased energy. Although this patient has a loss of interest in activities, the presence of hypervigilance symptoms and flashbacks following a traumatic event points towards a diagnosis of a stress-trauma related disorder.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of Trauma and Stress related disorder

 
PTSD
Adjustment disorder
Bereavement
Stressor
Extreme traumatic events like rape or accident
Financial/ Illness/ Relationship issues
Death of a loved one
Time
Symptoms
develop within 6 months and persist more than 1 month
Symptoms
develop within 3 months and resolve in 6 months if stressor eliminated
Symptoms develop within 2 months and resolve within 2 months
Symptoms
Flashbacks and nightmares
Mostly depressive and anxiety
Mostly depressive

questions.text: What is the embryological origin of the marked structure in the retroperitoneum?
questions.solution:
The marked structure is the uncinate process of the pancreas. It is embryologically derived from the ventral pancreatic bud.

Embryology of pancreas:  The pancreas develops from two buds, dorsal, and ventral, originating from the endodermal lining of the duodenum. When the duodenum rotates and becomes C-shaped, the ventral bud gets positioned immediately below and behind the dorsal bud. This is followed by the fusion of the parenchyma and the duct systems of the dorsal and ventral pancreatic buds.

Parenchyma of the pancreas:

  • Ventral pancreatic bud forms the lower part of the head and uncinate process
  • Dorsal pancreatic bud forms the upper part of the head, neck, body, and tail

Pancreatic ducts:

  • Main pancreatic duct (of Wirsung) is formed by the duct of ventral bud (proximal part),  oblique cross-communication between the 2 ducts (middle part), and the duct of dorsal bud (distal part).
  • Accessory pancreatic duct (of Santorini) is formed by the proximal part of the dorsal pancreatic duct.

questions.text:
Sequentially arrange the following renal injuries from least severe to most severe -
  1. Laceration of the pelvic ureteric junction 
  2. Subcapsular, non-expanding hematoma 
  3. Laceration up to renal medulla
  4. Injury confined to Gerota’s fascia
  5. Avulsion of renal hilum
questions.solution:
The correct sequence of renal injuries from least to most severe is 2-4-3-1-5.

  • Subcapsul, non-expanding hematoma (Least severe)
  • Injury confined to Gerota’s fascia
  • Laceration up to renal medulla
  • Laceration of the pelvic ureteric junction
  • Avulsion of the renal hilum (Most severe)

Renal injuries are mostly seen as a result of blunt trauma. Kidneys are the second most common visceral organ to be injured due to blunt trauma after the spleen. 

The examination includes findings related to the location of impact, flank ecchymosis, and gross or microscopic hematuria. Close attention to the entry and exit points in penetrating injuries is also important to estimate the trajectory of the missile. 

Radiological investigations are indicated when there is gross haematuria, shock and microscopic haematuria, pediatric renal trauma, and penetrating injuries.

CECT is the investigation of choice. It assesses the extent of the injury, showing laceration, extravasation, surrounding haemorrhage, and vessel injury. It also shows non-renal injuries and effectively stages renal pedicle injuries. Arterial occlusion will manifest as rim enhancement of the normal renal contour. 

Blunt trauma is mostly treated conservatively. Most penetrating injuries require surgical renal exploration.

Absolute indications for surgical intervention in renal trauma are:

  • Massive haemorrhage
  • Renal pedicle avulsion (grade 5 injury)
  • Expanding, pulsatile, or uncontained retroperitoneal hematoma

Relative indications are:

  • Large laceration of the renal pelvis or avulsion of the ureteropelvic junction
  • Bowel or pancreatic injuries
  • Persistent urinary leakage, postinjury urinoma, or perinephric abscess 
  • Complete renal artery thrombosis of both kidneys 
  • Renal hypertension
The five grade-classification of renal injuries by "The Organ Injury Scaling system of the American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST)" is explained in the pearl given below. 

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Kidney Injury Scale

GRADE  

 INJURY DESCRIPTION
I

Contusion

Microscopic or gross hematuria, urologic studies normal
  Hematoma

Subcapsular, nonexpanding, without parenchymal laceration
II

Hematoma

Nonexpanding perirenal hematoma confined to renal retroperitoneum
  Laceration

 <1 cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex without urinary extravasation
III

Laceration 

>1 cm depth of renal cortex, without collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation
IV Laceration

Parenchymal laceration extending through the renal cortex, medulla, and collecting system
  Vascular

Main renal artery or vein injury, with contained hemorrhage
V Laceration Completely shattered kidney
  Laceration   Avulsion of renal hilum, which devascularizes kidney

questions.text: During the ophthalmology postings, you were asked to check for the primary, secondary, and tertiary actions produced by the extraocular muscle innervated by the trochlear nerve in a 50-year-old diabetic female. You would look for which of the following actions respectively?
questions.solution:
Trochlear nerve innervates superior oblique muscle. The primary, secondary, and tertiary actions produced by this muscle are Intorsion, Depression, and Abduction respectively.

questions.text: Bromocriptine can be used in the management of all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Bromocriptine cannot be used for the management of acute psychosis, since it is a D2 receptor agonist.

Acute psychotic disorder refers to the presence of psychotic symptoms such as delusions and hallucinations for a duration of less than one month. It is more commonly seen in patients with personality disorders and those who have had major psychological stress in life. It is a transient disorder. Treatment primarily consists of antipsychotic drugs. The first-generation antipsychotic drugs are D2 receptor antagonists while the second-generation drugs act by variable mechanisms, primarily being 5HT2 antagonism.

Bromocriptine is an ergot alkaloid that acts as an agonist primarily at the dopamine D2 receptors. The primary use of bromocriptine is in patients with prolactinomas (option A). It normalizes the serum prolactin levels and decreases the size of the tumor itself. 

Neuroleptic malignant syndrome (option B) occurs due to excessive D2 receptor antagonism by first-generation antipsychotic drugs. The patients present with muscle rigidity, fever, myoglobinuria, and renal failure. The management consists of dantrolene (skeletal muscle relaxant) and bromocriptine (D2 receptor agonist).

A formulation of bromocriptine is also approved for use in diabetes mellitus (option D) with modest effects on blood glucose levels.

Related Pearl: Factors affecting prolactin secretion

Increased Prolactin Secretion Decreased Prolactin Secretion
Sleep Dopamine
Stress L-Dopa
Strenuous exercise Apomorphine
Sexual intercourse in women Bromocriptine and related ergot derivatives
Pregnancy  
Nursing  
Breast stimulation in non-lactating women  
Estrogen  
Hypothyroidism  
TRH  
Opioids  
Phenothiazines, butyrophenones  

Atypical antipsychotics - Risperidone

  

Dopamine synthesis inhibitors - α-Methyldopa

  
 

H2 antagonists - Cimetidine, ranitidine

  

Imipramines - Amitriptyline, amoxapine

  

Serotonin reuptake inhibitors -Fluoxetine

  

Calcium channel blockers - Verapamil

  
 

Thioxanthenes

Metoclopramide

  

Catecholamine depletors - Reserpine

  

Related Pearl: Pharmacological treatment of psychosis

First-generation antipsychotics are generally not preferred due to the higher risk of extrapyramidal side effects/ tardive dyskinesia.

Second-generation antipsychotics are preferred drugs:

  • Risperidone
  • Olanzapine
  • Quetiapine
  • Aripiprazole
  • Ziprasidone
  • Paliperidone

Benzodiazepines can be added to treat associated agitation. It is the drug of choice for catatonia.

Special situations:

  • Emergency: Use a short-acting intramuscular agent such as haloperidol, fluphenazine, olanzapine, or ziprasidone.
  • Chronic compliance: Long-acting injectable is used.
  • Treatment resistance (2 failed trials): Consider Clozapine.
  • All meds ineffective: May consider ECT.

questions.solution:
When the fetus is in an attitude of partial extension, the most common presenting part is the brow.

Attitude Presenting part

questions.text: True statement about the phenomenon seen in the image below:

choices.text: The cells being engulfed is destroyed immediately
A cell engulfs the cell of same type
The cell being engulfed undergo division inside the host cell
The above condition helps in the destruction of dead cells

questions.solution:
The above image showing a cell within a cell is termed as emperipolesis.

Emperipolesis is a condition where living and intact state hematopoietic cells are seen in the cytoplasm of a host cell without any damage. Both of these cells remain viable without any physiological or morphological changes. The cells taken in are neutrophils, lymphocytes, and plasma cells. The host cells may be a megakaryocyte, monocyte, endothelial cell, fibroblast, or malignant cells. The engulfed cell is enclosed in a membrane-bound vacuole in the cytoplasm of the host cell. Internalized cells appear to continue living within the host cell for brief periods of time. Sometimes they even undergo division within the vacuole.

Phagocytosis differs from emperipolesis as the engulfed cells are dead or dying cells or other materials from the extracellular space  (Option A and D). Phagocytosis also uses the host cell cytoskeleton to form pseudopodia and engulf the dead material. 

Entosis is a phenomenon where a cell engulfs a cell of the same type (Option B). While cells that are internalized by this mechanism are initially viable, the majority of them undergo a non-apoptotic form of cell death.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correct about the myogenic autoregulation of renal blood flow (RBF) and glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?

choices.text: Increased movement of calcium into cells
Increases RBF when arterial pressure rises
Prevents excessive stretch of renal vessels

questions.solution:
The myogenic mechanism of autoregulation helps to prevent excessive rises in renal blood flow and glomerular filtration rate when the arterial pres­sure increases.

The stretch of the vascular wall allows increased movement of calcium ions into the cells from the extracellular fluid. This causes vessel wall contraction preventing excessive stretch of the vessel and raising vascular resistance. This prevents increases in renal blood flow and GFR when the arterial pres­sure increases.

This mechanism is important in protect­ing the kidney from hypertension­-induced injuries. When there is a sudden increase in blood pressure, the myo­genic constrictor response in the afferent arterioles occurs within seconds, reducing the transmission of excessively high arterial pressure to the glomerular capillaries.

questions.text: The instrument shown in the image below is used to ____________
questions.solution:
The image shows a pachymeter used to measure corneal thickness. The corneal thickness indirectly reflects endothelial function. Ultrasonic pachymeters are more reliable than optical pachymeters.

Indications of pachymetry include the following:

  • Assessment of corneal thickness before and after refractive surgery
  • Monitoring keratoconus and thickness of transplanted corneas
  • Assess corneal edema

questions.text: Which of the following biochemical changes is not seen in a chronic alcoholic patient?

choices.text: Increased amount of pyruvate is converted to lactate

questions.solution:
In a patient with chronic alcoholism, there is an increased NADH/NAD+ ratio. As a result, several metabolic adaptations occur:

Within the cellular cytoplasm, elevated levels of NADH favor the transformation of pyruvate into lactate, which can lead to lactic acidosis. The resulting lack of pyruvate leads to insufficient production of oxaloacetate. This insufficiency, in turn, suppresses the process of gluconeogenesis and can cause hypoglycemia.

Diminished oxaloacetate, reduced pyruvate, and an abundance of NADH can inhibit the tricarboxylic acid (TCA) cycle. This inhibition leads to an accumulation of Acetyl CoA, promoting ketogenesis. The heightened presence of acetyl CoA leads to an increase in fatty acid synthesis. However, the fatty acid is not broken down, leading to fat buildup in the liver, known as fatty liver or steatosis.

Alcohol consumption can further exacerbate these conditions by promoting the release of Reactive Oxygen Species (ROS). This can cause damage to the mitochondria and induce cell death, or apoptosis.

Lactic acidosis also affects the excretion of uric acid and can lead to an acute attack of gout. Additionally, alcohol inhibits certain excitatory receptors, such as N-methyl aspartate receptors, and enhances the effect of inhibitory neurotransmitters like GABA receptors.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male presents with hemoptysis for the past 3 days. There is a history of pulmonary tuberculosis in the past for which he had completed treatment. His CT scan is shown below. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features and the CT showing a crescent sign are suggestive of aspergilloma.

Aspergillomas are mass-like fungus balls that are typically composed of Aspergillus fumigatus and are a non-invasive form of pulmonary aspergillosis. Aspergillomas occur in patients with normal immunity but structurally abnormal lungs, with pre-existing cavities. The most common underlying condition is pulmonary tuberculosis.

The fungal ball can be seen on both plain film and CT as an intracavitary mass surrounded by a crescent of air. The mass usually moves within the cavity when the patient moves and this sign is called the Monod sign.

Other clinical manifestations of Aspergillus:

  • The halo sign in chest imaging is a feature seen on HRCT where ground glass opacity surrounds a pulmonary nodule or mass and represents hemorrhage. It is typically seen in angioinvasive aspergillosis. Seen in immunocompromised patients.

Allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis - The image depicts finger in glove sign in the left upper lobe. It is seen due to branching thick tubular opacities due to bronchi distended with mucus and fungus.

questions.text: The oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curves in hyperthermia and carbon monoxide poisoning, respectively, shift to
questions.solution:
In cases of hyperthermia and carbon monoxide poisoning, the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve shifts to the right and left, respectively.

In carbon monoxide poisoning, the affinity of Hb for CO is about 200 times more than that for O2, and hence, the COHb releases the CO into the blood very slowly. The O2–Hb dissociation curve of the remaining hemoglobin shifts to the left.

Graph of the oxygen hemoglobin dissociation curve in anemia was tested recently in INICET May 2023. In chronic anemia, there is marked hemoglobin deficiency associated with increased 2-3, DPG in red blood cells, and as a result, the O2- Hb dissociation curve shifts to the right.

questions.text: A 55 kg lady has a resting oxygen consumption of 240 ml/min with 0.25 ml O2/ml of systemic arterial oxygen content and systemic mixed venous content of 0.20 ml O2/ml. Her baseline heart rate is 70 beats/min. Her cardiac output and stroke volume respectively will be:
questions.solution:
Based on the Fick principle, cardiac output can be calculated by the following equation:

Cardiac output = Oxygen consumption / [O2] pulmonary vein - [O2] pulmonary artery

In the given scenario:

  • The oxygen consumption for the whole body at rest is 240 mL/min.
  • Pulmonary vein oxygen content is measured in systemic arterial blood, which is 0.25 mL/min
  • Pulmonary artery oxygen content is measured in systemic venous blood, which is 0.20 mL/min

Hence Cardiac output = 240 ml/min / 0.25-0.20

                                = 4800 ml/min or 4.8L/min

Stroke volume = Cardiac output/Heart rate

                                          = 4800 ml/min/70 beats/min

                                          = 68.5 ml/beat

questions.text: A 38-year-old man came to the orthopedic outpatient clinic with a high stepping gait and is found to have a fracture at the neck of the fibula on an X-ray. This is associated with a loss of sensation in which of the following area/areas of the foot?
questions.solution:
A fracture at the neck of the fibula and a high stepping gait (foot drop) suggests injury to the common fibular nerve. This is associated with loss of sensation over the dorsum of the foot (marked 4) and the first interdigital space (marked 1). 

The nerves supplying the marked areas are shown below.

The common fibular nerve is derived from the dorsal branches of the 4th and 5th lumbar and 1st and 2nd sacral ventral rami. It runs obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa to the fibular head. It lies between the biceps femoris and the lateral head of the gastrocnemius. It then curves laterally around the neck of the fibula and gets divided into superficial and deep fibular nerves. 

The first interdigital space is supplied by the deep fibular nerve while the dorsum of the foot (except lateral and medial borders) is supplied by the superficial fibular nerve.

  Superficial fibular nerve Deep fibular nerve
Motor innervation
  • Peroneus longus
  • Peroneus Brevis
  • Extensor digitorum longus
  • Extensor hallucis longus
  • Tibialis anterior
  • Peroneus tertius
Sensory innervation
  • Lateral aspect of the lower leg
  • Dorsum of the toes except for the lateral side of the 5th toe and the first interdigital webspace

 
  • The first interdigital space
 

 

Injury to the common peroneal nerve at the level of the neck of the fibula causes foot drop. Ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion of the foot are lost, while the inversion and plantar flexion are usually preserved. Sensory innervation to the dorsum of the foot, including the first web space, is lost. The ankle reflex is usually preserved.

Other options:

Area 2 represents the lateral aspect of the foot which is supplied by the sural nerve.

Area 3 represents the medial aspect of the foot which is supplied by the saphenous nerve.

questions.text: A severely injured person who is a victim of an assault is brought to the hospital. Which among the following statements is false about recording his dying declaration?

choices.text: The doctors role is to ascertain compos mentis
Dying declaration can be recorded only by the magistrate
Dying declaration has to be recorded in patient's words
Suggestions or leading questions are not allowed

questions.solution:
A dying declaration can be recorded by the doctor himself in the presence of two witnesses if he thinks that the victim will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate.

A dying declaration is a statement, verbal or written made by a victim before his or her death, relating to the circumstances leading to death. A medical officer should inform the magistrate to have a dying declaration recorded as soon as the severely injured person is brought to the hospital.

The doctors can record it themselves in the presence of two witnesses if they think that the person will not survive till the arrival of the magistrate. Treatment should not be delayed while recording a dying declaration.

The doctor has to ascertain that the dying person is of sound mind (compos mentis) before recording the statement.

If the person dies or becomes unconscious while recording the dying declaration, the doctor must record the information obtained up to that point. It should be recorded in the patient's own words. No suggestions or leading questions are allowed, and any outsider is not allowed to be present.

After completing the writing, it has to be read back to the patient who has to approve it with a signature or thumb impression. The signature of two witnesses is mandatory.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 32 weeks of gestation presented to casualty with sudden onset abdominal pain and vaginal bleeding. On examination, she was tachycardic, her blood pressure was normal, and there were no signs of shock. The uterus was tender and the fetal heart rate was markedly elevated. Which of the following is not a risk factor for this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of abdominal pain, maternal tachycardia, a tender uterus with vaginal bleeding, and fetal distress point to a diagnosis of abruptio placentae, for which primiparity is not a risk factor. The risk of developing abruption increases with increasing parity (primiparity is not a risk factor).

Abruptio placentae refer to the premature separation of the placenta, either partially or totally from its implantation site before delivery. It is initiated by hemorrhage into the decidua basalis. Consequently, a decidual hematoma forms and expands, causing the placenta to get separated and compressed.

The bleeding between the membranes and uterus escapes through the cervix leading to external hemorrhage. Less often, the blood gets retained between the detached placenta and the uterus, leading to concealed hemorrhage.

Risk factors for placental abruption:

  • Prior abruption
  • Increased age and parity 
  • Cocaine use, Cigarette smoking (Option A)
  • Preterm prematurely ruptured membrane (Option B)
  • Preeclampsia and chronic hypertension (Option D)
  • Chorioamnionitis
  • Multifetal gestation
  • Low birth weight
  • Hydramnios
  • Trauma
  • Uterine leiomyoma - especially if located near the mucosal surface behind the placental implantation site
  • Single umbilical artery

Clinical classification of placental abruption:

Grade 1 Grade 2 Grade 3
Vaginal bleeding is slight Vaginal bleeding mild to moderate Bleeding is moderate to severe or concealed.

Uterus irritable, minimal tenderness

 Uterine tenderness is always present Uterine tenderness is marked.
Maternal BP and fibrinogen unaffected Maternal pulse increased, BP maintained Shock is pronounced
FHS good Fetal distress present Fetal death is the rule
Maternal shock absent Maternal shock absent Associated coagulation defect or anuria may complicate

questions.text: The below image represents the histological section of the skin. Identify the keratin filaments present in the layer labeled as  D?
questions.solution:

questions.text: The drug of choice for the management of acute  alcohol withdrawal is?
questions.solution:
Benzodiazepines are the treatment of choice for the management of acute alcohol withdrawal. It is used to prevent the progression from minor withdrawal symptoms to major ones, such as seizures and delirium tremens.

FDA-approved drugs used in the management of alcohol use disorder are:

  • Disulfiram: It inhibits the enzyme aldehyde dehydrogenase. It is used as an aversive drug and causes adverse effects when taken with alcohol. Therefore, it should not be administered until the patient has abstained from alcohol for at least 12 hours.
  • Naltrexone: It is a μ-opioid receptor antagonist. It decreased drinking by decreasing the feeling of reward with alcohol or decreasing craving.
  • Acamprosate: It may act by blocking hyperglutamatergic state and decreases craving.
  • Benzodiazepines: They act by increasing the binding of GABA to GABAA receptors. They are the drugs of choice for the management of acute alcohol withdrawal.
  • Fomepizole: It is used in the management of methanol poisoning. It acts by inhibiting the enzyme alcohol dehydrogenase.

Other drugs that are commonly used  in the management of alcohol use disorder, but not approved by the FDA are:

  • Gabapentin: It blocks voltage-gated calcium channels
  • Varenicline: It is a partial or full agonist at central nicotinic AChR subtypes. It is used to decrease alcohol consumption and smoking cessation.
  • Nalmefene: It is an antagonist of μ- and κ-opioid receptors. It is also used to treat opioid overdose or dependence.
  • Baclofen: It is a GABAB receptor agonist. It acts as a skeletal muscle relaxant and is used in the management of spasticity.

questions.text: After a recent event of severe floods in a metropolitan city, the local government has planned to implement certain measures which include floodwater diversion and storage, building new underground sewage lines with increased capacity, performing land surveys, and limit the construction of new buildings in flood-impacted areas.  The given measures are part of which of the following phases of disaster management?
questions.solution:
The measures given in the question, are part of disaster mitigation.

Disaster mitigation includes measures taken to prevent hazards from causing emergencies or to lessen the likely effects of emergencies. Some of these measures include:

  • Flood mitigation
  • Land-use planning
  • Improved building codes
  • Reduction and protection of vulnerable populations or structures.

Mitigation measures aim to reduce the vulnerability of the system. It complements the disaster preparedness and response activities.

Other options:

  • Disaster response includes activities such as rescue and first aid, field care, triage, etc.
  • Disaster rehabilitation refers to measures that lead to the restoration of pre-disaster conditions. Some of these measures include water supply restoration, food safety, basic sanitation, and personal hygiene, and vector control.
  • Disaster preparedness is a long-term plan with ongoing multisectoral activities, which include the development of policies or programs for disaster management, prevention, mitigation, preparedness, response, rehabilitation, and reconstruction. The measures taken will ensure that the country is well prepared to face any future disasters, and effectively prevent or manage to reduce the impact.

Disaster management cycle:

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman  presents to the CHC with complaints of vaginal discharge for 1 month. She also complains of a burning sensation in her vaginal area and urinary frequency for the past 5 days. There is no history of fever. Vitals are within normal limits and physical examination reveals a greenish frothy vaginal discharge. On speculum examination, you are able to see the below finding. Which of the following kits would you prescribe this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image showing strawberry cervix are suggestive of Trichomoniasis. The green kit containing Tablet Secnidazole 2 gm, to be taken orally as a single dose is recommended in its treatment.

Trichomoniasis is the infection of the female genital tract with the Trichomonas vaginalis protozoan. It characteristically causes a copious, frothy, offensive yellow-green discharge with vaginal soreness or irritation and urinary frequency. The vagina looks red and inflamed like a strawberry with punctate hemorrhagic spots.

Management: The CDC recommends one of the following treatment regimens.

  • Metronidazole 2 g orally in a single dose or Tinidazole 2 g orally in a single dose
  • The alternative regimen includes Metronidazole 500 mg orally twice a day for 7 days
  • Metronidazole gel does not reach therapeutic levels in the urethra and perivaginal glands. It is not recommended as it is less efficacious than oral metronidazole.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: In which of the following cases, vaginal birth after cesarean section (VBAC) can be considered?
questions.solution:
VBAC can be considered in case of a previous lower segment cesarean scar.

In cases where the previous cesarean section is done for some nonrecurrent indication and the uterine scar is sound, a vaginal delivery can be performed. 

Selection criteria for VBAC:

  1. One or two previous lower-segment transverse scars.
  2. Nonrecurring indication for prior cesarean section
  3. Pelvis adequate for the fetus
  4. Continuous monitoring of labor.
  5. Informed consent of the woman
  6. Sufficient personnel and equipment

Risk factors for VBAC:

  1. Classical or inverted T incision in prior cesarean
  2. Prior uterine rupture.
  3. Pelvis contracted or suspected CPD.
  4. Obstetrical contraindications such as placenta previa, malpresentation, or preeclampsia
  5. Transfundal surgery.
  6. Inadequate facilities

questions.text: A 7-year-old child with a history of sore throat two weeks ago presents with sudden onset of motor tics and emotional lability. A diagnosis of PANDAS was made. Which of the following may also be seen in this child?
questions.solution:
Pediatric autoimmune neuropsychiatric disorder associated with streptococcal infection (PANDAS) is associated with obsessive-compulsive disorder in children.

PANDAS results from the immune response of the body to Group A β-hemolytic Streptococcus infection. The antibodies directed against the bacteria cross-react with self-tissues due to molecular mimicry. The pathophysiology behind PANDAS is postulated to be the same as that of Sydenham chorea which occurs during acute rheumatic fever.

The diagnosis of PANDAS is based on:

  • Abrupt onset and episodic course of symptoms
  • Pediatric onset (age between 3 years and adolescent)
  • Temporal relation between Group A  β-hemolytic Streptococcus infection and the symptoms
  • Presence of OCD and/or a tic disorder (such as a motor or a vocal tic)

Related Pearl: Obsessive-compulsive disorder

Key points:

  • Most common:
    • Obsession: Contamination
    • Compulsion: Checking, cleaning
  • Treatment: Exposure and Response prevention - 1st line, Cognitive Behavioural Therapy(CBT), CBT with ERP, Pharmacotherapy.
  • Drug of choice: High dose SSRI
  • Treatment in nonresponsive patients: Clomipramine or antipsychotic augmentation
  • Treatment of severe or refractory cases: Deep brain stimulation

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl investigated for primary amenorrhea is diagnosed with Mayer–Rokitansky–Kuster–Hauser (MRHK) syndrome. Which of the following characteristics is not associated with this condition?

choices.text: Axillary and pubic hair is present

questions.solution:
The patients diagnosed with Mayer–Rokitansky–Kuster–Hauser (MRHK) syndrome have ovaries that are anatomically and functionally normal.

Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome or Mullerian agenesis is a condition wherein there is a congenital absence of the uterus and the vagina. The patients have a Karyotype of 46 XX, so the gonads present are ovaries. 

The patient's secondary sexual characteristics are well-developed (Option A and B) with normal external genitalia. The ovaries are normal but have an absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina. The patients usually have a blind-ended vaginal pouch. Diagnosis is made with the help of pelvic sonography and  MRI. Patients may have rudimentary Mullerian bulbs without an endometrial cavity.

The investigation algorithm for primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics is given below:

questions.text: Which of the following findings would not be seen in a patient with SIADH?
questions.solution:
In a patient with (SIADH) syndrome of inappropriate secretion of antidiuretic hormone, increased plasma renin activity would not be seen. Plasma renin activity is suppressed in SIADH.

In SIADH, there is a failure of the body to increase the diuresis even when the water intake is more than the urinary loss. There is a slight increase in the total body water. This causes dilutional euvolemic hyponatremia and reduced serum osmolality (Option C). This causes a suppression of the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system (RAAS). Atrial natriuretic peptide (ANP) (Option D) and B-type natriuretic peptide (BNP) levels are increased because of excess fluid retention. Suppressed RAAS and increased ANP and BNP together work to minimise the increase in extracellular volume and prevent oedema by increasing the GFR (Option B). They also cause increased sodium excretion in the urine.

questions.text:
The ABG analysis findings of a patient are given below. Which of the following is the likely diagnosis?

pH: 7.2

HCO3-: 10 mEq/L

PaCO2: 25 mmHg

Anion gap: 15

choices.text: High anion gap metabolic acidosis plus metabolic alkalosis
High anion gap metabolic acidosis only
High anion gap plus normal anion gap metabolic acidosis

questions.solution:
The given ABG is indicative of mixed high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA).

Interpretation of the ABG:

Step 1: The pH being 7.2 is suggestive of acidosis.

Step 2: Plasma HCO3- is 10 mEq/L, much lower than the normal value (22-28 mEq/L). Hence, this is a case of metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: To predict the respiratory compensation, we use the formula HCO3- + 15. This will give us the predicted PaCO2 values if there was compensation. Predicted PaCO2 in this case = 10 + 15 = 25 mEq/L. This is equal to the value given, so the respiratory compensation is adequate. This rules out option A.

Step 4: The anion gap given in the question is 15. Since the normal anion gap is 6-12, with an average of 10, a value of 15 is certainly high. So the scenario is suggestive of high anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA).

Step 5: Now the extent of change in anion gap and HCO3- levels has to be compared.

ΔHCO3- = median normal value – value given = 25 – 10 = 15

ΔAnion gap (ΔAG) = median normal value – value given = 10 – 15 = 5

Since ΔHCO3- is greater than ΔAG, it indicates that there are two entities decreasing the bicarbonate (HAGMA and NAGMA) but only one of them is contributing to the increased anion gap (HAGMA). NAGMA does not cause a change in the anion gap because HCO3- loss is rectified by Cl- reabsorption. Hence, the scenario in the given question is high anion gap and normal anion gap metabolic acidosis.

If ΔHCO3- < ΔAG, it indicates HAGMA plus metabolic alkalosis (option B).

If ΔHCO3- = ΔAG, it indicates the presence of only HAGMA (option C).

Related Pearl: Acid-Base Balance - Normal Values

Component Normal Range Optimal Value
pH 7.35 - 7.45 7.4
HCO3-  22 - 28 mEq/L   24 mEq/L
pCO2 35 - 45 mmHg 40 mmHg 
Anion gap 6 - 12 mEq/L <10 mEq/L
O2 saturation > 95%
pO2 75 - 100 mmHg  

Related Pearl: Causes of Metabolic Acidosis

High Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (MUDPILES) Normal Anion-Gap Metabolic Acidosis (FUSED CAR)
