questions.text: During couples therapy, the wife complains about the husband's behavior during intercourse. The husband says that he does not obtain pleasure unless he is yelled at and beaten. Which of the following paraphilias does the husband suffer from?
questions.solution:
The person in question is sexually aroused by being humiliated and injured by the sexual partner. This is highly suggestive of sexual masochism.

Paraphilias or perversions are sexual stimuli or acts that are deviations from normal sexual behaviors but are necessary for some people to experience arousal and orgasm.

Sexual arousal and pleasure stemmed from being humiliated, beaten, bound, or made to suffer is a paraphilia known as sexual masochism. This is a disorder that is widely seen in men rather than women. Moral masochism involves a need to suffer but is not accompanied by sexual fantasies. Another specific diagnosis that falls under masochism is autoerotic asphyxiation/asphyxiophilia. This is the act of achieving or heightening sexual arousal as a result of constriction of the airway or restriction of breathing encompasses asphyxiophilia.

Other options :

Option A: Frotteurism is when a person receives sexual gratification by touching or rubbing their genitalia against a non-consenting person. This behavior often occurs in busy and crowded places like buses. It is predominantly described in men.

Option C: When the sexual focus is on a particular object which is associated with the human body (a shoe for example), the paraphilia is known as fetishism. This is found mostly in men. The object of desire usually plays a part during masturbation or sexual intercourse.

Option D: Sexual arousal obtained from the physical or psychological suffering of another person is known as sexual sadism. It is commonly seen in males with the onset before the age of 18. Hereditary predisposition and a history of sexual abuse may be contributory factors to developing sexual sadism.

Other important paraphilic disorders include:

  • Exhibitionism involves the urge to expose genitals to a stranger or unsuspecting person.
  • Pedophilia involves recurrent intense sexual urges or arousal by children less than 13 years of age over a period of at least 6 months.
  • Voyeurism, also called scopophilia, involves an urge to watch an unsuspecting person naked or in sexual activity.
  • Transvestism refers to fantasies and sexual urges to dress in opposite-gender clothing.
  • Telephone and computer scatologia involves obscene phone calling or sending of videos and images to an unsuspecting recipient.
  • Necrophilia is an obsession with obtaining sexual gratification from dead bodies.
  • Zoophilia involves having the urge to involve in sexual activity like intercourse, masturbation, or oral-genital contact with an animal.
  • Coprophilia refers to the sexual pleasure associated with a desire to defecate on the partner, to be defecated on, or to eat feces (coprophilia).
  • Urophilia refers to the sexual pleasure associated with the desire to urinate on a partner or to be urinated on.
  • Hypoxyphilia is the desire to achieve an altered state of consciousness secondary to hypoxia while experiencing orgasm. They may use volatile nitrite or nitrous oxide to produce hypoxia.

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida came for her first ultrasound in the late first trimester period.  Two images of her ultrasound scan are given below and laboratory examination shows raised alfa fetoprotein (AFP). What can be the possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a primigravida with elevated AFP and a late first-trimester scan showing shower cap sign and open calvarium is suggestive of anencephaly. 

Anencephaly is characterized by the absence of cranium and telencephalic structures above the skull base and orbits with normal facial portions. Its incidence is 1 in 1000. Anencephaly and spina bifida are common in the first birth while the incidence of other malformations is high with increasing parity. 

The below image shows the shower cap sign and open calvarium in anencephaly. 

Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". Anencephaly is a severe defect and is not compatible with survival. The images are given below show open calvaria on antenatal ultrasound and frog-eye sign.

Option B- Intrauterine death is defined as the antepartum death occurring beyond the period of viability. Due to the liquefaction of brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, irregular overlapping of cranial bone termed spalding sign occurs. It appears 7 days after death. 

The image below shows the spalding sign.

Option C- Spina bifida is a congenital anomaly occurring due to incomplete development of the neural tube. It is divided into two:

  • spina bifida occulta
  • spina bifida aperta

The most commonly cited signs present in spina bifida are the banana sign and lemon sign.

The banana sign is the curved cerebellum due to its downward displacement that leads to Arnold-Chiari II malformation as shown below.

The lemon sign occurs due to the overlapping of the frontal bones due to the posterior shift of intracranial contents as shown below.

Option D- Omphalocele is a congenital midline anterior abdominal wall defect through which the solid abdominal viscera or bowel herniate. The herniated abdominal contents are covered by a membranous sac as shown below.

 The image below shows an ultrasound image of the fetus suggestive of an omphalocele (asterix).

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text:
Theme: reperfusion strategy for myocardial infarction

A 60-year-old man presents to the ER with severe chest pain. The pain began when he was climbing the stairs at his house and has persisted despite rest. He gives a previous history of similar episodes of chest pain, but they always resolved when he took rest. The pain is associated with breathlessness and sweating. He is a known case of type II diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He smokes 1 pack of cigarettes per day.

On examination: temperature 98.6°F, HR 100/min, BP 150/90 mmHg, SpO2 99% on room air. 12-lead ECG shows ST elevation in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6, and ST depression in leads II, III, and aVF. The nursing staff informs you that patient transfer to the nearest hospital with a cardiac cath lab will take 45 minutes. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?

choices.text: Transfer the patient for PCI after administering fibrinolytic agent
Transfer the patient for PCI without administering fibrinolytic agent

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a patient with ST-segment elevation myocardial infarction (STEMI). A transfer time of 45 minutes is well below the maximum permitted time interval of 120 minutes between the first medical contact and stent placement. Therefore, the most appropriate next step for this patient would be a transfer to a PCI-capable hospital without the administration of a fibrinolytic agent.

The patient in question has multiple risk factors for coronary artery disease, such as diabetes mellitus, hypertension, and smoking. Previous episodes of chest pain that were relieved on rest indicate stable angina. Now the patient has presented with severe chest pain that began on exertion (climbing the stairs) and is not getting relieved even on rest. This is suggestive of an acute coronary syndrome, most likely due to an acute change such as thrombosis in previously stable atherosclerotic plaque in the coronary arteries.

The vitals of the patient are unremarkable, except for elevated BP. The absence of desaturation and hypotension indicates that despite an ongoing acute coronary syndrome, the patient's heart function is fair at the moment. A 12-lead ECG showing ST-elevation in leads I, aVL, V5 and V6 indicates lateral wall STEMI. The ST depression seen in reciprocal leads II, III, and aVF supports this.

In a patient with STEMI, primary percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI) — angioplasty with/without stenting but without prior fibrinolysis — is more effective than fibrinolysis alone in opening the occluded coronary vessel and has better clinical outcomes. In case the patient has presented to a PCI-capable hospital, primary PCI should be done within 90 minutes of the patient presenting.

If the patient has presented to a non-PCI-capable hospital, a fibrinolytic agent is given within 30 minutes of the patient presenting if the anticipated time to PCI is >120 minutes. This time limit includes the time spent in non-PCI-capable hospital and the time taken to transfer the patient to a PCI-capable setup. If the anticipated time to PCI is ≤120 minutes, the patient is directly transferred to PCI-capable hospital without fibrinolysis.

In addition to the above management, the patients are also stated on oxygen (if hypoxemia is present), morphine, aspirin, sublingual nitroglycerine, and beta-blockers. Nitrates should be avoided in patients with suspected right ventricular infarction — hypotension with clear lung fields on auscultation.

questions.text: Which of the following viruses belongs to the family filoviridae, and is transmitted as depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
Ebola virus belongs to the family filoviridae and is transmitted by bats.

Ebola virus:

  • It is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa.
  • It belongs to the Filoviridae family.
  • Incubation period: 2 to 21 days.
  • Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of animals like chimpanzees and monkeys.
  • Human to human transmission is through blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.
  • It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.
  • Symptoms include fever, intense weakness, vomiting, diarrhea, rashes, and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding.
  • Ebola virus shows a bowl of spaghetti appearance.
  • The current treatment is mainly supportive.
  • Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

questions.text: A young patient presented to the OPD with the following findings. Which of the following types of respiratory failure is likely to be seen in her?
questions.solution:
The given clinical image shows scoliosis. The type of respiratory failure seen in patients with scoliosis is type II respiratory failure.

Type II respiratory failure occurs because of alveolar hypoventilation. Carbon dioxide elimination is impaired, leading to respiratory acidosis. If the underlying condition is chronic, the kidneys retain bicarbonate and the pH becomes normal. Alveolar hypoventilation can occur due to decreased CNS drive to breathe (such as with narcotic drugs or brainstem injury), or due to decreased strength of the respiratory muscles (such as myasthenia gravis, Guillian-Barre syndrome, amyotrophic lateral sclerosis, and kyphoscoliosis).

questions.solution:

questions.text: A 24-year-old primigravida presents with painless vaginal bleeding in the first trimester. The size of the uterus corresponds to the period of amenorrhea. On examination, the external os is closed. USG shows a well-formed gestational sac with fetal cardiac activity. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical features are suggestive of threatened abortion.

In threatened miscarriage, the process of miscarriage has started but has not progressed to a state from which recovery is impossible. 

Features:

  • Bleeding which is usually slight and may be brownish or bright red in color
  • Usually painless but pain appears following hemorrhage
  • Closed external os
  • Uterine size corresponds to the period of amenorrhea
  • Uterus and cervix feel soft
  • Transvaginal Ultrasonography shows a well-formed gestation ring indicating a healthy fetus with fetal cardiac activity.

Treatment involves bed rest, analgesics to relieve pain, and progesterone.

Seen in 1-2% of women with threatened or incomplete miscarriage

  -

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient came with a sharp, severe, constant, burning pain in his right chest. On examination, the lesion is as seen below. Which of the following is the characteristic finding that you would expect to see on microscopy with Tzanck smear in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image showing confluent, red, pustular lesions in a single dermatome associated with severe pain is suggestive of herpes zoster or shingles. Herpes zoster shows multinucleated giant cells on microscopy with Tzanck smear.

Tzanck smear is a cytological examination of skin blisters. After rupturing the roof of the blister, the floor is scraped with a blade and the material is transferred onto a microscopic slide and fixed. Slides are stained with Giemsa, Wright’s stain or toluidine blue and examined under the microscope.

The findings of various disorders on Tzanck smear are as follows:

Disorder Finding
Pemphigus Acantholytic cells
Bullous pemphigoid Predominantly eosinophils
Chronic bullous disease of childhood Predominantly neutrophils
Varicella-zoster Multinucleated giant cells
Herpes simplex infection Multinucleated giant cells
Toxic epidermal necrolysis Necrotic cells
Molluscum contagiosum

Henderson Paterson Bodies
Vaccinia, orf, milker's nodules and variola  Acantholytic cells with Guarneiri Bodies
Leishmania  Leishman-Donovan (LD) Bodies in the untreated patients 

Herpes zoster

It is a segmental eruption due to the reactivation of latent varicella-zoster virus from dorsal root ganglia. An earlier infection with varicella is essential before zoster can occur. 

The first symptom of zoster is usually pain and it may be accompanied by fever, headache, malaise, and tenderness localized to areas of one or more dorsal roots. The mucous membranes within the affected dermatomes are involved.

The patients are infectious, both from the virus in the lesions and nasopharynx. The thoracic dermatomes are most commonly affected in all ages. The posterior nerve roots and ganglia show inflammatory changes.

Zoster is a self‐limiting infection but it is painful and carries a risk of secondary infection and post‐herpetic neuralgia. Analgesia and treatment of secondary infections are sufficient for mild infections.

Indications for antivirals in VZV (Acyclovir 800 mg):

  • Painful zoster infections in adults
  • Facial zoster at any age
  • Immunocompromised

questions.text: What type(s) of hemolysis would you expect to see in patients with G6PD deficiency?
questions.solution:
Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency leads to both extravascular and intravascular hemolysis.

G6PD is an enzyme in the hexose monophosphate pathway (HMP) that maintains the cellular levels of NADPH. NADPH then provides reducing equivalents needed for the conversion of oxidized glutathione to reduced glutathione. Reduced glutathione helps neutralize free radicles, protecting against oxidant injury.

G6PD deficiency is an X-linked recessive (XLR) disorder that causes congenital hemolytic anemia due to enzyme deficiency. Hemolysis occurs in conditions of high oxidative stress as follows:

  • The oxidative stress causes the cross-linking of reactive sulfhydryl groups on globin chains. This causes denaturation and formation of membrane-bound precipitates known as Heinz bodies. When the membrane is severely damaged by Heinz bodies it causes intravascular hemolysis.
  • Less severe membrane damage causes decreased red cell deformability and become spherocytes. Macrophages pluck out the Heinz bodies from these cells as they pass through the splenic cords to form bite cells. Both bite cells and spherocytes get trapped in splenic cords. These sequestered cells are killed by macrophages causing extravascular hemolysis. 

Clinically, most of these patients are asymptomatic. Some patient develops episodic hemolysis when exposed to oxidative triggers such as infections, fava beans, and certain drugs. It leads to hemolytic anemia, hemoglobinemia, and hemoglobinuria.

Related Pearl: Classification of Hemolytic Anemias

Hemolytic anemias can be classified in 2 ways:

1. Based on the type of defect:

Type  Intracorpuscular Defects Extracorpuscular Factors
Hereditary

Hemoglobinopathies

Enzymopathies

Membrane-cytoskeletal defects

 Familial (atypical) hemolytic uremic syndrome
Acquired Paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH)

Mechanical destruction (microangiopathic)

Toxic agents

Drugs

Infectious

Autoimmune

2. Based on the sites of hemolysis:

Intravascular hemolysis:

  • Mechanical injury
    • Trauma caused by cardiac valves 
    • Microangiopathic hemolytic anaemias (hemolytic uremic syndrome, disseminated intravascular coagulation, thrombotic thrombocytopenic purpura) 
    • Repetitive physical trauma
  • Complement fixation (antibody-mediated destruction)
    • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- ABO incompatibility
    • Transfusion reaction  
    • Drug-induced 
  • Infections of red blood cells 
    • Malaria
    • Babesiosis
  • Exogenous toxic factors - clostridial sepsis

Extravascular hemolysis:

  • Hereditary spherocytosis
  • Thalassemia
  • Sickle cell anemia
  • Hemolytic disease of the newborn- Rh incompatibility

Both intravascular and extravascular hemolysis:

  • G6PD deficiency
  • Autoimmune hemolytic anemia

questions.text: Which of the following is the preferred irrigating fluid in monopolar-TURP and bipolar-TURP respectively?
questions.solution:
The preferred irrigating fluid for M-TURP and B-TURP are 1.5% isotonic glycine, and Normal saline respectively. 

Monopolar transurethral resection of the prostate (M-TURP) removes tissue with a wire loop that has an electrical current flowing in one direction (monopolar). The surgical site is irrigated with a non-conducting non-ionic fluid as the use of an ionic solution leads to dissipation of the cutting current and poor cutting efficacy. Thus, normal saline and N/5 saline cannot be used.

Bipolar transurethral resection of the prostate (B-TURP) uses a specialized resecting loop that incorporates both the active and the return portions of the circuit on the same electrode and an ionic irrigating solution such as normal saline can be used safely. 

The use of distilled water in TURP leads to the water-intoxication syndrome.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true about Culex larvae/ mosquito?
  1. Eggs are laid in clusters
  2. Siphon tube is present
  3. Breeds in clean water
  4. Larva lies parallel to the undersurface of the water
  5. Wings are unspotted and body is striped
questions.solution:
Culex larvae have siphon tubes and the eggs are laid in clusters.

Option 3: Culex breeds in dirty and polluted water while Anopheles breeds in clean water.

Option 4: The larvae of Anopheles lie parallel to the undersurface of water. In the case of Culex, Aedes and Mansonia, the larvae lie in the water with heads facing downwards.

Option 5: Wings of Culex and Mansonia are unspotted while unspotted wings and striped body is characteristic of Aedes.

Related Pearl: The Mosquito

The mosquito as a vector:

  • Mosquitoes are global in distribution
  • The main species of mosquitoes include the Anopheles, Culex, Aedes, and Mansonia
  • Flight range varies up to 11 km, except Aedes for which it is 100 meters
  • The life span of mosquitoes is around 8 to 34 days
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a proboscis, a pair of palpi, and a pair of antennae; a thorax and an abdomen
  • The larval stage lasts for 5 to 7 days

Characteristics:

Characteristics Anopheles Culex Aedes Mansonia

Eggs: 100-250. 

 Laid singly. Boat-shaped with lateral floats. Laid in clusters or rafts. Laid singly. Laid in star-shaped clusters.

Larval stage

No siphon tube.

Lies parallel to the undersurface of water.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.

Has siphon tube.

Lies in water with head faced downwards.
Adults Wings spotted. Wings unspotted. Wings unspotted. Striped body. Wings unspotted.
Breeding areas Clean water Dirty and polluted water Artificial collections of water Water bodies containing aquatic vegetation
Diseases Malaria, filaria Bancroftian filariasis, Japanese encephalitis, West Nile fever, viral arthritis. Yellow fever, dengue, DHF, chikungunya, rift valley fever, filariasis, Zika virus Malayan filariasis
Comments Anopheline mosquitoes tend to sit with their heads low and their rear ends raised high, especially when feeding. 

Called Nuisance mosquitoes

These culicine female mosquitoes keep their bodies horizontal while feeding.

Called tiger mosquitoes

Day biters

They get the tiger's name from the white stripes on its legs.

 Big, black, or brown mosquitoes with sparkling wings and legs. 

 

 

Culex mosquito keeps their bodies horizontal while feeding.

 Anopheles mosquito tends to sit at an angle, with their heads low and their rear ends raised high.

Aedes mosquito has a striped body pattern.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with fissured tongue and cheilosis. Investigations showed reduced glutathione reductase activity. Among the following co-factors of enzyme complexes, which one is most affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario suggests riboflavin/vitamin B2 deficiency. Both FAD and FMN require riboflavin for their synthesis. Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro.

The active form of riboflavin is Flavin mononucleotide(FMN) and Flavin Adenine Dinucleotide (FAD). FMN is present in Complex I of ETC and FAD is present in Complex II in ETC. FAD-dependent enzymes include succinate dehydrogenase, pyruvate dehydrogenase, alpha-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, xanthine oxidase, and acyl CoA dehydrogenase

Riboflavin is synthesised in the body by intestinal flora. Dietary sources rich in riboflavin are liver, dried yeast, egg, and whole milk. Fish, whole cereals, legumes, and green leafy vegetables are also good sources of riboflavin. Riboflavin is light-sensitive. Hence, riboflavin supplementation may be required during phototherapy for hyperbilirubinemia 

Clinical features of riboflavin deficiency include the proliferation of the bulbar conjunctival capillaries (the earliest sign of riboflavin deficiency) angular stomatitis, circumcorneal vascularisation, cheilosis, magenta-coloured tongue, glossitis, and seborrheic dermatitis. 

Other options:

Options B and C: NAD+ and NADP+ are derived from niacin.

Related Pearl: Biochemical Assay for Vitamin Deficiency State

Vitamin

Assay and test

Vitamin B1 (Thiamine)

RBC Trans-ketolase

Vitamin B2 (Riboflavin)

RBC glutathione reductase

Vitamin B6 (Pyridoxine)

RBC transaminase

Vitamin B9 (Folic acid)

FIGLU excretion/Histidine load test

Vitamin B12 (Cobalamine)

Serum methyl malonate level

questions.text: During the clinical examination of a patient with carpal tunnel syndrome,which of the following tests is least relevant?
questions.solution:
Neer's test is used in the diagnosis of impingement syndrome/painful arc syndrome.

Clinical tests in carpal tunnel syndrome include the reproduction of sensory symptoms such as paresthesias and pain by performing the following tests:

  • Durkan's test - By applying direct median nerve compression for about 30 seconds.
  • Tinel's test (sign) - By percussing the median nerve.
  • Phalen's test - By holding the wrist in flexion for about 60 seconds.

The following image shows Phalen's test:

The diagnosis of carpal tunnel syndrome is usually clinical. Nerve conduction studies can be done in patients with atypical symptoms to confirm the diagnosis in case of atypical presentation of carpal tunnel syndrome. The tests will show slowing of nerve conduction across the wrist.

Carpal tunnel syndrome usually presents at an age of 40–50 years. The common risk factors are pregnancy, rheumatoid disease, renal failure, and gout.

Most of the patients present with burning pain, tingling, and numbness in the distribution of the median nerve. The symptoms worsen with activity and at night. Hanging the arm over the side of the bed and shaking the arm relieve the pain.

Night pain and pregnancy-related symptoms can be reduced by using splints to prevent wrist flexion. Temporary relief from pain can be attained using steroid injection and is a diagnostic tool also.

In patients with an intermediate and chronic syndrome, an early carpal tunnel release can be performed. This surgery is beneficial in most patients, and maximum improvement is seen in 6 months after the release.

 

Other options:

Neer's test: In patients with a positive Neer's impingement sign, injection of 10% lidocaine into subacromial space, and repeating the test demomstrates pain reduction. 

Related Pearl: Compression neuropathies

Syndrome 

Nerve involved

Pronator teres syndrome

Median nerve (proximally compressed beneath ligament of Struthers, bicipital aponeurosis, or origins of pronator teres)

Radial tunnel (Arcade of Frohse) syndrome

Posterior Interosseous nerve (in proximal forearm)

Cubital tunnel syndrome

Ulnar nerve behind medial epicondyle

Cheiralgia Paresthetica (Wartenburg syndrome)

Superficial sensory branch of radial nerve

Carpal tunnel syndrome

Median nerve (at wrist)

Guyon's canal syndrome

Ulnar nerve(at wrist)

Thoracic outlet syndrome

Lower trunk of brachial plexus

Tarsal tunnel syndrome

Posterior tibial nerve

Piriformis syndrome

Sciatic nerve
Meralgia paresthetica Lateral cutaneous nerve of thigh
Mortons Metatarsalgia Interdigital plantar nerve 
Notalgia Paresthetica Superficial sensory neuropathy in the infrascapular area (Pruritus + Dysaesthesia)

questions.text: The clinical classification under CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) guidelines in a patient with the following feature would be:
questions.solution:
The given image is characteristic of atrophie blanche which is classified as C4b under CEAP guidelines.

Atrophie blanche is a localized white atrophic skin frequently surrounded by dilated capillaries and pigmentation, usually seen around the ankle. This is a sign of severe chronic venous disease.

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology) classification system is used to classify chronic lower extremity venous disease.

The clinical class of C4 under CEAP includes changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary to chronic venous disease. It is further classified as,

  • C4a-Pigmentation or eczema
  • C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche
  • C4c-Corona phlebectatica

Related Pearl: CEAP Classification of Chronic Lower Extremity Venous Disease

CEAP (Clinical-Etiology-Anatomy-Pathophysiology)

Clinical classification (C)*

C0

No visible or palpable signs of venous disease

C1

Telangiectases or reticular veins

C2

C2r

Varicose veins

Recurrent varicose veins

C3

Edema

C4

Changes in skin and subcutaneous tissue secondary

to chronic venous disease

C4a-Pigmentation or eczema

C4b-Lipodermatosclerosis or atrophie blanche

C4c-Corona phlebectatica

C5

Healed ulcer

C6

C6r

Active ulcer

Recurrent active venous ulcer

S

With symptoms attributable to venous disease

A

Absence of symptoms attributable to venous disease

Etiological classification (E)

Ec

Congenital (Klippel-Trenaunay syndrome)

Ep

Es

Secondary (postthrombotic syndrome, trauma)

Esi

Secondary (intravenous)

Ese

Secondary (extravenous)

Ec

Congenital

Anatomic classification (A)

As

Superficial

Patho-physiologic classification (P)

Pr

Reflux

Obstruction, thrombosis

Pr,o

Reflux and obstruction

Pn

No venous pathophysiology identified

Note:

  • The descriptor A (asymptomatic) or S (symptomatic) is placed after the C clinical class.
  • Telengiactesia refers to tiny intradermal venules <1 mm in diameter.
  • Reticular veins refer to small dilated subdermal blue veins of 1 to 2.9 mm
  • Varicose veins refer to dilated tortuous veins >3 mm in diameter

questions.text: A 45-year- old labourer presented to the emergency with weakness in the right side of the body and slurred speech. His history showed that he followed a strict vegetarian diet. O/E he was afebrile, his BP was 160/100 mm Hg, and HR was 110/min. Routine investigations were normal except for raised homocysteine levels. Which of the following deficiencies is not responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Niacin deficiency does not cause hyperhomocysteinemia as given in the above clinical scenario.

All the following vitamin deficiencies - pyridoxine (Vitamin B6), folic acid, and cobalamin (B12) can cause hyperhomocysteinemia which can lead to stroke as given in the clinical scenario.

  • Vitamin B6 is the co-factor for the enzyme cystathionine-β-synthase.
  • Vitamin B12 is the cofactor for the enzyme methionine synthase, which catalyzes the remethylation of homocysteine to methionine.
  • Due to a deficiency of vitamin B12, there is the failure of conversion of methyl tetrahydrofolate to tetrahydrofolate. Hence folate accumulates in the form of methyl tetrahydrofolate resulting in functional folate deficiency. 

Classic homocystinuria is a metabolic disorder of methionine metabolism, due to cystathionine beta-synthase deficiency. It is an autosomal recessive condition.

Cystathionine beta-synthase is a pyridoxal phosphate-dependent enzyme that condenses homocysteine with serine to form cystathionine. The absence of this enzyme will cause cysteine deficiency, hence cysteine needs to be supplemented in the diet.

Clinical features:

  • Affected children are initially asymptomatic. 
  • Ectopia lentis (subluxation of the lens) is seen first, after 3 years of age.
  • Intellectual disability and psychiatric and behavioral disorders.
  • Thromboembolic episodes.
  • Skeletal abnormalities resembling those of Marfan syndrome: They are tall and thin with elongated limbs and arachnodactyly (slender fingers).

Elevations of both methionine and homocysteine in body fluids are the diagnostic laboratory findings. The diagnosis is established by molecular analysis of cystathionine β-synthase (CBS) or by assay of the enzyme in cultured fibroblasts, phytohemagglutinin-stimulated lymphocytes, or liver biopsy specimens. Treatment includes restriction of methionine intake and supplementation with cysteine, betaine, vitamins B6, B12, and folate.

Methionine supplementation is required in non-classical homocystinuria. It is due to impaired re-methylation of homocysteine to methionine. This can be caused by defective methionine synthase or reduced availability of two essential cofactors, 5-methyltetrahydrofolate, and methylcobalamin.

Elevated homocysteine levels with low levels of methionine will be seen. Treatment includes methionine supplementation and administration of methyl folate, hydroxocobalamin, and betaine.

questions.text: The syndrome in which deletion affects the paternal allele in chromosome 15 is ________
questions.solution:
Deletion of the paternal allele in chromosome 15 causes Prader–Willi syndrome. It is a genomic imprinting disorder.

Imprinting involves transcriptional silencing of the paternal or maternal copies of certain genes during gametogenesis. In most cases, imprinting selectively inactivates either the maternal or paternal allele. Thus, maternal imprinting refers to the transcriptional silencing of the maternal allele, whereas paternal imprinting implies that the paternal allele is inactivated. On the other hand, the inheritance of both chromosomes of a pair from one parent is called uniparental disomy. Either of these mechanisms causes the following two diseases.

  Prader-Willi syndrome AngelMan syndrome
Deletions ( 70% cases) Deletion of Paternal genes after maternal gene silencing Deletion of Maternal genes after paternal gene silencing

Unipaternal disomy(UPD) (30%)

 UPD of maternal chromosome 15 UPD of paternal chromosome 15

Clinical features

Elevated Ghrelin levels: Loss of appetite control, obesity

Severe hypotonia

Short stature

Small hands and feet

Hypogonadotropic hypogonadism

Cognitive impairment

Short stature

Severe mental retardation with lack of speech

Stiff arm movements

Spastic, uncoordinated walk

Seizures and often inappropriate outbursts of laughter (Happy puppets)

Mnemonic:

Prader–Willi Syndrome: Paternal gene deletion (P for P)
Angelman syndrome: Maternal gene deletion (Mothers are Angels, Maternal gene deletion leads to Angelman syndrome)

Option B: Fragile X syndrome is caused due to trinucleotide repeat expansion of CGG in the long arm of chromosome X

Option D: Friedreich ataxia is caused by the expansion of a GAA trinucleotide repeat in the gene that encodes frataxin.

questions.text: A 20-year old male patient who is a known case of pulmonary tuberculosis presents with backache. Examination reveals localized tenderness in the T12-L1 vertebral areas, loss of power in both lower limbs, and bladder incontinence. On x-ray, paradiscal destruction of vertebrae is present.  Which of the following is the best management for the above patient?
questions.solution:
This patient who is a known case of pulmonary tuberculosis presents with backache, localized tenderness in the T12-L1 vertebral areas, loss of power in both lower limbs, incontinence of his bladder, and paradiscal destruction of vertebrae seen on X-ray is likely to have Pott's paraplegia. Anterolateral decompression and antitubercular treatment are the best management for the above patient with Pott's paraplegia.

Paradiscal areas are the most common site of vertebral involvement. The other patterns include central, posterior, and non-osseous involvement. 

Management of Pott’s paraplegia includes conservative management or surgery. 

Anti-tubercular chemotherapy forms the mainstay of treatment. The spine is put to absolute rest by a sling traction for the cervical spine, and bed rest for the dorso- lumbar spine. If paraplegia improves, conservative treatment is continued. Bracing is continued for a period of about 6 to 12 months.

Surgery is indicated in the following conditions:

  • Failed conservative management
  • Recurrence of the disease after treatment
  • Rapid onset paraplegia

Surgeries for Pott’s paraplegia include:

  • Antero-lateral decompression- surgery of choice for Pott’s paraplegia as it helps in the removal of both solid and liquid debris
  • Costotransversectomy- surgery indicated for paravertebral abscess
  • Laminectomy- indicated when the posterior parts of vertebrae are involved
  • Radical debridement and arthrodesis (Hongkong operation)

questions.text: A 50-year-old man complains of cramp-like pain in his calf for a month which increases with a downhill walk and decreases with an uphill walk. Pain is relieved on sitting or forward bending. What is the cause of pain in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario describes the characteristic features of neurogenic claudication, where the pain increases on the extension of the spine such as in walking downhill. It is relieved on sitting or forward flexion at the waist such as in an uphill walk.

It may be seen in cases of nerve compression from lumbar intervertebral disc prolapse or spinal stenosis. Symptoms become most prominent when there is a reduction of the interlaminar space; this occurs with prolonged standing when the spine is in an erect position.

Claudication pain may be of different types and can be differentiated as follows:

  • Vascular (intermittent) claudication pain is brought on by walking and is relieved by rest within 5 minutes. 
  • Claudication pain present on taking the first step of walking is classical for osteoarthritis. (Option A)
  • Neurogenic claudication occurs with changes in the position of the back such as bending forward and straightening. It takes more time to be relieved by rest (more than 5 minutes).

The most common symptom of peripheral obstructive vascular disease is intermittent claudication. It is usually felt in the calf when the superficial femoral artery is affected.

The distance that a patient is able to walk without pain or stopping is called claudication distance which varies only slightly from day to day. Such distance may even decrease further when the oxygen requirement of the muscles is increased as in cases like walking uphill, walking fast or carrying heavy weights.

Intermittent claudication is a feature of chronic arterial disease or occlusion of the artery. Classically, the muscle group affected by claudication is one anatomical level below the level of arterial disease.

Rest pain occurs when the occlusive disease progresses in severity and anaerobic respiration occurs even at rest. Though this pain is present during the day, it is exacerbated on lying down at night due to loss of gravity dependant perfusion of the foot. This may be relieved by hanging the foot out of the bed to restore the gravitational effects.

Intermittent claudication Neurogenic claudication Osteoarthritis
Pain after walking a certain distance Pain after walking or standing for some time Maximum pain on the first step.
Pain quickly relieved on resting. Pain relieved on flexion Pain relieved on resting.

questions.text: You notice the capnography of a patient showing the tracing below. Which of the following steps is best suited in his management?

choices.text: Stopping the inhaled anesthetic and administering dantrolene sodium
Extubation and re-intubation under proper visualization
Continue monitoring as the capnogram is normal

questions.solution:
The above capnographic waveform shows some carbon dioxide detected initially followed by the absence of carbon dioxide. This represents esophageal intubation. Extubation and re-intubation under proper visualization would be the best step in this situation.

Swallowed air in the stomach would cause the initial detection of CO2 which is soon washed out and the ETCO2 comes to zero. Also, breath sounds in the epigastrium are a sign of oesophageal intubation.

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: Exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

Other options:

Option A - Replacing the soda lime is done in case of rebreathing of CO2. This may be due to exhausted soda lime or incompetent expiratory valve in closed-circuit breathing systems. The capnographic waveform shows an elevated inspiratory baseline, which depicts rebreathing.

Option B- Stopping the inhaled anesthetic and administering dantrolene sodium would be indicated in patients with malignant hyperthermia. A dramatic increase in body temperature and muscle rigidity would normally be accompanying features. The increased metabolic rate caused by malignant hyperthermia causes a marked rise in ETCO2.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

questions.text: You would advise on-site chemical pre-treatment before incineration for all of the following biomedical waste except ____
questions.solution:
Urine bags do not have to undergo on-site chemical pre-treatment to sterilize before handing them over for incineration.

As per NACO or WHO guidelines, laboratory waste, microbiological waste, blood samples, blood bags should be sterilized with non-chlorinated chemicals on-site. After this, it should be handed over to the common bio-medical waste treatment and disposal facility for incineration.

questions.text: A 16-year-old woman was brought by her parents with sudden onset of blindness in both eyes. On examination, fundoscopy and cortical-evoked potentials were normal. On further probing the history, there were frequent fights between her parents, and the onset of blindness corresponded to one of their fights. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding this condition?

choices.text: Receiving support from others constitutes secondary gain
It is caused due to repression of conflicts in the unconscious mind
Patient is unconcerned about severe symptoms

questions.solution:
The above scenario is suggestive of conversion disorder. There is no organic neurological lesion present in such patients. The symptoms displayed cannot be explained by any neurological disease.

Conversion disorder is an acute and temporary loss or alteration in motor or sensory function triggered by psychosocial conflict. The patients tend to keep the psychological impact of the stressors in life repressed in their unconscious mind (option B). This stress is converted into physical symptoms such as non-epileptic seizures, paralysis, or blindness.

The patient's symptoms do not fit into the diagnosis of any neurological disorder and they cannot be explained by any neurological lesion — this is known as astasia abasia. The patients are unconcerned about even severe symptoms such as blindness (option C) — this is known as la belle indifference.

Patients achieve primary gain by keeping internal conflicts outside their awareness and then releasing them as physical symptoms. When the patients get advantages due to their symptoms, such as attention and care from the family, it is known as secondary gain (option A).

questions.text: Mrs. Rao, a 50-year-old woman with a 10-day history of nasal discharge, headache that increases on bending down, and pain over the medial canthus, now presents to the outpatient department with high-grade fever and chills, headache, and bilateral proptosis. On further inquiry, it is brought to light that the proptosis began in the right eye, and since yesterday, the left eye has also been affected. On examination, her pulse rate is 56 beats per minute, BP is 150/96 mm of Hg, the temperature is 102F.  There is periorbital edema, proptosis, and ophthalmoplegia. The pupillary response is sluggish. Fundoscopy reveals papilloedema.  Which of the following is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, with recurrent episodes of headache and pain over the medial canthus and repeated use of nasal decongestants, suggests that the patient was suffering from sinusitis which has most likely resulted in cavernous sinus thrombosis.

Cavernous sinus thrombosis (CST) is a septic thrombus formed in the cavernous sinus. It spreads from infection of the sinuses, teeth, ears, nose, and skin of the face. The contents of the cavernous venous sinus that may be affected include

  • Cavernous segment of the internal carotid artery
  • Perivascular sympathetic plexus
  • Abducens nerve (running through the Dorello’s canal)
  • Oculomotor nerve, trochlear nerve, and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve as part of the lateral wall. 

It presents as fever, severe headache, supraorbital pain, seizures, and edema in the mastoid region. Eye signs include proptosis, chemosis, and diplopia due to ophthalmoplegia from the involvement of oculomotor (CN-III), trochlear (CN-IV), and abducens nerve (CN-VI). Absence of corneal sensation due to the involvement of the ophthalmic division of trigeminal nerve (CN-Va). Ipsilateral ptosis, dilated pupil, and absence of direct and consensual pupillary right reflex due to oculomotor nerve palsy. Pulsatile proptosis occurs with the involvement of the internal carotid artery.

Clinically, the feature that strongly suggests the diagnosis is the pattern and bilaterality of the proptosis. In cavernous sinus thrombosis, proptosis is initially unilateral but soon becomes bilateral due to the spread of infection to the contralateral sinus through intercavernous communication. 

Investigation using brain MRI or MR venography should be done urgently. Following early diagnosis, management of cavernous sinus thrombosis typically includes IV broad-spectrum antibiotics and anticoagulants. 

Other options :

Options A- Retinoblastoma occurs in young children and presents with unilateral proptosis with leukocoria, squint, and defective vision.

Option B- Orbital pseudotumor also called idiopathic orbital inflammatory syndrome presents with unilateral proptosis with diplopia, and conjunctival chemosis. The inflammation is responsive to systemic corticosteroids.

Option C- Orbital cellulitis presents with unilateral proptosis with pain and decreased ocular motility.

questions.text: A primigravida mother presented to the emergency room in the early stage of labor. On abdominal examination, there is infra-umbilical flattening and fetal heart sounds are heard over the flanks. On per vaginal examination, the pelvis is found to be adequate. Image 1 shows the initial engagement of the head and Image 2 shows the position of the head after the internal rotation. What is the outcome that can be expected?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario shows that the presentation of the baby is occipito-posterior and image 1 shows that the head is engaged in the right occipito-posterior position. Image 2 shows that the head has undergone a short posterior rotation (1/8th of a circle). Since the pelvis is favorable, face-to-pubis delivery is possible in this mother.

Right occipito-posterior position (ROP) is the most common malposition, which occurs when the occiput is situated posteriorly over the sacroiliac joint, or directly over the sacrum. It is associated with the risk of delayed engagement of the head, prolonged labor due to transverse arrest, and the need for cesarean sections.

Features of the occipito-posterior position include infra-umbilical flattening and fetal heart sounds localized to the flank. The fetal parts are more prominently felt near the midline. The head engages through the right oblique diameter in ROP and the engaging AP diameter is occipitofrontal or suboccipito-frontal. 

In the majority of cases where the pelvis is favorable, uterine contractions are strong, and no complications arise, it results in normal vaginal delivery. With the occiput (back of the baby's head) as the leading part, it rotates approximately 3/8th of a circle towards the front, positioning itself behind the symphysis pubis. Due to the limitations of the neck's ability to withstand such torsion, the shoulders then rotate about 2/8th of a circle, aligning with the right oblique diameter. Consequently, the remaining progression of labor resembles that of the right occipitoanterior position in ROP.

When there is incomplete forward rotation during labor, the occiput undergoes an anterior rotation of approximately 1/8th of a circle, causing the sagittal suture to align with the bi-spinous diameter of the pelvis. Subsequent further anterior rotation is unlikely, and when labor arrest occurs in this position, it is referred to as deep transverse arrest.

In certain instances, the labor process does not involve rotation and instead leads to a condition called oblique posterior arrest. This occurs when both the sinciput (front part of the baby's head) and the occiput (back part of the head) touch the pelvic floor at the same time. This simultaneous contact is a result of the head being moderately deflected, preventing the occiput from rotating. The sagittal suture lies in the oblique diameter.

When the head is severely deflected during labor, it can result in posterior rotation, known as the occipitosacral position. Under favorable conditions, such as having a baby of average size, strong uterine contractions, and a well-suited pelvis (such as an anthropoid or spacious gynaecoid pelvis), spontaneous delivery may occur as face to pubis. However, in unfavorable situations where labor arrest occurs, it is referred to as occipitosacral arrest.

Indications of cesarean section in the occipito-posterior position include the arrest of labor, inadequate uterine contractions, fetal distress, and other obstetrical complications.

During the second stage of labor, if the anterior rotation of the occiput is completed, delivery occurs spontaneously or may require the application of ventouse or low forceps.

questions.text:
Which of the following substances inhibit oxidative phosphorylation in the electron transport chain?
  1. Atractyloside
  2. Arsenite
  3. 2,4-dinitrophenol
  4. Thermogenin
  5. Flouroacetate
questions.solution:
Atractyloside, 2,4-dinitrophenol, and Thermogenin inhibit oxidative phosphorylation in the electron transport chain.

Thermogenin and 2-4-dinitrophenol are uncouplers. Uncouplers act by increasing the permeability of the mitochondrial membrane to ions, thereby collapsing the proton gradient established by allowing the H+ to pass across without going through the ATP synthase enzyme complex. 2, 4 dinitrophenol is a synthetic uncoupler. Thermogenin is found naturally in the brown adipose tissue, whose function is heat generation, especially in newborns.

Atractyloside inhibits oxidative phosphorylation by inhibiting the transport of ADP into and ATP out of the mitochondria.

Oligomycin blocks oxidation and phosphorylation by stopping the flow of protons through the ATP synthase enzyme complex.

Inhibitors of ETC

COMPLEX INHIBITORS
Complex I Barbiturates
Complex II Malonate
Complex III Antimycin A and Dimercaprol
Complex IV Carbon monoxide, H2S, and Cyanide 

Arsenite and fluoroacetate are inhibitors of the TCA cycle

Related Pearl: Inhibitors of metabolic pathways

Inhibitors of glycolysis

Agent Enzyme
Iodoacetate Glyceraldehyde 3-phosphate dehydrogenase
Arsenate Phosphoglycerate kinase
Fluoride Enolase

 

Inhibitors of TCA cycle

Agent Enzyme
Fluoroacetate Aconitase

Arsenite

 α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase
Malonate Succinate dehydrogenase

 

Inhibitors of electron transport

Complex Inhibitors
Complex I Piercidin, Amobarbital, Rotenone
Complex II TTFA, Carboxin, Malonate
Complex III BAL, Antimycin A
Complex IV Hydrogen sulphide, Carbon monoxide, Cyanide

 

Inhibitors of oxidative phosphorylation

Agent Mechanism
Atractyloside Inhibits ADP and ATP Transporter
Oligomycin Blocks flow of protons through Fo complex

questions.text: A middle-aged woman comes to the OPD with complaints of weakness for the past 3 months. She is diagnosed to have microcytic hypochromic anemia. The stool microscopy reveals the following. Which of the following statements is true regarding the characteristic of the egg?

choices.text: Bile stained and floats in the saturated salt solution
Bile stained and does not float in the saturated salt solution
Non-bile stained and does not float in the saturated salt solution
Non-bile stained and floats in the saturated salt solution

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of iron deficiency anemia and the stool microscopy showing the egg is suggestive of infection by Ancylostoma duodenale. The eggs are non-bile stained and float in the saturated salt solution

The eggs are oval or elliptical in shape, colorless, and non-bile stained. It has a thin transparent hyaline shell membrane. The ovum is segmented with 4 to 8 blastomeres. There is a clear space between the segmented ovum and the eggshell. Eggs float in the saturated salt solution.

The adult worms live in the small intestines of infected persons, mostly in the jejunum. Humans are infected when filariform larvae in moist soil penetrate the skin or subcutaneous tissue. The larvae are then carried in the venous circulation to the heart and lungs, where they may cause mild transient pneumonitis or bronchitis. They migrate up the respiratory tract to the pharynx, are swallowed, and reach the small intestine producing epigastric pain, dyspepsia, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. 

A. duodenale ingests blood, secretes anticoagulants, and interferes with the absorption of iron, B12, and folic acid. This leads to iron deficiency anemia and protein-energy malnutrition resulting from blood loss. 

Albendazole (400 mg single dose) or mebendazole can be used for the treatment.

Related Pearl: Eggs in parasitology

questions.text: A pregnant woman at 14 weeks of gestation developed sudden-onset fever, rash, conjunctivitis, muscle and joint pain, malaise, and headache. On further evaluation, she tested positive for the Zika virus. Which of the following is not a mode of transmission of this virus?

choices.text: Bite of an infected Aedes mosquito

questions.solution:
The scenario given above describes Zika virus infection in the mother during pregnancy. Droplet transmission is not a mode of transmission of the Zika virus.

Zika virus is a flavivirus acquired mainly through the bite of an infected female Aedes aegypti mosquito. However, transmission can also occur perinatally, through sexual contact with an infected individual, breastfeeding, and blood transfusion. Congenital transmission of the Zika virus is known to cause fetal microcephaly. 

Although there have been a few cases reported of the Zika virus being transmitted from the infected mother to the infant by breastfeeding, the benefits of breastfeeding definitely outweigh its risks, and it is recommended for people to continue breastfeeding their infants. 

Congenital transmission of the Zika virus leads to fetal microcephaly. Zika virus infection during pregnancy may also lead to other malformations including limb contractures, high muscle tone, eye abnormalities, and hearing loss, known as congenital Zika syndrome.

Zika virus infection is characterized by influenza-like clinical signs including fever, headache, and malaise. An itchy, maculopapular rash, conjunctivitis, myalgia, and arthralgia usually accompany or follow those manifestations.

The complications of the Zika virus infection include Guillan-Barre syndrome, encephalitis, meningoencephalitis, peripheral neuropathies, and neurological birth defects. Other complications of pregnancy include preterm birth and miscarriage.

The disease is usually asymptomatic and self-resolving. People with mild symptoms should get plenty of rest, drink fluids, and treat pain and fever with common medicines. If symptoms worsen, they should seek medical care and advice. Pregnant women living in areas with Zika transmission or who develop symptoms of Zika virus infection should seek medical attention for laboratory testing and other clinical care.

Related Pearl: Taxonomy of Arboviruses

questions.text: Which of the following special stains is used for staining Treponema pallidum?
questions.solution:
Treponema pallidum can be demonstrated by the Levaditi staining method.

Silver impregnation smears used for Treponema pallidum can be stained by any of the following methods:

  • Fontana's method for staining films
  • Levaditi's method for tissue sections.

The image given below shows a hepatic tissue section stained using Levaditi stain.

Albert’s stain is one of three stains that can be used to demonstrate the volutin granules (metachromatic/ Babes-Ernst granules) of Corynebacterium diphtheriae. 

The two other stains used for this purpose are Neisser’s stain and Ponder’s stain. The bacilli are usually arranged in pairs or palisades or small groups, at various angles to each other, resembling the letters V or L. This has been called the chinese letter or cuneiform arrangement.

Related Pearl: Various stains and their applications in microbiology

A. Simple stains: Provides color contrast but gives same color to all bacteria and cells.

Type of stain Applications
Acidic stains

These include eosin, acid fuchsin, rose bengal, congo red, etc.

Used to stain pathological specimens
Basic stains.

Loeffler’s methylene blue stain is used in Quellung reaction. 

Polychrome methylene blue is used in McFadyean’s reaction.
Neutral stains

Wright and Giemsa stains are Romanowsky stains used to stain peripheral blood and bone marrow smears.  

Giemsa stain is used for histopathological diagnosis of malaria and other protozoan blood parasites.  

 

B. Differential stains: Imparts different colors to different bacteria. (These contain more than one stain).

Type of stain Applications
Gram stain: To differentiate between gram positive (stain purple/violet) and gram negative bacteria (stain pink or red).
Acid-fast stain:  Used in Ziehl–Neelsen staining technique for identification of acid–fast microorganisms such as M. tuberculosis, M. leprae, and Nocardia.
Fluorochrome staining: Auramine-rhodamine is used in fluorochrome staining for screening for tuberculosis.

C. Special stains:

Type of stain Applications
Staining volutin-containing organisms Corynebacterium diphtheriae stained by Albert’s stain. Green colored bacilli showing "chinese-letter" pattern, containing bluish-black metachromatic granules of cells.
Flagella stain Salmonella typhimurium stained by modified Ryu stain to show peritrichous flagella
Endospore stain Used in Schaeffer and Fulton staining technique to stain the endospores, where the primary stain is malachite green, and the counterstain is safranin.
Capsule stain Used in negative staining (Cryptococcus neoformans), McFadyean’s reaction, Polychrome methylene blue (anthrax bacilli).
Silver impregnation Fontana’s silver impregnation method used for staining treponeme and leptospire.
Silver staining Used in Grocott’s – Gomori’s methenamine silver stain. GMS stain is used to identify Pneumocystis jirovecii, which classically appear as crushed ping-pong balls.   Warthin–starry silver stain for spirochetes.
Calcofluor white staining The cell walls of fungi will bind the stain calcofluor white. It is especially useful for the identification of mucor and the causative agents of zygomycosis.  It is also used in staining acanthamoeba
Chance's staining For cell wall demonstration

questions.text: Which anti-hypertensive drug class is to be avoided in gout?
questions.solution:
Thiazides are avoided in patients with gout because they cause hyperuricemia and can precipitate acute attacks in susceptible patients.

Other adverse effects of thiazide diuretics include hyponatremia, hypomagnesemia and hypercalcemia. They also cause impaired glucose tolerance, and increased plasma levels of LDL and total cholesterol, and triglycerides. They can also cause erectile dysfunction and are thus not preferred for the treatment of hypertension in young males.

Other options:

Option A: The adverse effects associated with ACE inhibitors include a persistent dry cough, hyperkalemia, and angioedema. Angioedema refers to the sudden onset swelling of the nose, throat, larynx, lips, and tongue. ACE inhibitors can also cause acute renal failure in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis. They have a teratogenic potential and must be stopped as soon as possible when a pregnancy is diagnosed.

Option B: Immediate-release formulations of nifedipine can cause adverse effects such as headache, flushing, dizziness, and worsening of myocardial ischemia due to tachycardia. However, these effects are not seen with sustained-release formulations. Peripheral edema can be seen in some patients due to increased hydrostatic pressure in the lower limbs due to precapillary dilation and postcapillary constriction. Verapamil can also cause constipation.

Option C: The adverse effects of non-selective beta-blockers include bronchospasm, fatigue, and sleep disturbances (such as insomnia, nightmares), and blunting of physiological responses to hypoglycemia.

Note: In addition to thiazide diuretics, even loop diuretics can cause hyperuricemia. Other adverse effects of loop diuretics include hyponatremia, hypovolemia, and circulatory collapse. Because of the increased excretion of Ca2+ and Mg2+, they can cause hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. They are thus avoided in women with postmenopausal osteoporosis. They can also cause ototoxicity, hyperglycemia, and increased plasma levels of LDL and total cholesterol, and triglycerides.

Related Pearl: Effect of diuretics on excretion of electrolytes

Diuretics Sodium Potassium Calcium
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors ↑ ↑↑ No change
Osmotic diuretics ↑↑ ↑ ↑
Loop diuretics ↑↑ ↑↑ ↑↑
Thiazides ↑ ↑↑ ↓
Epithelial sodium channel blockers ↑ ↓ ↓
Aldosterone antagonists ↑ ↓ Insufficient data

Acute effects of thiazides on Ca2+ excretion are variable but when administered chronically, it decreases Ca2+ excretion.

Related Pearl: Site and mechanism of action of diuretics

Diuretics  Site of action  

Enzyme/receptor/transporter inhibited 
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors   Proximal tubule   Carbonic anhydrase  
Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter
Thiazides Distal convoluted tubule  Na+- Cl- symporter
Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC)

questions.text:
Which of the following are the core symptoms of autism spectrum disorder?
  1. Deficit in nonverbal social interactions
  2. Anxiety when the daily routine is disturbed
  3. Defect in language development
  4. Intellectual disability
  5. Ritualistic behavior
questions.solution:
Deficits in nonverbal communication, anxiety when the daily routine is disrupted, and ritualistic behaviour are core symptoms of autism spectrum disorder.

Intellectual disability and defects in language development may be present in patients with autism spectrum disorder, but they are not core symptoms — that is, the diagnosis of autism spectrum disorder can be made even without them. 

The core symptoms of autism spectrum disorder have been divided as:

Persistent deficits in social communication and social interactions

  • Delayed development of a social smile
  • Poor eye contact
  • Atypical attachment behaviour: may not acknowledge the most influential people in life
  • Deficits in reciprocal social skills and nonverbal communication
  • Unable to gauge the intentions of others, and thus may lack empathy

Restricted, repetitive patterns of behaviour, interests, or activities

  • Restricted exploration while playing
  • Atypical/ritualistic use of toys and objects, such as lining them up
  • Rigid, repetitive routine
  • Anxiety when the fixed routine is disrupted
  • Enjoying spinning and seeing the water flow
  • Stereotypic behavior

A significant number of children with autism spectrum disorder develop handedness later than expected. Some children may also have disturbances in achieving language milestones. 30% of children with autism spectrum disorder also have intellectual disability.

questions.text: To record a radial pulse, you apply sustained gentle pressure with the pads of the fingers just enough to palpate the pulse against the radius. Which of the following mechanoreceptors, that is present in the epidermis, responds to sustained pressure and touch?
questions.solution:
The mechanoreceptor that responds to sustained pressure and touch is the Merkel disc. It is a slow-adapting receptor made of expanded dendritic endings present in the epidermis. 

Other options-

Option B- Meissner's corpuscles respond to low-frequency vibration. They are rapidly adapting dendrites encapsulated in connective tissue present below the epidermis.  

Option C- Ruffini corpuscles respond to stretch and vibration. They are slow-adapting enlarged dendritic endings with elongated capsules that are present in the dermis of the skin.

Option D- Pacinian corpuscles respond to high-frequency vibration and deep pressure. They are rapidly adapting receptors. They are large encapsulated nerve endings with concentric layers of connective tissue that have an onion-skin appearance and are present in the dermis. 

Related Pearl: Sensory Receptors

Related Pearl: Slow vs rapidly adapting receptors

Slow adapting Rapidly adapting receptors
Also called tonic receptors Also called phasic receptors
They are expanded on free nerve endings. They are encapsulated nerve endings.
Responds to steady stimulus Respond to rate of change of stimulus
With steady stimulus, tonic receptors keep responding steadily. With steady stimulus, receptor responds initially but stops or adapts rapidly.
Examples: Merkel's disc, Ruffini's end organs, Joint capsule, Muscle spindle, Golgi tendon organs Examples: Pacinian corpuscle, Meissner's corpuscles, Hair end organs

questions.text: A 45-year-old female patient with complaints of recurrent bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain presents with the following finding. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image is of erythema nodosum. Along with the history of recurrent bloody diarrhea and abdominal pain, the patient is most likely to have inflammatory bowel disease. 

Erythema nodosum is a condition in which, tender and painful red nodules appear on the anterior part of the legs. They fade over a period of weeks but never ulcerate. Erythema nodosum is a type IV hypersensitivity reaction. The underlying pathology is septal panniculitis without vasculitis. Etiological factors of erythema nodosum include:

  • Infections such as group A β-hemolytic streptococcus infection, tuberculosis, leprosy, lymphogranuloma venereum, toxoplasmosis
  • Drugs such as oral contraceptives and sulphonamides
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Inflammatory bowel disease

questions.text: A 48-year-old male patient presents with the given finding. He also has right-sided hemiplegia and exaggerated reflexes on the right side. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given picture shows LMN facial palsy on the left side. The presence of right-sided hemiplegia and exaggerated reflexes indicates right UMN palsy. Together, these two point to the diagnosis of Millard-Gubler syndrome.

Millard-Gubler syndrome occurs due to a lesion in the ventral pons. It presents with ipsilateral facial palsy due to the involvement of facial nerve fibers leaving the brainstem, and contralateral hemiparesis due to damage to the descending corticospinal tracts. In addition, there is a weakness of the lateral rectus muscle due to damage to the abducens nerve fascicle.

The other brainstem syndrome that occurs at the level of the pons is Foville's syndrome. It occurs due to a lesion in the dorsal part of the pons. The clinical presentation is similar to Millard-Gubler syndrome, except it presents with complete ipsilateral gaze palsy due to abducens nucleus lesion.

Related Pearl: Medullary syndromes and Weber syndrome

Syndrome

Vessel involved

Clinical features

Medial Medullary syndrome / Dejerine syndrome

Vertebral artery/Anterior spinal artery
  • C/L loss of conscious proprioception
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • I/L tongue paralysis

Lateral Medullary syndrome / Wallenberg syndrome

Vertebral artery>Posterior inferior cerebellar artery
  • C/L loss of pain/temperature on the body
  • I/L loss of pain/temperature on face
  • Ataxia
  • Nystagmus
  • Vertigo
  • Horner's syndrome
  • dysphagia
  • Ipsilateral bulbar paralysis
  • Loss of gag reflex

Weber's syndrome

Posterior cerebral artery
  • I/L Oculomotor nerve palsy - ptosis with fixed dilated pupil pointed down and out
  • C/L hemiplegia
  • C/L paralysis of the lower face

C/L- Contralateral

I/L-Ipsilateral

questions.text: Which of the following drugs cannot be used for pneumonia caused by Pseudomonas?
questions.solution:
Cefpodoxime does not have anti-Psedumonas activity and so cannot be used for pneumonia caused by Pseudomonas.

The antipseudomonal cephalosporins include ceftazidime, ceftolozane, cefepime, and cefpirome. Cefepime and cefpirome also have excellent action against organisms that might be resistant to other cephalosporins such as Enterobacter. Thus, they are also called fourth-generation cephalosporins.

Other cell-wall inhibitors that are active against Pseudomonas are:

  • Extended-spectrum penicillins:
    • Carboxypenicillins: carbenicillin, ticarcillin 
    • Ureidopenicillins: piperacillin, mezlocillin
  • Carbapenams: imipenem, carbapenem, doripenem
  • Monobactum: aztreonam

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman presented with a bulge protruding from the vagina that increases in size on coughing and sneezing. She delivered her first baby six weeks back. What would be the most appropriate management in her case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to the diagnosis of pelvic organ prolapse. Ring pessaries are the preferred management in the case of prolapse in the postnatal period.

Pelvic organ prolapse is a condition where the pelvic organs herniate into the vagina due to weakness of the supports of the uterus. The patient may present with a feeling of a bulge protruding through the vaginal opening. Prolapse is aggravated by straining so the bulge increases on sneezing and coughing. It reduces on lying down, or by manual reduction. It may be accompanied by micturition disturbances like difficulty in initiating micturition or frequency of micturition. Rectal symptoms and coital difficulties can be present depending on the degree of prolapse.

Uterine prolapses following delivery should be managed conservatively for 3-4 months, with abdominal exercises, massage, and perineal exercises.  Young women rapidly improve if appropriate conservative methods are employed. If surgery is performed within 6 months of delivery, there is a high chance of recurrence of the prolapse.

A ring pessary is used for patients who cannot be surgically managed, such as pregnant patients, patients in the puerperium, and very elderly women unfit for surgery. It is used in adjunct with pelvic floor physiotherapy. Pessaries provide mechanical support to the pelvic organs. After being placed, they need to be changed every 3 months.

Option A: Fothergill's repair also known as Manchester's operation is suitable for women under 40 years who are desirous of retaining their menstrual and reproductive functions. It involves anterior colporrhaphy with amputation of the cervix. The Mackenrodt ligaments are sutured in the front of the cervix and colpoperineorrhaphy is done. It increases the risk of cervical incompetence leading to recurrent abortions and preterm deliveries. Shirodkar's modification of Fothergill's repair avoids cervical amputation, hence subsequent pregnancy complications are avoided.  

Option B: Le Forte's repair: This is preferred only in elderly women with advanced prolapse, or those unfit for surgery. Women wanting an active sexual life are poor candidates for this procedure as it creates an adhesive area in the midline. It may also lead to stress incontinence.

Option D: Vaginal hysterectomy with pelvic floor repair is the ideal management of genital prolapse in women >40 years of age, those who have completed their families and do not wish to preserve menstrual and child-bearing function.

Related Pearl: Management of Uterine prolapse

Category Treatment
Nulliparous or congenital prolapse 

Abdominal sling operations:

  • Abdominal wall cervicopexy
  • Shirodkar’s abdominal sling operation
  • Khanna’s abdominal sling operation
Pregnancy and postnatal period
  • Ring pessary (up to 16 weeks period of gestation)
  • Pelvic floor exercises
<40 years            
  • Fothergill's repair (Manchester operation)
  • Shirodkar's procedure
>40 years - with completed family  Vaginal hysterectomy and pelvic floor repair 
>60 years - unfit for surgery

These are done if the patient doesn't want to retain sexual function

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect about transfusion-related acute lung injury?

choices.text: Mediated by anti-HLA antibodies in recipient plasma
Usually develops within 6 hours after transfusion
Plasma transfusion from nulliparous females decreased incidence

questions.solution:
Transfusion-related acute lung injury (TRALI) is mediated by anti-HLA antibodies in the donor plasma, not the recipient plasma. 

TRALI is characterized by the development of hypoxia due to noncardiogenic pulmonary edema (option C) following a transfusion. It usually develops within 6 hours (option B) following transfusion, but delayed cases can present up to 72 hours. TRALI occurs due to transfusion of donor plasma that has high-titers of anti-HLA class II antibodies. Anti-HLA class I and anti-human neutrophil antigen antibodies are also involved. 

Transfusion of plasma and platelet concentrates from male donors and nulliparous females has been shown to reduce the incidence of TRALI significantly (option D). Recipient risk factors that increase the incidence of TRALI include smoking, alcohol consumption, and shock. Once features of TRALI develop in a patient, the treatment is supportive.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the classical hemorrhagic disease of the newborn?
questions.solution:
The age of onset of classical hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is 2-7 days. 

Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is caused by a transient deficiency of vitamin K–dependent factors, factors II, VII, IX, and X.

Causes include:

  • Lack of free vitamin K from the mother
  • Absence of the bacterial intestinal flora normally responsible for the synthesis of vitamin K.

Classical hemorrhagic disease of the newborn occurs early in the newborn period, typically between day 2 and 7 of life, and most often in exclusively breastfeeding infants who did not receive vitamin K prophylaxis at birth.

Early-onset vitamin K deficiency bleeding (after birth but in first 24 hr) occurs if the mother has been treated chronically with certain drugs that interfere with vitamin K absorption or function. (Option C)

Late-onset vitamin K deficiency bleeding (1-6 months of life) is usually associated with conditions that feature malabsorption of the fat-soluble vitamin K, such as cystic fibrosis, neonatal hepatitis, or biliary atresia. 

Hemorrhagic disease of the newborn is responsive to and prevented by vitamin K therapy (0.5-1 mg of phytonadione).

Related Pearl: Coagulation Pathways and its Abnormalities

Test results Inherited causes Acquired causes

Evaluates extrinsic pathway factors

Normal PT: 11-13 seconds

Mild vitamin K deficiency

Liver disease

Normal aPTT: 25-35 seconds

Factor XII, prekallikrein, or HMW kininogen deficiency

Prolonged PT + prolonged aPTT

Prothrombin (II), fibrinogen (I), factors V and factor X deficiencies

Disseminated intravascular coagulation (DIC)

Severe liver disease
