questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presented with a lump in her right breast, and she was advised to undergo a mammogram. The radiologist reported the mammographic lesion found as BIRADS grade 2. What will be the management plan for this patient?
questions.solution:
The management plan for this patient would be to undergo routine annual screening.

A Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BIRADS) score of 2 means that it is a benign lesion, and for these patients, annual screening is advised.

Related Pearl: BIRADS - Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System

Breast Imaging Reporting and Data System (BI-RADS) standardizes the reporting for mammography and ultrasonography and helps guide decision making:

Category Definition % Chances of Malignancy Follow-up
0 Incomplete assessment Not applicable Additional imaging evaluation
1 Negative Essentially 0% Annual screening
2 Benign finding Essentially 0% Annual screening
3 Probably benign finding >0% but ≤2% 6 monthly mammograms for the next 2 years
4

 

4A: low level of suspicion for malignancy >2% to ≤10%

4B: moderate suspicion for malignancy >10% to ≤50%

4C: high suspicion for malignancy >50% to <95%

 Biopsy
5 Highly suggestive of malignancy  ≥95% Appropriate action should be taken 
6 Known biopsy-proven malignancy Appropriate treatment

questions.text: You are a research associate working on clinical trials of a new drug for COVID-19. During which phase of a clinical trial would you receive feedback from practising clinicians about adverse effects of the new drug?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects of a newly marketed drug are detected during Phase IV of a clinical trial.

Phase IV of a clinical trial involves postmarketing surveillance and data-gathering studies after a certain drug has been marketed for general use. This includes the unknown adverse effects of the drug, drug compliance, and drug interactions. This phase includes all the patients who are on treatment with the drug in question and has no fixed duration.

Other options:

Option B: Phase III of a clinical trial is also called a multisite trial. It is done on patients who have been diagnosed to have the disease which the drug claims to treat. This phase is done for the confirmation of the efficacy of the newly developed drug in a larger population. Phase III is randomized and controlled and may be blinded.

Option C: Phase II of a clinical trial also involves patients diagnosed with the disease for which the new drug has been developed. Efficacy and dose-ranging of the drug are assessed during this phase of the trial.

Option D: Phase I of a clinical trial involves testing a new drug on healthy volunteers to assess its safety and tolerability.

Related Pearl: Phases of Clinical Trials

(First in human)

(First in patient)

Phase III

(Multi-site trial)

Phase IV

(Post-marketing)

50 - 500 

500 - 3000

Usually healthy volunteers

Patients with the target disease

Patients with the target disease

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Randomized and controlled trial; may be blinded

Usually the observational or open-label

Therapeutic exploration and dose-ranging: To determine efficacy and dose-ranging

 

Therapeutic confirmation and comparison: Indications are finalized and guidelines for therapeutic use are formulated. Monitoring of adverse reactions is done. 

Postmarketing surveillance: To monitor drug interactions, compliance and long-term or rare side effects

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to you with complaints of difficulty in hearing in the right ear which is slowly progressive. She also has tinnitus which is pulsatile in nature. An audible bruit is heard over mastoid when auscultation with a stethoscope. Her Rinne test was negative.  A tumor of the middle ear is suspected. All of the following signs can be seen by otoscopy except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture of a woman with progressive conductive hearing loss, tinnitus and audible bruit heard over the mastoid suggests a diagnosis of a ‘glomus tumor’. The Phelp sign on CECT scan (not otoscopy) is the erosion of the spine of the carotico-jugular crest, seen in glomus jugulare tumors. It is intact in glomus tympanicum.

The cell of origin in the glomus tumor is paraganglionic cells (not perivascular cells). These cells are derived from the neural crest. They are paragangliomas of the glomus bodies found in the mastoid.

Glomus tumor is the most common benign neoplasm of the middle ear.

It is of 2 types:

  • Glomus jugulare: It arises from the dome of the jugular bulb causing neurological signs of IXth to XIIth cranial nerve involvement.
  • Glomus tympanicum: It arises from the promontory of the middle ear and causes aural symptoms, sometimes with facial paralysis.

The rule of 10 is seen in the glomus tumor. It comprises of

  • 10% familial
  • 10% multicentric
  • 10% functional

It is 5 times more common in women. Common presenting features include:

  • Progressive conductive hearing loss
  • Tinnitus in glomus tumors is pulsatile, of swishing character, synchronous with a pulse, and can be temporarily stopped by carotid pressure.
  • Audible bruit heard over the mastoid with a stethoscope in all stages

Investigations would include:

  • Phelp's sign-on CECT scan helps to distinguish glomus tympanicum from the glomus jugulare tumor by identification of caroticojugular spine which is eroded in the latter.
  • MRI gives the soft tissue extent of the tumor.
  • Four vessel angiography is necessary when the CT head shows the involvement of a jugular bulb, carotid artery, or intradural extension.
  • A biopsy is never done since it’s a highly vascular tumor.

 The below given image shows a triangular red coloured glomus tumour behind the tympanic membrane in the middle ear.

Related Pearl: Signs in Glomus Tumors

Sign
Seen on
What is seen
Rising sun
Otoscopy
Tumor arising from floor
Brown sign
Otoscopy
On increasing the ear canal pressure, tumor pulsates and then blanches
Phelp sign
CT

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient is undergoing focused parathyroidectomy. After removal of parathyroid adenoma, the surgeon can confirm that there are no hyperactive parathyroid tissue left if the intraoperative PTH,
questions.solution:
A drop of intraoperative PTH to <50% of the preoperative PTH in 10 minutes suggests a single-gland disease. This is known as Miami criteria.

About 80% of the patients with primary hyperparathyroidism have single adenoma, and therefore undergo a focused or minimally invasive parathyroidectomy, where the localized abnormal parathyroid gland is removed. Once the gland is removed, the surgeon can ensure that there is no other hyperactive gland remaining by performing an intraoperative PTH assay.

It is based on the principle that the half-life of the PTH is 3-5 minutes. In a single-gland disease, once the gland is removed the PTH levels should drop to <50% of the preoperative PTH level within 10 minutes.

However, if there is no drop in PTH level, then a multi-gland disease is suspected and the surgery is converted to a bilateral neck exploration.

questions.text:
Match the given images with their respective names.
  1. Velamentous placenta
  2. Succenturiate placenta
  3. Circumvallate placenta
  4. Battledore placenta
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-a, 2-d, 3-b, 4-c.

Image 1 shows a velamentous placenta in which the cord is attached to the membranes. The cord vessels travel between the membranes for some distance before reaching the placenta. If these vessels are present over the membranes lying near the internal os in front of the presenting part, it is called vasa previa. The rupture of the membranes involving the overlying these vessels leads to vaginal bleeding of the fetal blood.

 

Image 2 is a Battledore placenta, where the cord is attached to the margin of the placenta. When it is associated with a placenta previa or a low-lying placenta, there can be cord compression, fetal anoxia, and fetal death.

 

Image 3 shows a succenturiate placenta. It is characterized by the presence of one or more small lobes of the placenta placed at varying distances from the main placental margins. A leash of blood vessels connects these accessory cotyledons to the main placenta. If these vessels are absent, then it is called placenta spuria. If this lobe is retained postpartum, there can be primary or secondary postpartum hemorrhage, subinvolution of uterus, uterine sepsis, polyp formation.

 

Image 4 is a circumvallate placenta. It is a type of placenta extrachorialis. There is a smaller chorionic plate as compared to the basal plate. The amnion and chorion fold and roll back on themselves to form a ring on the fetal side.

There is an increased chance of abortions, hydrorrhea gravidarum (excessive watery discharge per vagina), antepartum hemorrhage, growth retardation of the fetus, preterm delivery, and retained placenta and membranes.

questions.text: A 37-year-old man who works on a cattle farm presented with right upper quadrant pain and intermittent low-grade fever for the past 2 weeks. On examination, he is febrile and has mild tenderness in the right upper quadrant. CT scan revealed the following findings. Which of the following findings if present would form an indication for the choice of PAIR ( puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration) procedure?
questions.solution:
The case scenario with the CT scan showing a 'water lily sign' is suggestive of a hydatid cyst  and PAIR procedure is indicated in infected cysts. 

Echinococcus granulosus is the most common causative agent in hydatid cysts. The hydatid cyst usually develops three weeks after the infection. The cyst is surrounded by a fibrous capsule called the pericyst that is derived from the host tissue. The cyst wall is composed of two layers, ectocyst (outer gelatinous membrane), and endocyst (inner germinal membrane). Ectocyst is a laminated membrane, which is acellular. It helps in the passage of nutrients. The endocyst helps in producing the laminated membrane and scoleces.

The brood capsules are cellular masses in the hydatid fluid which consists of scoleces. In a definitive host, these scoleces develop into adult tapeworm while in the intermediate hosts these develop into new hydatid cysts. The brood capsules are attached to the endocyst by a pedicle or stalk. The brood capsules may mature and detach from the mother cyst and become the daughter cysts, which are an exact replica of the mother cysts.

The freed brood capsules and scoleces present in the hydatid fluid are called hydatid sand.

The image below shows the cross section of the hydatid cyst.

The first/initial imaging test is USG, and a CT scan can be used to diagnose the condition. CT scan is the best imaging modality for hydatid cysts. It shows the presence of a space-occupying lesion with a smooth outline with septa. CT scan has an accuracy of 98% in the detection of hydatid cysts and higher sensitivity to demonstrate the daughter cysts and extra-hepatic cysts. 
The indirect hemagglutination test and enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) have a sensitivity of 80% overall and are the initial screening tests of choice.

Management:

Asymptomatic and inactive cysts are managed conservatively and monitored by ultrasound. Active cysts should first be treated by a full course of albendazole. Procedures used for treatment include PAIR, pericystectomy, and laparoscopic marsupialization of the cyst.

PAIR is a minimally invasive technique that complements or replaces surgical treatment. It is done after adequate drug treatment with albendazole or praziquantel. It involves puncture, aspiration of the cystic fluid, injection of 95% ethanol solution or hypertonic saline, and re-aspiration of the solution after 5 minutes. Puncture is done under ultrasound guidance.

 

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: A 30-year-old lady presents with complaints of inability to conceive for the past 2 years. Physical examination is unremarkable. A semen analysis of the husband revealed no abnormalities. Hysterosalpingography is done and it shows the following picture. What is the next step of management that can be done for this patient?
questions.solution:
The next step of management that can be done in this patient is to perform transvaginal 3D ultrasonography.

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) cannot accurately distinguish between the septate and bicornuate uterus. HSG provides excellent information about the interior contour of the uterine cavity, but not the external uterine contour. 

In case of bicornuate uterus, the intercornual angle >105 degrees and it is <75 degrees incase of a septate uterus. Unfortunately, the majority of angles of divergence between the horns fall between 75 and 105 degrees leading to overlapping between the two anomalies on HSG.

Transvaginal 3D ultrasonography (3D TV US) is done to differentiate between the bicornuate uterus and a septate uterus and is recommended for the assessment of patients with a suspected uterine anomaly. Pelvic MRI without contrast also provides excellent delineation of both internal and external uterine contours. It should be reserved for patients for whom 3D TV US is not possible.

A bicornuate uterus is characterized by two separate endometrial cavities, that may communicate with each other and a single uterine cervix. It is caused by the incomplete fusion of the Mullerian ducts. Failure of fusion may extend to the cervix, resulting in a complete bicornuate uterus, or may be partial, causing a milder abnormality. 

On HSG, the bicornuate uterus is seen as widely diverging horns with an intercornual angle > 105 degrees. However, MR imaging is necessary to define the external or fundal contour. 

Metroplasty is done for women with recurrent pregnancy loss from no other identifiable cause.

A septate uterus is characterized by the presence of a septum in the endometrial cavity. It is caused by the failure of the medial segments of the Mullerian ducts to regress, creating a permanent septum within the uterine cavity. The septum can project minimally from the fundus or can extend completely to the cervical os. On HSG, the intercornual angle is < 75 degrees.

Hysteroscopic septum resection is done for women with recurrent pregnancy loss.

Related Pearl: Mullerian Anomalies

 

Class Mullerian anomaly Reason/Feature Treatment Complications
I Uterine hypoplasia or uterine agenesis Underdeveloped or non-developed paramesonephric duct
  • Infertility treatment -surrogacy 
  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia
 Infertility

 
II Unicornuate uterus Non-developed paramesonephric duct Excision of rudimentary horn, if any  
  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text:
A 65-year-old diabetic woman presents with painless loss of vision. The ocular findings are shown in the image below. Which of the following is true about this condition?
  1. Painless progressive loss of vision
  2. Iris shadow is absent
  3. Visual acuity does not improve on pin-hole testing
  4. Black spots against red glow on distant direct ophthalmoscopy
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the above image are suggestive of an immature senile cataract. Here, iris shadows are present on examination.

An immature senile cataract is characterized by partial opacification of the lens. The cuneiform and cupuliform patterns of opacification may be seen which later become diffuse and irregular. The lens appears greyish-white. Both immature senile cataract and nuclear sclerosis without cataract present with painless progressive loss of vision and appear grey in color on oblique illumination examination. They can be differentiated based on the following points:

  Immature senile cataract Nuclear sclerosis
Iris shadow Present Absent

Distant direct ophthalmoscopy

Black spots against red glow are observed

No black spots are seen against the red glow

Slit-lamp examination

Areas of cataractous cortex seen

Clear lens with nuclear sclerosis seen

Visual acuity on pin-hole testing

Does not improve

Usually improves

 

Related Pearl: Maturation of Cortical Cataract

1. Stage of lamellar separation 

2. Stage of incipient cataract- cuneiform and cupuliform patterns can be made out at this stage.

 

3. Immature senile cataract: 

  • The lens is greyish white.
  • Clear cortex is still present, so iris shadow is visible
  • Untreated immature cataracts can progress and develop into intumescent cataracts as a result of swelling and congestion of the lens due to degeneration of lens proteins.

 

4. Mature cortical cataract/ Ripe cataract 

  • The opacification is complete
  • The lens is pearly white

 

 

5. Morgagnian hypermature cataract

  • The whole cortex liquefies and the lens is converted into a bag of milky fluid.
  • The small, brownish nucleus settles at the bottom, altering its position with a change in the position of the head.

questions.text:
During a central line insertion, the patient suffers a pleural puncture and develops breathing difficulty and sharp pain. There is an absence of breath sounds on the right side. A chest X-ray is done and appears as shown below. A needle is inserted in the 2nd intercostal space as an emergency measure. However, the breathing difficulty persists and a decision to insert an intercostal drain is taken. You would insert the chest drain into the triangle that lies _________.
  1. Posterior to the midaxillary line
  2. Anterior to the mid-axillary line
  3. Above the level of the nipple
  4. Below the level of the nipple
  5. Above and Medial to the pectoralis muscle
  6. Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and chest X-ray is suggestive of tension pneumothorax. The safest site for insertion of a chest drain is the triangle of safety which lies:

  • Anterior to the mid-axillary line;
  • Above the level of the nipple;
  • Below and lateral to the pectoralis major muscle.

This will be present in the fifth intercostal space.

Pneumothorax refers to the collection of air between the lung and chest wall causing the lung to collapse. Tension pneumothorax develops when a "one-way valve" air leak occurs either from the lung or through the chest wall. Air is sucked into the thoracic cavity without any means of escape, completely collapsing and then compressing the affected lung.

Tension pneumothorax is characterized by chest pain, tachypnea, tachycardia, hypotension, tracheal deviation away from the side of injury, unilateral absence of breath sound, cyanosis, and neck vein distension.

Tension pneumothorax is a clinical diagnosis, and treatment should never be delayed waiting for radiological confirmation.

Treatment consists of immediate decompression, initially by rapid insertion of a large-bore cannula on the affected side.

Due to the variable thickness of the chest wall, kinking of the catheter, and other technical or anatomic complications, needle decompression may not always be successful. In this case, finger thoracostomy is an alternative approach and is recommended as the next best step. 

Tube thoracostomy is mandatory after needle or finger decompression of the chest and is the definitive management.

The technique of drain insertion includes the following:

  • The area should be thoroughly sterilized before the procedure.
  • Adequate local anesthesia to include the pleura.
  • Sharp dissection should be done to cut only the skin.
  • Blunt dissection with artery forceps down through the muscle layers; which involve the serratus anterior and the intercostals.
  • An oblique tract is made so that the skin incision and the hole in the parietal pleura do not overlie each other and so that the drain is in a short tunnel, which reduces the chance of entraining air.
  • A drain for pneumothorax and haemothorax should aim towards the apex of the lung.
  • A drain for pleural effusion or empyema should be nearer the base.
  • The drain should pass over the upper edge of the rib to avoid injury to the neurovascular bundle that lies beneath the rib. 
  • A vertical mattress suture is inserted for later wound closure. This is important for pneumothorax management but not required if the drain is for empyema (provided there is the adherence of the pleura) because that tract should lie open.
  •  The drain should be connected to an underwater seal device which functions as a one-way valve.
  • Do not attach to a suction device at another end because it may worsen the air leak if the lung is fragile or might even cause a shift of mediastinum if the lung doesn't expand well
  • After completion, check the position of the drain by taking a chest radiograph.

questions.text:
Which of the following is true regarding the given statements:

Assertion: Diffusion capacity for carbon monoxide(CO) called DLCO is measured as an index of diffusing capacity of the lung.

Reason: The transfer of CO is not limited by perfusion but by diffusion.

choices.text: Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion
Both assertion and reason are true but the reason is not the correct explanation of the assertion
Assertion is true and reason is false
Assertion is false and reason is true

questions.solution:
Both assertion and reason are true and the reason is the correct explanation of the assertion. 

The diffusion capacity of the lungs is measured with carbon monoxide (CO) called DLCO because its uptake is diffusion-limited. Carbon monoxide (CO) is taken up by hemoglobin in the red blood cells at such a high rate that the partial pressure of CO in the capillaries stays very low. Blood usually stays for only 0.75 s in the pulmonary capillaries, and equilibrium is not reached in this. Therefore, at rest, the transfer of CO is not limited by perfusion but by diffusion. 

The diffusing capacity of the lung for a given gas is directly proportional to the surface area of the alveolar-capillary membrane and inversely proportional to its thickness.

In this test, a small amount of CO is used to measure the alveolar gas exchange during a 10-second breath-hold. The CO in exhaled breath is then analyzed and the quantity of CO that crosses the alveolar membrane is determined. The normal value of DLco at rest is about 25 mL/min/mm Hg.

DLCO is decreased in patients with:

  • Interstitial lung disease
  • Emphysema (chronic bronchitis usually have normal DLCO)

DLCO is increased in patients with:

  • Obesity
  • Asthma
  • Pulmonary hemorrhage
  • Exercise

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient was infused 1500 mL of 2% dextrose. His body weight is 82 Kgs, and BMI is 26.5 Kg/m2. Which of the following Darrow-Yannet diagrams correctly represents the state of distribution of the body fluids after infusion? (The graph A is the normal state, while the dotted lines in graphs B to D, indicates altered distribution. The arrows indicate the direction of change).
questions.solution:
2% Dextrose is a hypotonic solution. Infusion of hypotonic solution causes the body fluids to re-distribute as depicted by the Darrow-Yannet diagram, marked C.

When a hypotonic solution is infused, the osmolarity of the extracellular fluid decreases, and the volume of ECF increases. The water shifts from ECF to ICF, until the osmolarity of both sides becomes equal. This results in increased volume and decrease osmolarity of ICF as well.

Similar changes are seen in water retention, as in SIADH.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: A 38-year-old pregnant woman undergoes a quadruple test, which shows elevated levels of hCG and inhibin-A, and reduced levels of unconjugated estriol and maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein. The given findings suggest _______
questions.solution:
Elevated levels of hCG and inhibin-A, reduced levels of MSAFP (maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein), and unconjugated estriol in a quadruple test suggest trisomy 21/Down's syndrome.

The quadruple screening test is the measurement of maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP), unconjugated estriol, hCG, and inhibin-A. It is ideally done in the second trimester, during 15-20 weeks of gestation. The abnormalities seen on the quadruple screen are tabulated below:

  Trisomy 21 Trisomy 18 Neural tube defect or abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
β hCG High  Low Normal
Inhibin A High

Normal /Low

 Normal

Various antenatal screening tests for aneuploidy are as follows:

Dual test (1st trimester) Triple test (2nd trimester) Quadruple test
(2nd trimester)

1. Beta HCG 

2. PAPPA (Pregnancy-associated plasma protein A)

This can be combined with nuchal translucency by USG

1. Beta HCG 

2. Unconjugated estriol 

3. MSAFP  

1. Beta HCG 

2. Unconjugated estriol 

3. MSAFP 

4. Serum inhibin

questions.text: The type of fracture shown in the image below occurs due to:

choices.text: Elasticity of the bones in children
Blow from a heavy weapon with small striking surface

questions.solution:
The given image shows a depressed fracture of the skull. It occurs when a heavy weapon with a small striking surface is used. This fracture also indicates the impression of the weapon used. Hence, it is known as a signature fracture.

Other options:

Option B- Elasticity of the bones in children prevents the formation of fracture lines. This results in only indentation of the skull known as Pond's fracture.

Option D- An oblique bullet wound may lead to a gutter fracture.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: Wobble hypothesis states that _________

choices.text: The degeneracy of the genetic code resides in the first nucleotide of the codon triplet
The degeneracy of the genetic code resides in the middle nucleotide of the codon triplet
The degeneracy of the genetic code resides in the last nucleotide of the codon triplet
The degeneracy of the genetic code resides in all the nucleotides of the codon triplet

questions.solution:
The degeneracy of the genetic code resides in the last nucleotide of the codon triplet. 

Wobble hypothesis essentially conveys that the base pairing which occurs between the last nucleotide and the corresponding nucleotide of the anticodon is not necessarily based on the Watson-Crick rule. It helps to explain the degeneracy of the genetic code.

For example, three codons for glycine—GGU, GGC, and GGA—can form a base pair from one anticodon, 3′ CCI 5′ ie, I, inosine, can base pair with U, C, and A, as shown in the diagram below.

questions.text:
Match the following visual field defects with the site of the lesion

A. Optic radiations in the parietal lobe

B. Central chiasma

C. Optic radiations in the temporal lobe

D. Lateral chiasma
questions.solution:
The correctly matched lesions and their visual field defects are as follows:

Image 1 - B. Central chiasma
Image 2 - C. Optic radiations in the temporal lobe
Image 3 - A. Optic radiations in the parietal lobe
Image 4 - D. Lateral chiasma

Image 1: Bitemporal hemianopia due to lesion of central chiasma. The causes include tumors in the sella turcica region, suprasellar aneurysm pressure, and chronic arachnoiditis. It presents with bitemporal hemianopic paralysis of pupillary reflexes.

Image 2: Superior quadrantic hemianopia is also known as pie in the sky defect. It is caused when lesions affect the inferior fibers of the optic radiations in the temporal lobe. Lesions of the optic radiations spare pupillary reflexes and atrophy of the optic disc is not seen. The causes include vascular occlusions, primary/secondary tumors, trauma, and injuries sustained during lobectomy.

Image 4: Binasal hemianopia due to lesion of lateral chiasma. The causes include distention of the third ventricle, and atheromas of the carotids/posterior communicating arteries. It presents with binasal hemianopic paralysis of the pupillary reflexes.

Image 3: Inferior quadrantic hemianopia also known as pie on the floor defect. It is caused dues to parietal lobe lesions affecting the superior fibers of the optic radiations. 

Related Pearl: Lesions in the optic pathway

Transection of the pathways at the locations indicated by the letters causes the visual field defects shown in the diagram above.

  • The fibers from the nasal half of each retina decussate in the optic chiasm, so that the fibers in the optic tracts are those from the temporal half of one retina and the nasal half of the other.
  • A lesion that interrupts the optic nerve causes blindness in that eye.
  • Lesions affecting the optic chiasma destroy fibers from both nasal hemiretinas and produce a heteronymous (opposite sides of the visual fields) hemianopia.
  • A lesion in one optic tract causes blindness in half of the visual field and is called homonymous (same side of both visual fields) hemianopia (half-blindness).
  • Occipital lesions may spare the fibers from the macula because of the separation in the brain of these fibers from the other subserving vision.

questions.text: An infant seems normal at birth but develops breathing difficulties shortly after birth with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. His urine was found to have a characteristic smell of tomcat urine. Which of the following is used in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine odor is seen in Multiple carboxylase deficiency. Affected infants should be treated with Biotin.

Multiple carboxylase deficiency refers to one of two inherited defects of biotin metabolism.

  • The neonatal/infantile form is caused by a deficiency of holocarboxylase synthetase and presents in the first week of life with lethargy, poor muscle tone, and vomiting.
  • Juvenile/late form is caused by biotinidase deficiency and is associated with a slow but progressive loss of biotin in the urine, leading to organic aciduria. It is characterized by alopecia, ataxia, ketoacidosis, dermatitis, seizures, myoclonus, and nystagmus.

Both infantile and late-onset multiple carboxylase deficiency can be treated with pharmacological doses of biotin.

It is called multiple carboxylase deficiency because biotin is a water-soluble vitamin that is a cofactor for all 4 carboxylase enzymes in humans:

  • Pyruvate carboxylase
  • Acetyl CoA carboxylase
  • Propionyl CoA carboxylase
  • 3-methylcrotonyl CoA carboxylase

Related Pearl: Inborn Errors of Amino Acid Metabolism and Their Associated Urine Odor

questions.text: A radiation oncologist uses radiotherapy as part of the treatment protocol for various tumors. This treatment modality is found to be least effective in which among the following tumors?
questions.solution:
Radiotherapy is least effective in melanoma as it is a highly radioresistant tumor.

Apoptosis occurs in response to radiation in some but not all cells. No meaningful apoptosis occurs in very radioresistant tumors like melanoma and glioblastoma.

Seminoma is a highly radiosensitive tumor and hence radiotherapy is commonly used for treatment.

Related Pearl: Radiosensitive and Radioresistant Tumors

Highly radiosensitive tumors :

  • Lymphoma
  • Seminoma
  • Myeloma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Wilms tumor

 Highly radioresistant tumors :

  • Melanoma
  • Osteosarcoma
  • Pancreatic carcinoma
  • Hepatic carcinoma
  • Renal cell carcinoma
  • glioblastoma

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman delivered a baby with the following anomaly. Further investigations revealed multiple anomalies like tracheoesophageal fistula, vertebral,  anal, cardiac, renal, and arterial defects. Which of the following drug taken by the mother is most likely to be responsible for the baby's condition?
questions.solution:
The image shows a newborn with radial aplasia of the right arm. This feature, along with the given clinical presentation, describes VACTERL defects. This condition is associated with maternal intake of statins. 

VACTERL defects is an acronym for a group of congenital malformations which characteristically include:

  • Vertebral defects
  • Anal atresia
  • Cardiovascular malformation
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula with esophageal atresia
  • Radial/Renal dysplasia
  • Limb anomalies

Genito-urinary anomalies (ambiguous genitalia, genitourinary fistula, cryptorchidism) and other system anomalies like facial asymmetry, external ear malformation, etc. can also be found in these patients.

VACTERL defects have been associated with maternal exposure to statins, doxorubicin, and lead. They are also associated with maternal diabetes.

Other options:

Option A: Penicillamine causes cutis laxa syndrome. Cutis laxa is a group of rare connective tissue disorders in which the skin becomes inelastic and hangs loosely in folds. Maternal exposure to penicillamine was found to be associated with cutis laxa in infants.

The image below shows cutis laxa:

 

Option B: Vitamin D causes supravalvular aortic stenosis.

Option C: Lithium causes Ebstein anomaly. 

Related Pearl: Teratogenic drugs and the birth defects

Drugs Adverse effects
Penicillamine Cutis laxa syndrome
Lithium Ebstein anomaly
Isotretinoin Facial-ear anomalies, heart disease, CNS anomalies
Progesterone Masculinization of the female fetus
Quinine Abortion, thrombocytopenia, deafness
Topiramate Cleft lip
Valproate Spina bifida, limb defects, autism spectrum disorder, facial and cardiac anomalies, Coarctation of the aorta, Aortic stenosis, Pulmonary atresia, Ventricular Septal Defect. 
Vitamin D Supravalvular aortic stenosis
Warfarin Fetal bleeding, hypoplastic nasal structures
Statins Vertebral, anal, cardiac, tracheoesophageal fistula, renal, arterial, limb (VACTERAL) defects
Phenytoin Ventricular septal defect, Atrial Septal Defect, Coarctation of the aorta, Patent Ductus Arteriosus
ACE inhibitors and ARBs

Hypoplasia of organs, anuria, irreversible renal failure
Carbimazole and Methimazole  

Choanal atresia, aplasia cutis, tracheoesophageal fistula and fetal goiter
Alcohol Atrial Septal Defect, Ventricular Septal Defect

questions.text: A 4-month-old infant was brought to the OPD with complaints of several episodes of seizures. During the examination, the baby was found to have fair skin, blue eyes, and developmental delay. The laboratory tests revealed elevated levels of phenylalanine and was diagnosed with phenylketonuria. The infant was placed on a low-phenylalanine diet with tyrosine supplementation, but the baby continued to have neurological symptoms. A defect in which of the following enzymes would best explain the given condition?
questions.solution:
Phenylketonuria can be caused by a defect in phenylalanine hydroxylase or dihydropteridin reductase. In this case, restriction of phenylalanine and supplementation of tyrosine did not improve symptoms, so the defect in dihydropteridin reductase best explains the condition.

Dihydropteridine reductase is required for the conversion of dihydrobiopterin to tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4). BH4 is the coenzyme for phenylalanine hydroxylase, tyrosine hydroxylase, and tryptophan hydroxylase. In addition to decreased levels of tyrosine, these patients also have decreased levels of catecholamines and 5-hydroxytryptophan. Therefore the symptoms do not improve with the restriction of phenylalanine alone. It also requires supplementation with BH4, dihydroxyphenylalanine, and 5-hydroxytryptophan.

Phenylketonuria

It is the most common inborn error of amino acid metabolism. It commonly occurs due to a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (classic phenylketonuria). Less commonly it can also occur due to a defect in dihydropteridin reductase. These defects result in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. The patient develops clinical features due to elevated levels of phenylalanine metabolites and decreased levels of tyrosine.

Clinical features include intellectual disability, developmental delay, and seizures. Fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes are seen due to tyrosine deficiency which is required for melanin synthesis.

Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of phenylalanine. Ferric chloride test, Guthrie test, and Tandem mass spectrometry can help in the diagnosis.

A diet low in phenylalanine and supplementation of tyrosine can prevent the mental retardation of PKU. Other treatment options are large neutral amino acid supplementation, sapropterin (commercially available BH4), and the use of the enzyme substitute pegvaliase (phenylalanine ammonia-lyase).

Related Pearl: Phenylketonuria

  1. BH4 - tetrahydrobiopterin (or sapropterin, a synthetic form of BH4)

questions.text:
Which of the following conditions are characterized by metastatic calcification?
  1. Renal failure
  2. Milk-alkali syndrome
  3. Advanced Atheromatous plaque
  4. Sarcoidosis
  5. Papillary thyroid cancer
questions.solution:
Metastatic calcification can be seen in renal failure, milk-alkali syndrome, and sarcoidosis. Advanced Atheromatous plaque and Monckeberg medial sclerosis present with dystrophic calcification.

Pathologic calcification is the abnormal tissue deposition of calcium salts, together with smaller amounts of iron, magnesium, and other mineral salts. It is of two types namely metastatic and dystrophic calcification.

Metastatic calcification is the deposition of calcium salts in otherwise normal tissues. Metastatic calcification can be seen in interstitial tissues of the gastric mucosa, kidneys, lungs, systemic arteries, and pulmonary veins. It occurs in case of hypercalcemia secondary to some disturbance in calcium metabolism. The principal causes of hypercalcemia:

  • Increased secretion of parathyroid hormone (PTH)
  • Resorption of bone tissue in multiple myeloma, skeletal metastasis, and Paget's disease
  • Vitamin-D-related disorders such as Vitamin D toxicity and sarcoidosis (Option 4)
  • Renal failure (Option 1) causes retention of phosphate which leads to secondary hyperparathyroidism
  • Aluminum intoxication
  • Milk-alkali syndrome (Option 2) due to excess ingestion of calcium and absorbable antacids (milk or calcium carbonate) 

Dystrophic calcification is the deposition of calcium salts in dying tissues and areas of necrosis. It occurs even in the presence of normal calcium levels. It may be seen in atherosclerosis (Option 3), aging/damaged heart valves, and tuberculous lymph nodes. Papillary thyroid cancer (Option 5) has dystrophic calcification in the form of psammoma bodies.

Related Pearl: Types of calcifications

  Dystrophic calcification Metastatic calcification
Location Dead and dying tissues Normal interstitial tissues of the vasculature, kidneys, lungs, and gastric mucosa.
Calcium metabolism Normal deranged causing hypercalcemia
Examples

Calcific valvular stenosis

Advanced Atheromatous plaque

Monckeberg medial sclerosis

Parathyroid tumors

Hypercalcemia of malignancy

Paget disease

vitamin D intoxication

Sarcoidosis

Renal failure

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypercalcemia

  • Parathyroid-Related
    • Primary hyperparathyroidism
      • Adenoma(s)
      • Multiple endocrine neoplasia
      • Carcinoma
    • Lithium therapy
    • Familial hypocalciuric hypercalcemia
  • Malignancy-Related
    • Solid tumour with metastases (breast)
    • Solid tumour with humoral mediation of hypercalcemia (lung, kidney)
    • Hematologic malignancies (multiple myeloma, lymphoma, leukemia)
  • Vitamin D–Related
    • Vitamin D intoxication
    • ↑ 1,25(OH)2D :
      • Sarcoidosis and other granulomatous diseases
      • Impaired 1,25(OH)2D metabolism due to 24-hydroxylase deficiency
    • Associated with high bone turnover
      • Hyperthyroidism
      • Immobilization
      • Thiazides
      • Vitamin A intoxication
      • Fat necrosis
    • Associated with renal failure
      • Severe secondary hyperparathyroidism
      • Aluminium intoxication
      • Milk-alkali syndrome

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl presenting with blood in stool has the following examination findings. Her father had similar complaints at the age of 10 and was recently diagnosed with pancreatic cancer. The patient's biopsy samples are obtained after a colonoscopy. What are the most likely histological changes to be seen?
questions.solution:
A young child with blood in stools, positive family history, and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation as shown in the image is suggestive of Peutz-Jeghers syndrome. Hamartomous polyps with normal epithelium are seen in this condition.

Peutz-Jeghers syndrome is an autosomal dominant condition that is characterized by the formation of multiple hamartomatous polyps in the gastrointestinal tract (small intestine, colon, and stomach) and mucocutaneous hyperpigmentation. The hyperpigmentation typically appears as dark blue to brown macules on the lips, nostrils, buccal mucosa, palmar surfaces of the hands, genitalia, and perianal region. This rare syndrome presents at a median age of 11 years. This condition is associated with an increased risk of malignancies which include cancers of the stomach and small intestines, colon, pancreas, breast, and lungs.

The histopathological findings of the polyps reveal an arborizing network (freely branching) of glands that are lined by the normal intestinal epithelium, as seen in the image below: 


Other options:

Both ulcerative colitis (option A) and Crohn's disease (option C) can present with blood in stools, however, they have a bimodal median age of presentation (2nd-4th decades of life and 7th-9th decades of life). 

Option A - Pseudopolyps with submucosal crypt abscesses are the histopathological findings seen in ulcerative colitis. It is a form of inflammatory bowel disease. It involves the entirety of the colon (pancolitis) and presents with bloody mucoid diarrhea and cramping abdominal pain.

Here is an image showing crypt abscesses limited to the mucosa and submucosa as seen in ulcerative colitis:


Option C - Noncaseating granulomas with transmural ulcers and skip lesions are histopathological findings as seen in Crohn's disease. 

It is also a form of inflammatory bowel disease that commonly involves the terminal ileum but can affect any portion of the GI tract. Patients usually present with iron deficiency anemia and sporadic attacks of mild diarrhea, fever, and abdominal pain.

Here is an image showing noncaseating granulomas as seen in Crohn's disease:


Option D - Adenomatous polyps with epithelial dysplasia are seen in neoplastic polyps. The patients usually present in adulthood.

These can range from small and pedunculated to large and sessile. It is a premalignant pathology that has a high risk of progression to colonic adenocarcinoma. Types of neoplastic/adenomatous polyps include tubular, tubulovillous, and villous polyps. Common histological findings include markers of epithelial dysplasia such as nuclear hyperchromasia, elongation, and stratification. 

The image below shows tubular and villous adenomas seen in neoplastic polyps:

Related Pearl: Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome

  • Autosomal-dominant disease
  • Germline defects in the tumor suppressor serine-threonine kinase 11 (STK11) gene on chromosome 19.

Features:

  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, and digits
  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract (stomach - rectum).
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Screening: Baseline colonoscopy and upper endoscopy at age 20 years, followed by annual flexible sigmoidoscopy thereafter.

 

Histologic image showing the characteristic arborizing network of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands lined by normal-appearing intestinal epithelium:

questions.text: A person is not exempt from criminal responsibility when he commits a crime in which of the following states?
questions.solution:
The person is not exempt from criminal responsibility when he commits a crime during voluntary drunkenness.

The person is not criminally responsible during the following conditions

  • Somnambulism (Option B) also known as sleepwalking, is when people get up and walk around while asleep.
  • Somolentia
  • Delirium tremens (Option C) - It is a severe form of alcohol withdrawal. It involves sudden and severe mental or nervous system changes.
  • Involuntary drunkenness
  • Post-traumatic automatism
  • Oneroid state (Option D) - A dream-like fantastic delusional derangement of consciousness, is characterized by a kaleidoscopic quality of psychopathological experiences, wherein reality, illusions and hallucinations are merged into one. It is typically accompanied by motor and, in particular, catatonic disturbances.
  • Twilight state

The tests to determine criminal responsibility include:

  • McNaughten's rule (included in Sec. 84 of IPC)
  • Durham rule
  • Curren’s rule
  • The Irresistible Impulse Test (New Hampshire Doctrine)
  • The American Law Institute (ALI) Test
  • The Federal Rule

 

Related Pearl: Criminal Responsibilities

BNS section

Previous IPC Section

Deals with

questions.text: What is the investigation of choice for renal scarring in reflux nephropathy?
questions.solution:
Tc-99m DMSA (dimercaptosuccinic acid) is used in renal imaging to evaluate renal structure and morphology, particularly in paediatric imaging for detection of scarring and pyelonephritis.

  • DMSA is an ideal agent for the assessment of renal cortex as it binds to the sulfhydryl groups in proximal tubules at the renal cortex with longer retention than other agents.
  • It allows better assessment of differential renal function. It is a static scan as opposed to dynamic DTPA or MAG3 scans.

Other Options:

  • Tc-99m DTPA (diethylene-triamine-pentaacetate) is cleared only via glomeruli with no tubular excretion and hence used for direct measurement of GFR.
  • Tc-99m MAG3 (mercaptoacetyltriglycine) is excreted through renal route via both glomeruli infiltration and tubular excretion; hence, in paediatric patients and patients with poor renal function this test is considered superior to DTPA scan.
  • The screening investigation used in renovascular hypertension is Captopril DTPA and gold standard investigation is renal angiography.

questions.text:
Match the following laboratory findings with their respective interpretations.
Laboratory findings Interpretation
1. Anti-HBs only A. Acute HBV infection
2. HBsAg, HBeAg, IgM Anti-HBc 

B. Recovered from HBV
3. HBsAg, Anti-HBe, IgG Anti-HBc C. Vaccinated against HBV
4. Anti-HBs, IgG Anti-HBc, Anti-HBe D. Inactive HBV carrier state
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Laboratory findings Interpretation
1. Anti-HBs only C. Vaccinated against HBV
2. HBsAg, HBeAg, IgM Anti-HBc 

A. Acute HBV infection
3. HBsAg, Anti-HBe, IgG Anti-HBc D. Inactive HBV carrier state 
4. Anti-HBs, IgG Anti-HBc, Anti-HBe B. Recovered from HBV

 

HBsAg. It usually becomes positive by 1-12 weeks following infection. In resolving acute HBV hepatitis, the HBsAg becomes undetectable by 8 weeks following the onset of jaundice. After HBsAg disappears, anti-HBs antibodies appear and remain detectable lifelong. 

There might be a gap of several weeks between the disappearance of HBsAg and the appearance of anti-HBs. During this window period, the diagnosis of acute hepatitis is made by the presence of IgM anti-HBc antibodies. Anti-HBc antibodies are the first antibodies to appear in the serum. They usually appear within 1-2 weeks after HBsAg becomes positive. 6 months after the acute infection, the IgG subtype of the anti-HBc becomes prominent.

HBeAg and HBV DNA are qualitative and quantitative markers of viral replication respectively. During acute infection, there is a disappearance of HBeAg and the appearance of anti-HBe antibodies. In chronic HBV infection, HBsAg remains detectable and anti-HBs are absent. Furthermore, HBeAg may be present if it is active type of chronic hepatitis.

Related Pearl: Interpretation of common serologic patterns in hepatitis B infection

questions.text: A 30-year-old male has been tested positive for SARS-COV-2. His household contacts are screened for the same, despite the absence of symptoms. What is the level of prevention employed here?
questions.solution:
Screening is a type of secondary prevention.

It is done to detect the disease in its early stages. Secondary prevention includes early disease detection, and its target is healthy-appearing individuals with subclinical forms of the disease. This is defined as the action which halts the progress of the disease at its incipient stage before it becomes clinically apparent and prevents complications. Screening tests and early diagnosis are the specific intervention used in the secondary level of prevention and they help to arrest the disease process.

Related Pearl: Lead Time in Screening

Lead time is the period between the first possible time of detection and the usual time of diagnosis.

Lead time is the advantage gained by screening. It helps in the early diagnosis and treatment of disease. Early treatment reduces the severity by reversing the disease process.

Related Pearl: Levels of Prevention

questions.text:
A 16-year-old girl presented with complaints of irregular periods, acne, and increased facial hair growth. USG revealed multiple ovarian follicles arranged in a necklace pattern. Which of the following is not true regarding the endocrinological changes of this condition?

PCOD- Polycystic Ovarian Disease.

SHBG- Sex hormone binding globulin
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the given clinical scenario is polycystic ovarian disease. FSH/LH ratio falls in PCOD

In PCOS, Serum FSH will be normal but FSH/LH ratio falls.

Polycystic ovarian syndrome multisystem, metabolic, endocrine dysfunction that commonly occurs among women in the reproductive age group. It has multifactorial causation, such as lifestyle changes, stress, diet, obesity, and hyperinsulinemic states.

Important clinical features of PCOS are:

  • Menstrual abnormalities - oligomenorrhea, amenorrhea. Dysmenorrhoea is absent.
  • Obesity
  • Hirsutism, acne, and alopecia due to hyperandrogenism
  • Acanthosis nigricans due to insulin resistance
  • Infertility

Rotterdam criterion is used to diagnose PCOS. The presence of any two of the three components of this criteria establishes the diagnosis of PCOS.

  •  Oligo/ amenorrhoea, anovulation, infertility
  • Hirsutism/ acne
  • Ultrasound findings-

    • Enlarged ovaries with the ovarian volume of more than 10 mL

    • 12 or more small follicles each  2-9 mm in size placed peripherally.

     

The ultrasound image below shows an enlarged ovary with multiple follicles in the periphery.

 

Related Pearl: Management of PCOD

Complaint Management  
Irregular periods OCPs
Obesity Lifestyle modification
Insulin resistance Metformin
Hirsutism /acne OCPs with cyproterone acetate
Infertility Clomiphene

Note: Letrozole is as effective as Clomiphene in treating infertility in PCOD with fewer side effects. However, it's pending FDA approval and is used off-label.

Related Pearl: Endocrinological changes of PCOD

  1. Elevated Estrone/E1 levels.
  2. LH level is raised over 10 IU/mL. FSH level remains normal to low, but FSH/LH ratio falls.
  3. Testosterone and epi-androstenedione levels rise.
    • Testosterone elevated but < 200 ng/dL (normal range 20 -80 ng/dL)
    • Testosterone > 200 ng/dL suggests androgen-secreting ovarian tumor
    • DHEA-S values may be normal or slightly elevated
    • DHEA >700 ng/mL suggests adrenal tumour
  4. Serum SHBG is reduced.
  5. Triglyceride level >150 mg/dL-hyperlipidaemia HDL <50 mg/dL.
  6. Fasting blood glucose/fasting insulin <4.5 suggests insulin resistance
  7. Prolactin is mildly raised in 15% cases
  8. Fasting insulin is more than 10 mIU/L in PCOS in 50–70%cases
  9. Thyroid function tests may be abnormal (hypothyroidism)
  10. 17-a-hydroxyprogesterone in the follicular phase >300 ng/dL suggests adrenal hyperplasia due to 21-hydroxylase deficiency.
  11. Urinary cortisol <50 μg/24 h.

questions.text: Deficiency of which of the following complement components causes hereditary angioneurotic edema?
questions.solution:
C1 esterase inhibitor (C1 INH) blocks the activation of C1, the first protein of the classical complement pathway, and inherited deficiency of this inhibitor is the cause of hereditary angioedema.

The targets of C1 inhibitor are proteases, specifically C1r and C1s of the complement cascade, factor XII of the coagulation pathway, and the kallikrein system. Hereditary angioneurotic edema is an autosomal dominant disorder where the deficiency of C1 INH leads to unregulated activation of kallikrein and increased production of vasoactive peptides such as bradykinin. Bradykinin is an inflammatory mediator that caused neutrophil chemotaxis, capillary dilatation with plasma leakage, and smooth muscle relaxation.

Episodes of edema affecting the skin and mucosal surfaces such as the larynx and the gastrointestinal tract, which may result in life-threatening asphyxia or nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea after minor trauma or emotional stress.

Clinical syndromes associated with genetic deficiencies of complement components are as follows:

Deficiency Syndrome
C1 esterase inhibitor Hereditary angioneurotic edema
C1, C2, C4 SLE and other collagen vascular diseases

C3 and its regulatory protein

C3b inactivator

 Severe recurrent pyogenic infections
C5 to C8 Bacteremia, mainly with gram-negative diplococci, toxoplasmosis
C9 No particular disease

questions.text: A 50-year-old man with lung cancer, presents with difficulty in activities like climbing stairs, getting up from a chair, combing hair, etc. The following characteristic sign was found on examination. The most probable diagnosis is:
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is dermatomyositis.

Features that point to a diagnosis of dermatomyositis are:

  • Image showing - upper eyelid lilac erythema/ heliotrope rash 
  • Age group 50-60 yrs
  • Proximal myopathy which is manifested as difficulty in climbing stairs, getting up from chairs, lifting hands, etc.
  • Association with internal malignancy (lung cancer)

The classic cutaneous signs in dermatomyositis:

  • Facial rash
  • Eyelid erythema and edema
  • Nail fold changes
  • Gottron’s papules
  • Shawl sign - macular erythema of the upper chest and back
  • Scalp erythema and hair loss
  • Flagellate erythema
  • Mechanic’s hands
  • Poikiloderma
  • Cutaneous calcinosis

The following images show Gottron's papules on hand and V-shaped rash over chest, respectively:

questions.text: A 4-month-old baby presented with a history of constipation, lethargy, and has poor activities. Clinical examination reveals jaundice,  hypotonia and there was no palpable goiter. Laboratory investigations revealed a low T4 and elevated TSH levels. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The likely diagnosis in this clinical scenario is thyroid dysgenesis. History of constipation, lethargy, poor activities, jaundice, and hypotonia is suggestive of primary hypothyroidism. Since the child is 4 months of age, this is a case of congenital hypothyroidism. Congenital hypothyroidism with no palpable goiter, low T4, and elevated TSH is suggestive of thyroid dysgenesis. It is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism.

Thyroid dysgenesis is the aplasia, hypoplasia, or an ectopic thyroid gland.

Causes of Congenital hypothyroidism:

         Goitrous

    (Palpable goiter)

     Non-goitrous

   (No palpable goiter)
  • Thyroid dyshormonogenesis
  • Iodine deficiency
  • Placental passage of antithyroid drugs
  • Thyroid dysgenesis
  • Thyroid receptor blocking antibodies
  • Central hypothyroidism

 

Clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism:

  • Prolongation of physiologic hyperbilirubinemia: early sign (it is due to delayed maturation of glucuronide conjugation)
  • Constipation: usually does not respond to treatment
  • Wide open anterior and posterior fontanelles (>0.5 cm) and cranial sutures
  • Developmental delay, delayed bone growth, delayed dentition
  • Cardiovascular: slow pulse rate, cardiomegaly, asymptomatic pericardial effusion, edema
  • Respiratory: macroglossia, feeding difficulties, choking spells, respiratory difficulties
  • Hematological: macrocytic anemia refractory to treatment with haematinics
  • Nervous system: hypothermia, hypotonia, slow relaxation of deep tendon reflexes, sluggishness, and somnolence.

 

Laboratory Findings:

Condition Goitre T4 TSH
Thyroid dysgenesis Absent Low Elevated
Thyroid dyshormonogenesis Present Low Elevated
Thyroid receptor blocking antibodies Absent Low Elevated
Central hypothyroidism Absent Low Normal/Low

questions.text: A 25-year-old primigravida at 34 weeks of gestation was admitted as her BP was 150/90mmHg and urine dipstick was 2+ on antenatal checkup. Which of the following drugs is least suited for her management?
questions.solution:
Captopril is an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor and it is contraindicated in pregnancy.

High BP and proteinuria are diagnostic of preeclampsia. The following drugs may be used for the management of pre-eclampsia.

Drug Dose
Labetalol

100 mg TID or QID

Methyl-dopa

250–500 mg TID or QID

Nifedipine

10–20 mg BD

Hydralazine

10–25 mg BD

ACE inhibitors inhibit the conversion of angiotensin I to the potent vasoconstrictor angiotensin-II. When given in pregnancy, they can cause severe fetal malformations such as:

  • IUGR
  • Fetal renal tubular dysgenesis.
  • Neonatal renal failure.
  • Pulmonary hypoplasia.

Anti-hypertensives to be avoided in pregnancy include:

  • ACE inhibitors.
  • Angiotensin receptor blockers.
  • Diuretics (contraindicated as anti-hypertensive but can be given in congestive cardiac failure).
  • Sodium nitroprusside (used only as a drug of last resort in refractory severe hypertension)

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements regarding Hashimoto's thyroiditis:
  1. It most commonly causes hyperthyroidism.
  2. Antibodies against thyroid peroxidase are seen. 
  3. Thyroid profile shows low TSH and high T4.
  4. It is associated with thyroid lymphomas.

TSH - Thyroid-stimulating hormone

T4 - Thyroxine
questions.solution:
Statements 2 and 4 are correct regarding Hashimoto's thyroiditis. It is characterized by the presence of antibodies against thyroid peroxidase and is associated with thyroid lymphomas.

Statements 1 and 3 are false. Hashimoto's thyroiditis, most commonly causing hypothyroidism (not hyperthyroidism), is associated with high TSH and low T4 levels (not low TSH and high T4). 

Hashimoto's thyroiditis is the most common cause of hypothyroidism in iodine-sufficient areas. It is an autoimmune disease that results in the destruction of the thyroid gland and gradual and progressive thyroid failure.

It occurs most commonly among middle-aged women. It is associated with malignant lymphoma of thyroid.

Patients present with painless diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland. Since the follicles are damaged and cannot form the hormones anymore, these patients tend to be in a state of hypothyroidism. However, initially few patients may present with a transient hyperthyroid state, known as hashitoxicosis, due to the release of thyroid hormones by disruption of the thyroid follicles.

Laboratory investigations:

  • T3 and T4 are low
  • TSH is raised
  • Presence of autoantibodies against:
    • Thyroid peroxidase (TPO)
    • Thyroglobulin

Histopathology of Hashimoto's thyroiditis:

Morphologically, there is a diffuse enlargement of the thyroid gland, with an intact capsule. It is well demarcated from the adjacent structures.

Microscopic features include:

  • Intense lymphocytic infiltrate containing small lymphocytes, plasma cells, and well-developed germinal centres.
  • Atrophied thyroid follicles, lined by epithelial cells, contain eosinophilic granular cytoplasm. These epithelial cells are referred to as Hurthle cells.

Hürthle cells arise from the follicular epithelium. These oncocytic cells include an eosinophilic granular cytoplasm.

The following image shows a histopathological picture of Hashimoto thyroiditis :

 

Note:

  • Low TSH and high T4 levels can be seen in hyperthyroidism. Causes of hyperthyroidism includes Grave's disease, toxic goitre, and toxic adenoma.
  • Low TSH and normal T4 levels are seen in subclinical hyperthyroidism.
  • High TSH and normal T4 levels are seen in subclinical hypothyroidism.

Related Pearl: Causes of Hypothyroidism

 

Primary

(Low T3, T4 → Raised TSH levels)

Secondary

(Low TSH levels → Low T3, T4)

Tertiary

(Low TRH → Low TSH → Low T3,T4)

questions.text: The CT of a patient with a vertebral hemangioma would demonstrate _______.

choices.text: Corduroy sign in the axial section and Polka dot sign in the sagittal section
Corduroy sign in the sagittal section and Polka dot sign in the axial section
Both Corduroy sign and Polka dot sign in the sagittal section
Both Corduroy sign and Polka dot sign in the axial section

questions.solution:
In patients with vertebral hemangioma, corduroy sign is seen in the sagittal and coronal section and polka dot sign is seen in the axial section of CT scans.

Hemangioma is typically a benign tumor of the vertebral body. This tumor is mostly clinically silent and is usually detected incidentally. The vertebral body is the most common location for hemangioma. Atypical location of hemangioma is the posterior elements of the vertebra and is indicative of an aggressive lesion. Symptomatic hemangiomas usually present with pain, neurologic compromise, or fractures.

Radiographs show large lesions with vertical striations and coarse, thick trabeculae, giving a corduroy appearance in sagittal and coronal sections. It is also known as the jail bar sign.

On an axial computed tomography (CT) scan, hemangioma shows a classic polka dot appearance. MRI is the standard for diagnosing hemangiomas.

Treatment: Most hemangiomas do not require treatment. Vertebroplasty is useful in aggressive hemangiomas. 

The below CT image shows characteristic polka dot appearance (left) and corduroy appearance (right):

The name corduroy comes from the similarity to the corduroy cloth (seen in the image below) in appearance.

questions.text:
Choose the correct statements about the drugs used in the management of pulmonary artery hypertension.
  1. Combination therapy in treatment-naive patients is associated with a lower risk of clinical worsening.
  2. Riociguat stimulates soluble adenylyl cyclase.
  3. Bosentan is a selective blocker of the endothelin A receptor.
  4. Epoprostenol is administered by continuous IV infusion.
  5. Selexipag is a prostacyclin receptor antagonist.
questions.solution:
In the treatment of pulmonary artery hypertension (PAH), combination therapy with two drugs when the patient presents for the first time is associated with a lower risk of clinical worsening. One of the approved drugs in the management of PAH is epoprostenol. It is synthetic prostacyclin which is administered by continuous IV infusion.

NO causes vasodilation by stimulating soluble guanylyl cyclase (sGC) enzyme and increasing cGMP levels. In patients with PAH, NO is used for vasoreactivity testing. If there is an adequate response to inhaled NO, then DHP-type calcium channel blockers such as sustained-release nifedipine can be used for the management of PAH. Inhaled NO is also used for the management of persistent pulmonary hypertension of newborn. Riociguat is another drug used in PAH that activates soluble guanylyl cyclase enzyme (statement 2) and causes vasodilation.

Endothelin antagonists that are used for PAH include drugs like ambrisentan, bosentan, and macitentan. While bosentan and macitentan block both endothelin A and B (statement 3) receptors, ambrisentan is a selective blocker of endothelin A receptors. The adverse effects of endothelin antagonists include pulmonary edema, risk of testicular atrophy, and elevated liver enzymes.

Epoprostenol was the first synthetic prostacyclin. It is given by a continuous IV infusion by a drug delivery pump. The adverse effects include myalgia, headache, flushing, diarrhea, and hypotension. Treprostinil is a prostacyclin analog that is available as an IV infusion, subcutaneous injection, inhalation, and oral delivery. Iloprost is another prostacyclin analog available as an inhaled formulation. Selexipag is an orally active prostacyclin receptor agonist (statement 5).

Another class of drugs used in PAH is phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitors. These drugs prevent the breakdown of cGMP by phosphodiesterase, thus keeping the vessels in a dilated state. This class of drugs includes sildenafil and tadalafil. Headache and flushing are the most commonly reported side effects.

Related Pearl: Drugs used in Pulmonary Arterial Hypertension (PAH)

questions.text: Which of the following is not an indication to start treatment in subclinical hypothyroidism?
questions.solution:
TSH 7 mIU/L in a patient with subclinical hypothyroidism is not an indication to start levothyroxine therapy.

Subclinical hypothyroidism refers to a situation when serum TSH is raised but T3 and T4 are the lower end of the normal reference range. This can persist for many years and can progress to overt hypothyroidism. The risk of progression is higher in patients who have antibodies against thyroid peroxidase, and those who have serum TSH > 10 mIU/L.

  • Pregnant patient
  • Female patient who wishes to conceive
  • Symptoms of hypothyroidism present
  • Risk of heart disease present
  • TSH > 10 mIU/L
  • Antibodies to thyroid peroxidase present

Any TSH elevation should be confirmed to be present over a period of three months before considering treatment. Treatment is by starting a low dose of levothyroxine (25-50 μg/day) to normalize TSH levels.

questions.text: Which of the following atypical antipsychotics has the highest risk of galactorrhea?
questions.solution:
Among atypical antipsychotics, risperidone, paliperidone and amisulpride have a higher risk of galactorrhoea.

Tuberoinfundibular neurons project from the arcuate nucleus of the hypothalamus to the anterior pituitary. Dopamine is delivered in this region via the hypophyseal vessels. Dopamine binds to the D2 receptors present on the lactotropes in the anterior pituitary, and tonically inhibits the prolactin secretion from these cells. 

The more potent a D2 blocking drug is, the more likely it is to cause hyperprolactinemia. All first-generation antipsychotic drugs cause hyperprolactinemia due to their D2 blocking properties. Among the atypical antipsychotics, risperidone, paliperidone, and amisulpride are associated with hyperprolactinemia. Hyperprolactinemia can induce breast engorgement, galactorrhea, and infertility in women, and sexual dysfunction in men.

questions.text: A 16-month-child is brought with a history of abdominal distension and delayed mental development. On examination, the cornea is cloudy and there appears to be hepatosplenomegaly. The radiograph of the child is given below. What is the probable diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis in this patient is Hurler's syndrome.

As the child presents with mental retardation, hepatosplenomegaly, cloudy cornea and given x-ray shows a J-shaped sella turcica and a thickened calvaria, the most likely diagnosis is Hurler's Syndrome.

Hurler's syndrome is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 1. This is due to the defect in the α-L iduronidase leading to the accumulation of heparan sulphate and dermatan sulphate.

Radiological features in Hurler Syndrome:

  • Macrocephaly
  • J-shaped sella (seen in above radiograph)
  • Thickened calvaria (skull cap)
  • Oar-shaped ribs (seen below)
  • Hook-shaped vertebral bodies

 

Other options:

Option A- Tay-Sachs disease is a hereditary neurodegenerative disorder due to the deficiency of the enzyme hexosaminidase-A resulting in the excess storage of GM2 ganglioside within the lysosomes of cells. The clinical features include developmental delay, intellectual impairment, seizures, and breathing difficulty.

The CT image shows macrocephaly and reduced attenuation of the cerebral white matter. MRI can delineate deep white matter demyelination, and indicate calcification in thalami on T2 weighted sequences.

Option C- Gaucher disease is the most common lysosomal storage disorder characterized by autosomal recessive inheritance due to the deficiency of the glucocerebrosidase enzyme. This results in the accumulation of a glycolipid (glucocerebroside) within the lysosomes of macrophages.

The clinical features include bone pain, pathological fractures, bone crises hepatosplenomegaly, and hematological disturbances.

The radiological features of the skeletal involvement include osteopenia, osteonecrosis, fractures (pathological), Erlenmeyer flask deformity, and H-shaped vertebra.

Option D- Hunter's disease is also known as mucopolysaccharidosis 2 resulting from the deficiency of iduronate sulfatase. This causes the accumulation of dermatan sulfate and heparan sulfate.

The clinical features include abnormal facies characterized by the prominent forehead, flattened nasal bridge, coarse facies, gingival hyperplasia, macroglossia, short stature, dysostosis multiplex, macrocephaly, intellectual disability, hepatosplenomegaly.

These patients lack clouding of the cornea.

The radiological features include thickened calvaria, enlargement of the skull, broad clavicle and ribs, thoracolumbar kyphosis, hip dysplasia, and genu valgum deformity.

questions.text: Identify the marked artery.
questions.solution:
The artery marked is the posterior inferior cerebellar artery. This artery branches out from the vertebral artery and it is the largest branch of the vertebral artery.

The following image shows the circle of Willis.

Related Pearl: Circle of Willis

questions.text: A 34-year-old male was diagnosed with a urogenital tumor. History revealed that the patient had cryptorchidism in his childhood. Which of the following tumors is most likely to be seen in this patient?
questions.solution:
The most common cancer in patients who had cryptorchidism in childhood is seminoma.

The most common type of testicular cancer to develope in untreated undescended testes is seminoma. The cancer risk for adults who have history of cryptorchidism in childhood depends on the time of orchidopexy. 

  • Risk is 2-3 times greater if orchidopexy is done before puberty.
  • Risk is 5-10 times greater if orchidopexy is done after puberty.

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumor (GCT) (~50% of GCTs). The peak incidence is seen in the fourth decade. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma, or the pineal gland tumor termed germinoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and podoplanin and negative for cytokeratin.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of hemorrhage or necrosis as shown below.

The histological image shows sheets of uniform cells with clear cytoplasm and central nucleus, with a prominent nucleolus (fried-egg appearance). The sheets of cells are poorly demarcated into lobules by delicate fibrous septa containing a lymphocytic infiltrate.

Related Pearl: WHO 2016 classification of testicular tumors

I. Germ-cell tumors (GCTs) derived from germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Germ-cell neoplasia in situ
  • Seminoma
  • Non-seminomatous GCTs
    • Embryonal carcinoma
    • Yolk sac tumor, postpubertal-type
    • Choriocarcinoma
    • Teratoma, post-pubertal type
  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

II. Germ-cell tumors unrelated to germ-cell neoplasia in situ

  • Spermatocytic tumour
  • Teratoma, prepubertal type
  • Yolk sac tumor, prepubertal type
  • Mixed

III. Sex cord stromal tumors

  • Leydig cell tumor
  • Sertoli cell tumor
  • Granulosa cell tumor
  • Fibroma–thecoma

IV. Tumor containing both germ-cell and sex cord-stromal elements

  • Gonadoblastoma

V. Hematolymphoid tumors

  • Mixed germ-cell tumors

 Lactate dehydrogenase (LDH):

  • LDH has limited sensitivity and specificity for seminoma, but LDH levels >2000 U/L are more consistent with bulky disease, and rising levels are an accurate indicator of recurrence.
  •  In non-seminomatous germ-cell tumors (NSCGT), LDH is directly related to tumor burden.

questions.text:
Match the following drug interactions with their respective examples.
Drug interaction Example
1. Synergistic A. Cortisol + Epinephrine
2. Additive B. Levodopa + Carbidopa
3. Permissive C. Trimethoprim + Sulfamethoxazole
4. Potentiation D. Aspirin + Paracetamol
questions.solution:
The correct match is:

Drug interaction Example
1. Synergistic C. Trimethoprim + Sulfamethoxazole
2. Additive D. Aspirin + Paracetamol
3. Permissive A. Cortisol + Epinephrine 
4. Potentiation B. Levodopa + Carbidopa

 

When two or more drugs are given together, they can interact with each other in different ways:

Drug effect Definition Examples
Additive

The combined effect of two drugs equals the sum of the effects of individual drugs given alone.

Effect of A and B together = effect of A + effect of B.

Aspirin + paracetamol (analgesics)

Amlodipine + atenolol (antihypertensive)

Metformin + glibenclamide (antidiabetics)
Synergistic

The combined effect of two drugs exceeds the sum of the effects of individual drugs given alone.

Effect of A and B together > effect of A + effect of B.

Sulfamethoxazole + Trimethoprim

Aspirin + Clopidogrel
Potentiation One component alone does not produce any effect, but enhances the effect of the other component.

Levodopa + Carbidopa

Carbidopa itself doesn't have any activity at the dopamine receptor. It just functions only to block the peripheral conversion of levodopa.
Permissive The presence of one substance is required for the full effects of another substance

Glucocorticoids are required for the full effects of catecholamines
Antagonism One drug abolishes or decreases the action of another drug or physiological substance. Naloxone acts as antagonist to morphine at the opioid receptors.
